webTitle: The best musical taste scene: High Fidelity

fields.headline: The best musical taste scene: High Fidelity
fields.trailText: Chicago. Having split up with his girlfriend the previous night, Rob (John Cusack) trudges into work at his record store Championship Vinyl. His assistant, the mild-mannered Dick (Todd Louiso), is already listening to a tape. Rob looks puzzled.
fields.body:
Chicago. Having split up with his girlfriend the previous night, Rob (John Cusack) trudges into work at his record store Championship Vinyl. His assistant, the mild-mannered Dick (Todd Louiso), is already listening to a tape. Rob looks puzzled.

"What's this?"

"It's the new Belle And Sebastian," Dick enthuses. "Do you like it?"

Before Rob can answer, his other assistant Barry (Jack Black) strides in. He stops in his path, taking in the tune.

"What the fuck is this?"

"It's the new Belle And Sebastian," replies Dick.

"It's the record we've been listen ing to and enjoying, Barry," continues Rob.

"Well that's unfortunate," Barry mutters. "BECAUSE IT SUCKS ASS!"

Barry takes off the tape, and replaces it with another - Katrina And The Waves' Walking On Sunshine. He begins to dance around the shop, clapping and singing along. Rob and Dick look on miserably. Rob snaps.

"Turn it off, Barry."

"Sorry," bellows Barry, "it won't go any louder."

Rob switches the tape off himself.

"OK, I was just trying to cheer us up. So go ahead - put on your old sad bastard music. See if I care."

Rob eyes him across the counter.

"I don't want to hear old sad bastard music, Barry."

He stares at his feet.

"I just want something I can ignore."

See also: This Is Spinal Tap, Amadeus, Airheads

Don't see also: Grace Of My Heart

Pointless trivia: Making his screen debut in Tim Robbins's political satire Bob Roberts, Jack Black also provided backing vocals on the film's soundtrack.

webTitle: Comedy review: Edinburgh festival: Puppetry of the Penis

fields.headline: Australians do dick tricks
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh Festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Puppetry of the Penis
Pleasance Above ***
fields.body:
Puppetry of the Penis
Pleasance Above ***

Exactly what it says it is - no more and certainly no less: two unassuming and personable Australians do dick tricks. Manipulating their genitals into various objects and landmarks, they give you an eyeful of the Eiffel Tower, a cute little joey in a pouch, the Loch Ness monster and the Duke of Edinburgh. Kentucky Fried Chicken puts you off the idea altogether. Proceedings are also videoed and displayed on a large screen for the full, close-up effect. Men in the audience tend to spend the whole 50 minutes with their legs crossed and, thankfully, there are no chances for audience participation.

Once you've got over the initial pop-eyed "ouch" factor, this turns out to be a gently witty, surprisingly charming little show. It works because the guys are nice, apparently normal (well, as normal as anyone who waves their penis about for a living could be) and unembarrassed. Their patter is entertaining, and everything is done with a high degree of decorum. They may be flashing their genitals but they keep their socks and beanie hats on.

This is more Blue Peter than toilet humour; it has everything to do with origami and nothing to do with sex. The extraordinary, non-threatening flaccidity of the organs is one of the most fascinating features of this show. This is the penis de-sexualised. It is a freak show, but in the best possible taste.

I very much doubt even your great-granny would find it shocking, though she might wonder if it is art and worry about the long-term medical implications of using the penis like a pipe-cleaner.

Don't try this at home.

Till August 28. Box office: 0131-556 6550.

webTitle: Manufacturing's facts make global sense

fields.headline: Manufacturing's facts make global sense
fields.standfirst:
Industrial logic in the exchanges

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Life, it appears, is not so bad for manufacturers after all. Despite the gnashing of teeth from the Confederation of British Industry and other lobbying groups about the fearsome price being paid for the overvalued pound, the official figures tell a somewhat different story. Factory production was up by 0.4% in the latest quarter - hardly spectacular, but broadly in line with the economy's trend growth rate.
fields.body:
Life, it appears, is not so bad for manufacturers after all. Despite the gnashing of teeth from the Confederation of British Industry and other lobbying groups about the fearsome price being paid for the overvalued pound, the official figures tell a somewhat different story. Factory production was up by 0.4% in the latest quarter - hardly spectacular, but broadly in line with the economy's trend growth rate.

So what is going on out there? Are companies really clinging on by their fingertips or are they coming to terms with the high level of sterling and managing to stay competitive by cutting costs?

The most obvious explanation is that the high exchange rate is a slow burn phenomenon and that it will have a gradual, rather than dramatic, impact. The respite British manufacturing is at present enjoying as a result of the continued strength of the American economy and the recent pick-up in Europe will be brief.

An alternative and somewhat more optimistic scenario is that the strength of the pound is merely accelerating a trend in manufacturing that was already happening, albeit at a slower pace. Yesterday's industrial production figures show a clear split between the hi-tech parts of the economy and the rest - with output of mobile phones, computers and pharmaceuticals all booming.

On the other hand, firms producing textiles or food and drink are really hurting. This would appear to be part of an international division of labour associated with globalisation rather than simply the result of the exchange. However, people who have something to complain about are always more vociferous than those who are doing well - hence the apparent disparity between the survey evidence and the official figures.

No confidence?

Nycomed Amersham's chief executive, Sir William Castell, reckons that genetics will have as great an impact on this century as information technology did on the last. He believes that in 20 years' time it will be normal for individuals to have their DNA tested, and to have medicines personalised for their own specific needs.

Nycomed is in the vanguard of this revolution as one of a handful of big companies supplying machines which can examine DNA effectively. So it is worrying that Sir William wants to locate the jewel in the crown, Amersham Pharmacia Biotech, in the US.

There will be little immediate impact in the UK. None of the 800 British employees will lose their jobs - at least, not for now, although there must be a question mark over the chances of APB's willingness to make substantial future investments in Buckinghamshire. But it is the thinking behind the decision to raise its American profile via a Nasdaq listing and a US address that is cause for concern.

The decision about APB's future appears posited on where Sir William and his management team believe the biotech industry's centre of gravity will be - the US. If they are right, the decision makes sound commercial sense. Unfortunately it could also mean that although the UK has plenty of companies working hard at exploiting the results of gene technology, the country could miss out on the most lucrative part of the whole process - identifying useful genes in the first place.

BA - a hard slog

Managing British Airways is an unenviable task: it is facing a struggle on two fronts. Both appear to be a hard slog. The first task is to improve operating results after last year's hefty losses. The second is to negotiate an alliance with KLM that will satisfy both sets of shareholders in terms of valuation and industrial logic as well as keeping regulators on both sides of the Atlantic on board.

This, too, at a time of US-UK tension over air traffic liberalisation.

Yesterday's results from BA, and the accompanying commentary provided little by way of hard evidence regarding the likely outcome in either area. BA has its strategy for taking on the competition from low cost airlines - smaller planes, more emphasis on more profitable passengers, cutting loss-making routes.

But it is hard to assess to what extent the modest improvement in first quarter revenue figures was a direct result of the BA strategy and how much a general improvement in the industry. Nor will escalting fuel bills help the equation.

As to the possible link-up with KLM, BA's verdict is that the deal is a complex one; others might choose stronger terms. The public posturing suggests that any price acceptable to the KLM end will look very steep from BA's point of view. The negotiations will be tough.

Shareholders are unlikely to prove any trickier to persuade than regulators - particularly in the US. American regulators will be keen to use any leverage - and there will be plenty - that comes to hand to force a breakthrough in the stalled talks on air traffic liberalisation - otherwise known as greater access to slots at Heathrow. European regulators will want to have their say, too.

At least BA management has few illusions about the task in hand.

webTitle: Edinburgh festival review: Theatre: I Kissed Dash Riprock

fields.headline: A romantic confession
fields.standfirst:
I Kissed Dash Riprock
Assembly Rooms ***

Special report: the Edinburgh Festival 2000
fields.trailText:
I Kissed Dash Riprock
Assembly Rooms ***
fields.body:
One grrrrl's confession of her romance with a Clooneyesque film-star hunk: this sounds light, and it is. Cyndi Freeman's performance is of the women-in-Friends school: sassy, kooky, skinny, shiny-haired and slightly over the top.

For all that this is a likeable show, rescued by sharp writing. When Dash calls her, she almost sobs for joy that he calls her "pal"; when he invites her to visit his ranch in Montana she goes into imaginative overdrive ("my own personal beer commercial: Montana"). Even when the material veers too close to chick-lit staples, it does so knowingly. She has a 14-year-old Juliet (as in Romeo) part of her subconscious guiding her towards romance, but also a 90-year part telling her to get out and have fun. That voice would recommend this heartily.

Till August 28. Box office: 0131-226 2428.

webTitle: Oftel attacks BT over ADSL fees

fields.headline: Oftel attacks BT over ADSL fees
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: BT was attacked by Oftel yesterday over its £40 monthly charge for high-speed internet access, after a survey by the telecommunication watchdog found consumers wanted cheaper web services.
fields.body:
BT was attacked by Oftel yesterday over its £40 monthly charge for high-speed internet access, after a survey by the telecommunication watchdog found consumers wanted cheaper web services.

A survey by Oftel of 2,070 consumers found that those interested in asymmetric digital subscriber line technology - which delivers internet access at about 10 times the speed of today's modems - were only prepared to pay an average of £13 a month.

Oftel said that even with an additional monthly fee of £10 to have unmetered access that meant the total charge would still be short of the £40 being quoted by BT Openworld.

However, BT said yesterday that £13 would not cover its costs of offering ADSL services.

ADSL, which is just being rolled out, has had at least 100,000 possible users express interest. It also allows the delivery of video on demand and traditional television services via telephone lines.

A BT spokesman said the company had conducted its own marketing and research which suggested customers were prepared to pay its £40 charge. "We believe it's competitive and that people will pay this price."

At least 30 other companies are planning to offer ADSL services - a move which is expected to lead to price competition.

Oftel said not even higher-income groups or keen internet users were prepared to pay more than £13 on average. Only larger households were willing to pay more, but then only £20.

Oftel's survey was conducted by Mori in May and also found one in four homes is connected to the internet with the majority of users online for little more than one hour a week.

webTitle: Edinburgh festival review: Theatre: The King of Scotland

fields.headline: A self-proclaimed king
fields.standfirst:
The King of Scotland
Assembly Rooms ****

Special report: the Edinburgh Festival 2000
fields.trailText:
The King of Scotland
Assembly Rooms ****
fields.body:
In a gold-paper crown, straitjacket, bare legs and cheap socks, the self-proclaimed king of Scotland surveys his territory. His rise to power has been quick, hilarious, terrifying - brushing aside the establishment ("Burke's Peerage coming out of his arse") and his wife ("Face on her like soiled toilet-paper") on the way. It has also been delusional, part of a swift descent into madness, electrifyingly written in a new "free" adaptation of Gogol's Diary of a Madman for Theatre Babel.

And free it is. Our madman (Brian Pettifer) is a Glaswegian, unemployed for 18 years, now working at a Department of Social Inclusion call centre. At first, like some edgy stand-up, he tells us the details of his life in a torrent. It's funny, brutally so, then the key changes, and the descent into lunacy begins. He stalks his boss's It Girl daughter, boasting of his credentials for royalty ("My ancestors were dentists") and sexual prowess, his every erection "a roaring stonker".

He imagines that dogs write letters about everyday doggy concerns ("lamp-posts aren't what they used to be") but full of the dark meanderings of his mind too, where the girl is a filthy tramp begging for it, and he is king. On Gogol's tombstone, the epitaph reads "By my bitter word will I laugh". By these bitter, obscene, bleak words you will laugh, and then wonder how you could have done.

Till August 27. Box office: 0131-228 1404.

webTitle: House prices come off the boil, says Halifax

fields.headline: House prices come off the boil, says Halifax
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The annual rate of house price growth has halved over the past six months - from 16% to 8% - illustrating the extent of the property market's slowdown since the start of the year, according to new figures yesterday from the Halifax.
fields.body:
The annual rate of house price growth has halved over the past six months - from 16% to 8% - illustrating the extent of the property market's slowdown since the start of the year, according to new figures yesterday from the Halifax.

July saw a 0.3% increase in UK house prices, lifting the average price to £84,276. The small rise cancels out the 0.3% fall registered in June, and means the cost of an average home is almost unchanged on March, when it was £84,117. However, last month's rise compares with the 1.6% increase seen in July 1999.

The annual rate of house price inflation continued its downward trend, falling for the third month in a row. It now stands at 8% - the lowest figure since June 1999, when it was 6.6%. In January this year property price inflation was running at 16%.

Further evidence that the housing boom is over was provided by Inland Revenue figures showing that the number of house sales in England and Wales was 4% lower in the period April to June compared with the first three months of this year, said a Halifax spokesman. The figures come hard on the heels of data from rival lender Nationwide, which said the cost of an average home fell 0.2% in July.

The Halifax said this "softening" in the housing market was consistent with recent signs of reduced growth in consumer spending and retail sales, suggesting that household sector demand is less buoyant than a few months ago.

"The four mortgage rate rises between last September and February and the abolition of mortgage interest tax relief in April are the two key factors explaining the housing market slowdown," it added.

The Halifax joined the Nationwide in arguing that a repeat of the early 90's crash was unlikely, pointing out that the economy is "in good shape", housing affordability at a national level remains favourable and, despite the rate rises, mortgage payments still swallow up less than a quarter of a typical first-time buyer's gross pay.

"These factors should support a steady housing market over the remainder of the year," said the spokesman.

webTitle: Edinburgh festival review: Lady Salsa

fields.headline: In thrall to Cuban music
fields.standfirst:
Lady Salsa
Edinburgh's Garden Party **

Special report: the Edinburgh Festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Lady Salsa
Edinburgh's Garden Party **
fields.body:
With millions in thrall to Cuban music, it's time the history of the island, inextricably linked to the evolution of its music and dance, was explored. This was the idea that drove director Toby Gough to create Lady Salsa, an ambitious piece of musical theatre based on the life of 75-year-old Cuban actress Hilda Oates, who stars in the show.

Gough's first-night introduction was a litany of the problems the Cuban company, drawn from four dance and theatre groups from Havana and Santiago de Cuba, had to overcome to get here. Then came a flow of movement from 16 dancers symbolising the ancient gods of the African slaves. Sonora la Calle has to be the tightest rhythm section on the fringe, hardly pausing throughout a hectic dash from African percussive to rumba and mambo.

Yet, despite a stage fizzing with motion, the show faltered. The narrative verged on the banal, the story structure meandered and the script was sometimes simplistic to the point of patronising. The production needs tightening if it is to live up to its spectacular promise and do justice to its cast.

Till August 28. Box office: 0131-226 2151.

webTitle: Edinburgh festival review: Comedy: Dave Gorman

fields.headline: A rollercoaster of comedy
fields.standfirst:
Dave Gorman
Pleasance Above *****

Special report: the Edinburgh Festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Dave Gorman
Pleasance Above *****
fields.body:
Just like his previous shows, Reasons to Be Cheerful and Better World, Dave Gorman's latest vehicle is a brilliant example of what can happen when you take an idea and run with it. The idea is this: Gorman set out to find, meet and photograph himself meeting other Dave Gormans. A simple enough notion, maybe, but it inspired one of the funniest shows in years - an hour-long rollercoaster of comedy.

Gorman first goes to Scotland, where he meets the assistant manager of East Fife Football Club, Dave Gorman; then he goes right round the world. There's even a Dave Gorman in this audience. We share Gorman's excitement as he locates his first gay namesake, and his heartbreak as he is cruelly refused a meeting with Dave Gorman of Leamington Spa. By the end of the show, he is offering £300 to anyone who will change their name by deed poll, and a desperate, entire grand to the person who will christen their child Dave Gorman.

The tale is fascinating and Gorman's immaculate timing and deadpan delivery mean there is scarcely a second's break in the hilarity.

The idea is this: Gorman set out to find, meet and photograph himself meeting other Dave Gormans. webTitle: Edinburgh festival review: Theatre: Stiff-Undertaking Undertaking

fields.headline: You'll weep, but only with laughter
fields.standfirst:
Stiff-Undertaking Undertaking
Club Pleasance ****

Special report: the Edinburgh Festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Stiff-Undertaking Undertaking
Club Pleasance ****
fields.body:
Actor Forbes Murdston is no stranger to loss. He lost his family to a rare disease, he lost his theatre company at sea and now he has lost his wife. This is a tragical tale and you'll weep, but only with laughter.

Spymonkey's devised comedy is a Victorian melodrama that takes place in an inept undertakers' ("Good morning, we're mourning") where staff rivalries, tombstone one-upmanship, a fixation on organ donation and inappropriate behaviour ensure Mrs Murdston will never rest in one piece, let alone peace.

This is a dead funny, quick-witted show about mortality, full of the kind of clever word-play that ensures you get from "passed away" to "pissed off" very quickly, and some skilled physical comedy: there is a brilliant scene in which the corpse takes on a life of its own. There is a nifty little set, a coffin that provides some great entrances and exits, and the cast are superb, although - how should I put this? - they should resist the desire to corpse.

Spymonkey is a new company. On the evidence of this endearing, inventive show, they should have a very long life.

Till August 28. Box office: 0131-556 6550.

webTitle: Proms review: NYO / Norrington

fields.headline: Love is the drug
fields.standfirst:
National Youth Orchestra/ Norrington
Royal Albert Hall, London****
fields.trailText:
National Youth Orchestra/ Norrington
Royal Albert Hall, London ****
fields.body:
Is the tale of a drug addict's obsessive passion for a coquette a suitable subject for a celebration of the Queen Mother's 100th birthday? Some might say not - but that's the starting point of Berlioz's Symphonie Fantastique, with which the NYO and Roger Norrington chose to close their musical tribute to the orchestra's patron.

The pomp and pageantry of royalty was dealt with before the interval with Walton's Crown Imperial (written for the 1937 coronation), followed by Handel's Fireworks Music and Elgar's Cockaigne, their majesty emphasised by the NYO's colossal forces, with doubled and trebled woodwind parts, immense choirs of brass, eight harps and vast batteries of percussion. The sheer sumptuousness of it all is mightily impressive, as is the delicacy which Norrington teases out of such an enormous orchestra in passages like the Bourée from the Fireworks Music, where he gets the NYO woodwind to play with the transparency of a period band. Only in Cockaigne, which needs passion as well as grandeur, did the tension slip a bit, though Norrington tellingly emphasises the Straussian warmth of the orchestration, and the playing was glorious.

His rapport with the NYO was tangible throughout the evening, nowhere more so than in Berlioz's opium-drenched phantasmagoria. Norrington is well known for his period-instrument performances of the Fantastique, but even when using large-scale conventional forces, his interpretation is equally riveting, equally revelatory. The opening unfurls into a fever of genuine delirium, then assumes an unstable macho swagger once the druggy hero meets his beloved. The ballroom sequence is dazzling, an opalescent swirl of colour, helped infinitely by the NYO's eight harps (Berlioz wanted six - most conductors settle for two).

Norrington takes the March to the Scaffold much slower than most and the impression is of a heavy tumbrel, processing relentlessly to the guillotine. The finale is devastating, with the woodwind choirs screaming, which is obscene in the extreme. Norrington clearly enjoyed every second of it. So did the players, and when it was over the audience went wild, the ovation hugely deserved.

webTitle: Proms review: Jessye Norman

fields.headline: Diva's cycle of life
fields.standfirst:
Jessye Norman
Royal Albert Hall, London ****
fields.trailText:
Jessye Norman
Royal Albert Hall, London ****
fields.body:
Mistress of the grand gesture, cult diva Jessye Norman arrived for her Prom in her usual inimitable style, sweeping onto the platform in swathes of lime-green tulle to receive the cheers of a strangely less than packed house. Some, one suspects, might have felt a bit shortchanged, for this was not so much a recital as a London Sinfonietta concert in which Norman took part in two out of four items.

The focus inevitably fell on the UK premiere of woman.life.song, the song cycle which Norman commissioned from Judith Weir to specially written texts by Toni Morrison, Maya Angelou and Clarissa Pinkola Estes. It charts the passage of a woman's life from birth to contented old age, celebrates the continuity of female experience, and inhabits a world far removed from masculine visions of women's dependence on men, though the inherently feminist quality of the text is offset by a push on Weir's part towards the almost ritual expression of a universality of experience.

The act of singing is equated with vitality itself, as Norman turns from speech to song as the work's heroine gains her individuality, the process reversing itself at the close as the dissolution of death is quietly contemplated. The instrumental textures become more dense with experience, surrounding Norman with darkly sensual tendrils of sound as sexual maturity is reached, deepening still further for the haunting lullaby in which the heroine rocks her own mother into the final sleep of death. The influence of Stravinsky's Les Noces can be heard in the bell-like sonorities which bring the work to its close. Weir very much has the measure of Norman's voice, exploiting its velvety middle and lower registers (there's a very sexy descent to a low G at one point), keeping her for the most part out of the stratospheres where you can now, just occasionally, detect a beat in the sound. The whole has the timeless beauty of Weir's music at its absolute best.

Norman's other contribution to the proceedings is a performance of Schoenberg's Cabaret Songs, fruitily sexy, at times downright dirty, though occasionally sacrificing pitch to innuendo. As an encore, she gave us Strauss's Zueignung (Dedication), pivoting in a circle on the platform so that the reiterations of "Habe Dank" (Thank You) were grandiloquently addressed to all areas of the auditorium. Left to their own devices the Sinfonietta, conducted by David Robertson, played Stravinsky's Dumbarton Oaks with tremendous spike and panache, then were heard at their absolute best in Ravel's Introduction and Allegro, which was ravishingly done, its tremendous harp cadenzas exquisitely played by Helen Tunstall.

webTitle: Holiday time

fields.headline: Holiday time
fields.trailText: 8 August: I work without a contract but I am worried that if I get pushy and ask for holiday and sick pay I could find myself dismissed.
fields.body:
The problem

I have been working for the same employer for more than a year but I do not have a contract. Initially this did not bother me as I wanted part-time temporary work while I finished my degree.

I worked four days a week from August 1999 but now I am concerned about holiday and sick pay, and even my entitlement to back pay. I have not made a fuss about it so far because I am worried that, without a contract, I might be dismissed.

The solution

First of all, your not having a contract actually makes it harder for your employer to dismiss you not easier, since they are at fault for not giving you a contract within twelve weeks of employment. As you have now been with the company a year, it is harder for them to dismiss you without good reason since you could claim for unfair dismissal. In addition, one reason that they cannot dismiss you for is for asserting your statutory employment rights. In other words, your making a fuss and asking for a contract, holiday and sick pay, is in fact, simply an assertion of your basic rights and you cannot be sacked for asking. For this reason, asking for your rights might even protect you from being dismissed.

The bottom line is that you do have the right to a contract, to holiday pay and to sick pay and you should be getting them. I suggest that you contact your local ACAS public enquiry point (in the phone book) to establish exactly what you are entitled to (eg, holiday entitlement varies according to the number of days worked). Once you know what to ask for, you could compile a friendly letter to your line manager in which you politely point out what you ought to be getting and asking for these rights to be put into place immediately.

Whether or not you wish to claim back pay for holiday depends on a number of legal and psychological factors. ACAS will be able to advise on your legal rights, but, from a psychological point of view, it might not be worth pursuing this aspect. Only you can decide if it is worth risking goodwill for the sake of some back pay. Form the tone of your letter, you are already uncomfortable about making waves by asserting your rights, so, you might prefer to leave it at that.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

webTitle: EC gives e-commerce exchange the go-ahead

fields.headline: EC gives e-commerce exchange the go-ahead
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Money Unlimited

Net news
fields.trailText: The European commission yesterday gave its first approval for a business to business internet-based marketplace but warned it was not giving carte blanche to the creation of similar ventures.
fields.body:
The European commission yesterday gave its first approval for a business to business internet-based marketplace but warned it was not giving carte blanche to the creation of similar ventures.

It has approved the setting up of MyAircraft.com, a joint venture between the American aerospace groups United Technologies and Honeywell International. But commission officials said proposals for other online business to business marketplaces would be examined on a case by case basis.

Industry will welcome yesterday's decision, for it indicates that the commission is not opposed to such ventures in principle. Such marketplaces, where suppliers come together to provide goods and services for business customers, are expected to dominate e-commerce.

They are forecast to account for four-fifths of all e-commerce by 2005 - completely overshadowing general online retail activity.

Business to business exchanges aim to provide one-stop-shops for business customers, cut out the middleman and spread the cost and risks of venturing into the e-commerce arena.

Earlier EC officials had indicated that they were concerned that business to busi ness marketplaces could lead to the creation of anti-competitive cartels.

Their decision on MyAircraft.com was expected to set a global standard for regulators. But Amelia Torres, a commission spokeswoman, said: "The commission found no competition problems with this market, but we should not assume that will be the case with all the others."

She said that Covisint, a business to business exchange between car makers General Motors, Ford and DaimlerChrysler, would probably not qualify for review by the commission, although it is being examined by the United States federal trade commission and the German cartel office.

"If these projects don't take the form of full-function joint ventures jointly controlled by the parent companies, there may be no obligation for us to look at them," Ms Torres said.

The commission said MyAircraft.com was seen by third parties as a tool to make operations within the aerospace sector quicker, more efficient and less costly.

It also took into account the relatively high number of similar ventures already operating or planned for the sector.

"MyAircraft.com will in all likelihood face strong competition from other similar websites," the commission said in a formal statement.

Boeing, BAe Systems, Lock heed Martin, and Raytheon announced a similar venture last month.

United Technologies is one of the world's leading aircraft engine makers. Its operations include Sikorsky helicopters. Honeywell International is an aerospace equipment maker and hi-tech materials group.

 Royal Ahold announced that Dixons Group and Germany's Edeka are to join its online business to business venture, WorldWide Retail Exchange. Ahold noted that this brings the number of retailers belonging to the online procurement site to a total of 26 - with aggregrate annual sales of around 500bn euros.

webTitle: Jongleurs founders sell stake to Regent for £7m

fields.headline: Jongleurs founders sell stake to Regent for £7m
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The husband and wife team who together founded Jongleurs comedy clubs have sold their 51% stake to Regent Inns in a deal that could be worth as much as £8.5m.
fields.body:
The husband and wife team who together founded Jongleurs comedy clubs have sold their 51% stake to Regent Inns in a deal that could be worth as much as £8.5m.

Regent aims to open up to 15 new clubs in Britain in the next two years. "We already have one or two sites that we are looking at," said Stephen Haupt, Regent's chief executive.

Despite past tensions between the controlling family and Regent Inns over price, the pub chain acquired full ownership of the eight Jongleurs comedy clubs and Bar Risa businesses for £7m. Further performance related payments could take the final figure to £8.5m.

At least £6m will be issued as convertible unsecured loan stock in Regent, which will be convertible into Regent ordinary shares at 153p per share. A further £1m will be paid in unsecured loan notes and another £1.5m could be paid in debt if profit targets are met in the two years to June 2002. Regent Inns held 49% of the company.

Jongleurs hit the headlines with a combination of live comedy, fast food and dancing, initially provided by John Davy and his wife Maria Kempinska and has launched the careers of Ben Elton, Harry Enfield, Jack Dee and Ruby Wax.

The transactions include an exclusive licence to use the Jongleurs name for existing and future clubs in the UK.

Since Regent's first involvement with Jongleurs in 1997 the number of clubs has increased from the two original sites in Battersea, opened in 1983, and Camden to eight nationwide. There are four comedy clubs in London and others in Nottingham, Leicester, Southampton and Oxford.

Mr Davy and Ms Kempinska, a former drama teacher, will still book and monitor the quality of all comedy acts and will initially provide box office and marketing support services through the newly formed company, Jongleurs Comedy Limited.

They will also own the intellectual property rights to the Jongleurs brand, including broadcast rights and the Jongleurs comedy portal. Regent owns 5% of this company which will take advantage of new internet opportunities.

Last year the Jongleurs units showed operating profit of £1.2m, profit before tax of £700,000 and net assets of £500,000. Yesterday Regent Inns' share price closed at £1.28, down 1.5p.

webTitle: Washington threatens BA-KLM merger

fields.headline: Washington threatens BA-KLM merger
fields.trailText: British Airways' chief executive, Rod Eddington, yesterday admitted that an increasingly aggressive stance by US regulators could scupper his planned deal with KLM to create the world's third-largest airline.
fields.byline: Terry Macalister and Jane Martinson in New York
fields.body:
British Airways' chief executive, Rod Eddington, yesterday admitted that an increasingly aggressive stance by US regulators could scupper his planned deal with KLM to create the world's third-largest airline.

While confirming that BA had extended the exclusivity period for its discussions with the Dutch carrier, Mr Eddington acknowledged that European and American bureaucrats were playing an increasingly pivotal role.

BA's new boss said in an interview with the Guardian: "I believe a deal with KLM is do-able but its a very complex transaction. It's a matter for governments and politicians as well."

His comments came as Washington trade negotiators increased pressure on him by insisting any KLM merger would scupper other BA plans to expand in the US.

One source said: "They are basically living in fantasy land if they think they can get this through American regulators."

US politicians are convinced BA wants KLM to take advantage of the Dutch carrier's agreement with North West Airlines of the US, which has protection from anti-trust laws.

US politicians are seen by some to be using the carrier's interest in America as a lever to help push the UK government to open Heathrow to US carriers.

BA yesterday posted a £50m second quarter loss, against a £200m profit for the same period last time. But Mr Eddington said he was "cautiously optimistic". Underlying profitability had shown its first improvement since the middle of 1997 although higher fuel prices and losses on asset sales turned last year's profit into a sizeable deficit.

The City marked down BA shares 3p to 338p, disappointed that passenger yields and some revenue figures were not better. There was also gloom that the timetable was slipping on merger talks with KLM. Andrew Light, transport analyst with Salomon Smith Barney, said: "The real obstacle to a BA/KLM merger is the attitude of US regulators. If the airlines cannot find common ground quickly it does not augur well for the future."

Another sticking point is the valuation of KLM. While on the basis of market value KLM should represent only 16% of the combined group, its chief executive wants at least 25%.

fields.headline: Arbitrator ends 10-year Andersen family feud
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Andersen Consulting yesterday finally broke away from the Arthur Andersen accountancy firm after a crucial ruling by an arbitrator ended a 10-year feud between the two factions.
fields.body:
Andersen Consulting yesterday finally broke away from the Arthur Andersen accountancy firm after a crucial ruling by an arbitrator ended a 10-year feud between the two factions.

Both sides were claiming victory after two and half years of arbitration by the International Chamber of Commerce. However, Jim Wadia, chief executive of Arthur Andersen, announced his retirement after the decision.

The arbitrator, Guillermo Gamba, ruled that Andersen Consulting would have to change its name but it did not need to hand over a $14.5bn (£10bn) "divorce settlement" - which might have crippled the consultancy business - claimed by Arthur Andersen's partners.

The arbitrator concluded that the consultancy should be allowed to split off even though Arthur Andersen had kept to its contractual obligations.

Both groups until yesterday fell under the umbrella of Andersen Worldwide.

The Andersen Consulting partners will have to pay out $850m in fees to Arthur Andersen which were withheld during the three years of arbitration.

"This is total win for Andersen Consulting. We won. It's over," said Joe Forehand, global managing partner of the consultancy firm.

However, Mr Wadia said: "We are pleased that the arbitration has upheld our position."

The bitter rows between the two organisation began in the early 1990s when Arthur Andersen, traditionally a tax and audit firm, started to conduct more consultancy work, which frustrated Andersen Consulting.

The separation between consultancy and accountancy firms is expected to become an increasing trend because of calls by US regulators for more demarcation between the two.

Andersen Consulting tried to negotiate its departure from Arthur Andersen three years ago but attempts to reach a settlement failed and drove the two into costly and lengthy arbitration.

The consulting partners tried to buy their way out of the group but their offers were rejected.

Andersen Consulting, which has spent millions of pounds in advertising, described the ruling that it could no longer use the name as "a small price to pay". It remains to be seen whether Arthur Andersen decides to the use the name for its consultancy business.

webTitle: Edinburgh festival review: Comedy: Simon Munnery

fields.headline: Munnery's entrance
fields.standfirst:
Simon Munnery
Meadows Theatre Big Top **

Special report: the Edinburgh Festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Simon Munnery
Meadows Theatre Big Top **
fields.body:
Munnery's entrance is one of the most stunning things on the fringe. In a hail of dry ice and double-entendres, the bespectacled maniac rides in on top of a silver ice-cream van that doubles as a time machine. An enormous computerised screen declares Munnery's self-styled superiority. We, the humble masses, are "scum", our church McDonald's. Sadly, thereafter things fall flat.

On a good night Munnery can be one of the funniest, most thought-provoking experiences in comedy, but on a bad one he is infuriating. You'd think that after four years this inconsistency would have been ironed out, but no - things have hardly got going before the computer that controls his video screen (an integral part of the show) crashes. Catastrophe can trigger Munnery's finest rapid-fire wit; this time he fails to seize the opportunity, even when Abba blares in from the next tent. Instead, we feel sympathy as the "superior" being is all but drowned out by Dancing Queen.

When you can hear them, Munnery's sniping one-liners are wonderful. However, much of the material seems familiar, and some are just not very funny. The technical problems will presumably be overcome, but this is a weak show.

Till August 27. Box office: 0131-667 0202.

webTitle: Market forces: Woolwich turns rumour mill

fields.headline: Woolwich turns rumour mill
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Woolwich continued to keep dealers busy yesterday in another wise subdued market. The former building society's shares rose 9.5p to 268p - still well below the value at which they floated three years ago - as a sizeable 13.2m shares changed hands.
fields.body:
Woolwich continued to keep dealers busy yesterday in another wise subdued market. The former building society's shares rose 9.5p to 268p - still well below the value at which they floated three years ago - as a sizeable 13.2m shares changed hands.

The buying is taking the shares off their recent lows and the rumour mill is grinding hard. Yesterday's favourite tip was that Axa, the French insurance company, wanted more than just a cooperative arrangement with Woolwich to help market the bank's highly regarded current account-cum-mortgage product called Open Plan.

Talk about a full offer by Axa for the bank was doing the rounds but failed to be pinned down as the gossip mongers tried to work out how such a deal could be structured and whether the French had the cash.

On the face of it, yesterday was another summer Monday in the markets: the FTSE 100 index closed marginally higher, up 24.3 points at 6,387.8, on meagre volume of 1bn shares thanks to strength in a couple of heavyweight sectors - banks and oils.

However, for the market's shrewder players something more interesting was going on. On one level the performances of BP Amoco (up 10p to 607p) and Shell (5p higher at 554p) were not surprising. After all, Brent crude futures rocketed in the US on Friday night and European oil stocks were simply playing catch-up.

But there were also positive performances from drug groups Glaxo Wellcome (10p better at £19.68), SmithKline Beecham (15p stronger at 892p) and brewer Scottish & Newcastle (up 17.5p to 472), all of which seemed to suggest some defensive buying.

Sure enough, one of London's biggest broking houses was expressing its preference for cash as an asset class and adopting a more cautious tone in its sector strategy with a bias toward defensive sectors.

In its latest equity market analysis, Deutsche Bank was telling its clients that the risks for investors are now on the downside. "This month we have adopted a more cautious tone _ with a bias toward pharmaceuticals, utilities and the defensive consumer sectors," it said.

Despite Deutsche's warning, some growth stocks made progress. Cable group Telewest Communications closed 10p better at 170p, enlivened by bid speculation and some bargain hunting. Early in the session the shares climbed 15% before one mooted bidder, Callahan Associates, flatly denied reports that it had made an offer. A hostile bid for the company is improbable anyway given the fact that UPC and Microsoft together own 48.7% of the company.

Elsewhere, optical chip specialist Bookham Technology shot up 496p to £44.65 ahead of second-quarter figures on Wednesday. But dealers were not getting carried away with the move - only 549,844 shares changed hands.

Another results-related mover was long-distance telecoms group Colt Telecom, which advanced 116p to £21.56. Colt reports today and most pundits are confident that it will report revenues toward the top end of expectations.

On the downside, Nycomed Amersham shed 52p to 646p, as it confirmed one of the market's worst kept secrets: the planned flotation of its jointly owned life sciences business, Amersham Pharmacia Biotech.

Among the smaller FTSE 250 stocks, engineer McKechnie rose 24p to 395p as it finally agreed a 400p a share management buy-out, while property group Minerva rose 7p to 244.5p, boosted by planning permission for a £700m shopping mall.

Internet action group QXL.com was under pressure again (down 3p at 65p) this time from news that the blind trust of chairman Jonathan Bulkeley has disposed of 325,000 shares, supposedly to cover its administrative fees.

Software group Merant, down 41.5p to 88.5p, was one of the worst performing smaller company shares as its first-quarter results came in sharply below expectations.

Tagger is on track

Dmatek, the Israeli maker of electronic tagging equipment, reports its first set of figures since graduating from AIM today and, according to the word in the market, investors will not be disappointed.

Half-time figures are said to have met management's expectations and the company is reckoned to be close to appointing a City broker.

Best know for the tagging low-risk criminals, Dmatek is trying to diversify its customer base by moving into other fields such as the lucrative US healthcare market. A system for monitoring Alzheimer patients using its core tagging technology is being tested by health authorities in the US and is said to be going well.

Dmatek, which made a net profit after tax of $1.76m in 1999, is high risk, high reward investment. Its shares closed 17.5p higher at 247p yesterday but are still some way from the 334.5p reached in March.

webTitle: Review: Ballets of Fokine

fields.headline: Sensuality in art deco
fields.standfirst:
Ballets of Fokine
Royal Opera House, London ***
fields.trailText:
Ballets of Fokine
Royal Opera House, London ***
fields.body:
Mikhail Fokine was the great reformer of the Russian ballet in the early 20th century and the first of Serge Diaghilev's choreographers. He occupies a vitally important role in the history of the Kirov, who perform six of his ballets in two programmes at the Royal Opera House. Fokine's Petrushka, the tragic tale of a puppet's unrequited love, is set in a bustling fairground in the decadent days of pre-communist St Petersburg. The gaudy art deco sets and costumes designed by the Russian artist Alexandre Benois dazzled audiences at its Parisian premiere in 1911, and they are equally fantastic in this new production - the stage looks almost like an animated art exhibition.

What is interesting about this ballet is the synthesis of mime, Russian folk dance and classical ballet that creates a theatrical spectacle rather than a display of dance steps. This emphasis on dramatic content was radical for its time, as were the ballet's depictions of ordinary Russian people. The other puppets - a pert ballerina and her object of desire, the rich but stupid Moor - outrage the jealous, impotent Petrushka, who is killed when he aggravates them both. The three solo parts are brilliantly danced, although Andrian Fadeyev as Petrushka performs the puppet's characteristic inverted positions and floppy leaps with too much cool technical expertise and not enough soul.

Schéhérazade (1910), based on one of the tales from The Arabian Nights, was a risqué ballet for its time, depicting as it does an orgy that takes place within the harem of Sultan Shakhriar. This sensual ballet, lavishly designed by Léon Bakst, is full of billowing drapes, swaying lanterns and women wearing transparent trousers - the very image of the white man's fantasy of the orient, full of exotica, of carnal delights and savage behaviour. While the sultan's back is turned the women of the harem let in the male slaves and all hell breaks loose. The star is the Golden slave danced by the impressive Faroukh Ruzimatov, whose dramatic presence and passionate interpretation give the sultan's favourite wife - danced by Altynai Asylmuratova - every reason to be unfaithful. These two outshone the rest of the cast, staying in their dramatic roles even throughout the curtain call.

webTitle: Coach tragedy should not stop school trips

fields.headline: Coach tragedy should not stop school trips
fields.standfirst: The death of a British schoolboy after a coach crash in France should not mean the end of extra-curricular visits abroad, says education correspondent Rebecca Smithers
fields.trailText: The death of a British schoolboy after a coach crash in France should not mean the end of extra-curricular visits abroad, says education correspondent Rebecca Smithers
fields.body:
For the group of young teenagers travelling to France, it was a trip they had been looking forward to for almost a year. The youngsters could finally put school behind them at the start of the summer holidays, excited at the prospect of an action-packed adventure holiday in the Dordogne where they would enjoy canoeing, rock climbing, white-water rafting, assault courses and horse-riding.

But today's tragic news that a British teenager had died and 17 passengers were injured, up to seven of them seriously, after their coach overturned on the way to the holiday, inevitably raised fresh anxieties about the risks and dangers of school trips.

Two parties of children aged between 13 and 17, from Chadwell Heath Foundation school, Romford, Essex and the 41st Edinburgh Boys Brigade were travelling with the Hertfordshire-based school travel specialists PGL Travel. The company, which was set up 27 years ago, has a sound reputation as a specialist travel company and boasts an exemplary safety record.

Guidance is issued by the department for education and employment for local education authorities placing a strict duty on their schools to look after the children in their care. That applies whether a school organises a trip itself, or whether - as in this case - it 'sub-contracts' it to an outside organisation.

Suitable transport is one of the first considerations, for travel in the UK as well as overseas. British coaches are subject to strict safety regulations and the rules governing the transportation of children are even more stringent.

All coaches which carry schoolchildren must now be fitted with seatbelts, although many already had them installed before their usage became compulsory.

There are also firm rules about the hours drivers can do. With drivers needing, by law, to rest from time to time, coaches on long journeys will have two. As a back-up, drivers' hours are closely monitored by the tachograph - once dubbed by truckers as the "spy in the cab" - which records the numbers of hours that drivers complete and the speed at which they drive.

But the worries about the threats of litigation from parents and the damage caused by bad publicity are understandably making head teachers less keen than they used to be about organising the kind of trips that are designed to build on what a child learns in the classroom.

By coincidence, last week, a motion was discussed at the annual conference of the Professional Association of Teachers, highlighting delegates' concerns about the mass of red tape and bureaucracy involved in school trips.

While acknowledging the need for many of the steps on health and safety grounds, the motion said: 'Conference believes that the level of regulation and bureaucracy involved in taking pupils out of school is so great that it is no longer considered 'worth the effort'".

Written consent, for example, is required by parents as well as full details of any allergies that a child might have, medication that they might need and permission for the teacher to act as guardian, while transport considerations and the need to check out premises and sites all add to the teachers' workload.

The PAT rightly believes that school trips are important and should continue. The safety and welfare of children has always been of paramount importance and should continue to be so. The French tragedy is regrettable, but should not deter parents from sending children on valuable extra-curricular trips of this kind which can do so much to broaden their horizons.

webTitle: Robert Newman's comedy manifesto

fields.headline: Performers of the world unite
fields.standfirst:
Novelist and performer of 'Chomsky-lite stand-up' Robert Newman takes current comedy to task
Special report: the Edinburgh Festival 2000
fields.trailText: Novelist and performer of 'Chomsky-lite stand-up' Robert Newman takes current comedy to task
fields.body:
You tend not to associate the word "politics" with the phrase "Edinburgh fringe comedy festival", unless you're talking about the Scottish Assembly. So why am I taking my own brand of Chomsky-lite stand-up to the Edinburgh fringe this month? Political comedy is dead. The ideological battles are over. History has ended. There is no alternative. There is no conflict between the interests of workers and bosses - in fact, there aren't even workers and bosses any more.

If there's one thing comedy loves more than rigidities, authoritarian pronouncements, lies, conformity, ideologues and the views of rich people in general, it is this: a world in which everything has been sorted out lovely and we're all working together like a team. (Two fellers pouring cement together, one fat, one thin. A sunny day. Pocketing his fob-watch, the foreman sets off for lunch, happy in the knowledge that when he comes back it'll all be finished.)

Newsnight editor Peter Horrocks embraced this mood of togetherness when he told his staff in 1997: "Our job should not be to quarrel with the purpose of policy, but to question its implementation." Everything has turned out nice - even if there are still some people who don't realise that the class war is over and believe there is a conflict of interest between bosses and workers. People like the International Herald Tribune, say, whose recent jubilant front-page announced: Rise In Joblessness Delights US Markets. And BusinessWeek with its headline: Thanks, Goodbye - Amid Record Profits Companies Continue To Lay Off Employees. (Two men whistling, and the gentle rumble of an approaching steamroller.)

Everywhere people are angry, betrayed, working longer hours just to pay their bills, and hoping they never get ill or old or have kids who want to go to university. Nowadays political stand-up gets the kind of response in places like Barnstaple, Gravesend and Maidstone that five years ago you used only to get in Liverpool, Glasgow, Manchester or Sheffield. In as unlikely a place as the Hampshire market town of Petersfield, for example, I noticed people were particularly angry. I'd only been on stage 10 minutes before many of them were standing up, grabbing their coats and rushing out in a seething revolutionary mass. An insurgent mob demanding money from the theatre-owners themselves!

The past 20 years have seen a rollback of a century's social progress and democracy. This presents politically involved musicians, writers, artists, film-makers and performers with a challenge: how to describe the Hydra of corporate-led globalisation. Or, to put this question strictly in terms of comedy: when the central fact of life is an unprecedented upward transfer of power and wealth from people to unaccountable private tyrannies, where da gags gonna come from?

Well, firstly you can forget about conventional satire. Lampooning politicians is inherently reactionary. By attacking individual politicians, satire implies that were it not for these few "rotten apples" - bunglers or swindlers - then the system of corporate-led globalisation itself would be just fine and dandy. John Pilger has described conventional satire as a handy safety-valve.

Satire has no fire in its belly and believes in nothing. Which is why the producer of a famous TV satire show told me that there is no such thing as poverty in Britain, nor are there "systems" or "class interests". (He then went on to moan how everyone thinks he is right-wing, but really he isn't anything.)

Satire always ends up following the news agenda and replicating its institutional biases - for example, the habit of ignoring issues to talk about power-play, intrigues and the whole wretched soap opera of Westminster gossip. (Quite apart from the fact that separate studies show that 40% of all "news" items are laundered PR messages that come from "issues management" firms like Burson Marsteller and Hill & Knowlton. )

I'm not saying that having a pop at individual politicians or CEOs is always pointless. Just that there's satire and satire. A great political comedian like Roberto Benigni never gives Fiat chariman Gianni Agnelli and media mogul Silvio Berlusconi the legitimacy those feudal lords claim for themselves. When Benigni does Agnelli's walk or Berlusconi's slow head-turn, their arch-grandiosity seems like a bubble they can go around in just so long as they never meet the real world. He gets laughs off them precisely because he shows them to be mere, witless, products of a rigged system. In Italy they call this system appartenenza; in Britain it's called the "public-private partnership". In both countries it means the same: a socialist nanny state lavishing corporate welfare on the rich and "tough love" capitalist market discipline on the poor.

Same with Michael Moore. When the people's champ gives us the dope on corporate bosses and sweatshop kings, he never presents their greed as some kind of deplorable personal trait. Moore never suggests they should be replaced by some other CEO who is less greedy. A nice CEO! A gentle robber baron! To a union-man like Moore they are part of a process of exploitation (and part of that same system that BBC "satire" producers don't believe in).

The Zapatistas define humanity as "the struggle against de-humanisation, the struggle to walk upright in a world that keeps pushing us down". This could be a description of Chaplin's Modern Times, right down to that see-saw floor of his rickety shack. Or Laurel and Hardy, or Steptoe, or Richard Pryor. The modern satirical idea, however, is somewhat different. Instead of misfits trying to conform, we have conformists trying to look rebellious.

PJ O'Rourke, Jeremy Clarkson, David Aaronovich, Richard Littlejohn, Rush Limbaugh - all these self-styled "iconoclasts" are, in fact, high-priests of dominant and fashionable orthodoxy. These brave and rugged frontiersmen want to impress us with their subversive views, but when do we ever hear anything else anyway? All we ever get is the corporate-friendly view. Where are the acres of news space about grassroots alternatives to the free market? Where are the black feminists' syndicated columns? Jeremy Clarkson hurls manful defiance at the new green tyranny of endless eco-shows like, er, Top Gear, The Car's the Star, Grand Prix Highlights and The Farnborough Air Show. Listen, bubblecut: BP is in the_ govern_ment!

Apart from TB, one characteristic that this neo-liberalism shares with other golden ages of political comedy, like the late 19th century, is that the gags just write themselves. At last week's demonstration against tube privatisation, Bob Crowe of the RMT described how a gas company is running the fire station, Virgin is supplying gas, Western Water is bidding for the tube, and non- emer gency ambulances are in the hands of a mini-cab firm. Not only has Dickens's Circumlocution Office been privatised but Podsnappery is flourishing too. In Dickens's description of Podsnap in Our Mutual Friend you can almost see Tony Blair or Clare Short when someone confronts them with one of those words that have been taken out of the dictionary, like "class" or "imperialism":

Mr Podsnap settled that whatever he put behind him he put out of existence. There was a dignified conclusiveness - not to say a grand convenience - in this way of getting rid of undesirables_ Mr Podsnap had even acquired a peculiar flourish to his right arm in often clearing the world of its most difficult problems, by sweeping them behind him (and consequently sheer away).

All year BBC economics correspondents and New Labourites have been saying that there is "almost zero unemployment in the US". A quick phone call to the Census Bureau or the American Bureau Of Labor Statistics might give them figures between 12m and 15m. Not including the 2m banged up. But that's not the point. In today's elitist cant, if the facts don't fit, they have to be suppressed for the ideology to survive.

And this brings us to one of the major obstacles to doing a political comedy show: such is the state of British "news media", there is a real information problem. If, for example, you happen to have a hilarious yet rousingly defiant routine on the recent Bolivian water riots, you first have to:

a) convince people that they've happened; and

b) tell them what happened.

And in doing this you run the risk of clogging up your act, over-loading it with stodgy chunks of background data. But the flipside of this is that there is sometimes an agreeable expectation when audiences can't quite see where the next gag's gonna come from - a tension I have been known to let build up for an hour.

Ironically, one of the reasons the public don't have the facts is what Jeremy Hardy describes as the "tyranny of humour". Every news and current affairs show has its gonky comedy bit. I like to think that my stand-up shows are one of the few places people can escape this incessant humour, the wall-to-wall comedy of our chuckle-culture.

Even as audiences queue up, an expectant grin on their vacant maws, I like to watch them through a crack in the dressing room door and think: I'll wipe that smile off your face.

So why am I taking my own brand of Chomsky-lite stand-up to the Edinburgh fringe this month? Political comedy is dead. The ideological battles are over. History has ended. There is no alternative. There is no conflict between the interests of workers and bosses - in fact, there aren't even workers and bosses any more. If there's one thing comedy loves more than rigidities, authoritarian pronouncements, lies, conformity, ideologues and the views of rich people in general, it is this: a world in which everything has been sorted out lovely and we're all working together like a team. (Two fellers pouring cement together, one fat, one thin. A sunny day. Pocketing his fob-watch, the foreman sets off for lunch, happy in the knowledge that when he comes back it'll all be finished.) Everything has turned out nice - even if there are still some people who don't realise that the class war is over and believe there is a conflict of interest between bosses and workers. People like the International Herald Tribune, say, whose recent jubilant front-page announced: Rise In Joblessness Delights US Markets. And BusinessWeek with its headline: Thanks, Goodbye - Amid Record Profits Companies Continue To Lay Off Employees. (Two men whistling, and the gentle rumble of an approaching steamroller.) webTitle: Owen gives Windsor Park another memory to savour

fields.headline: Owen gives Windsor Park another memory to savour
fields.standfirst: Liverpool drew 2-2 with Benfica but failed to live up to the spirit of Eusebio, writes  John Mullin
fields.trailText:
Liverpool drew 2-2 with Benfica in the annual Belfast Challenge Tournament but failed to live up to the spirit of Eusebio, writes John Mullin.

Liverpool 2 - 2 Benfica
fields.body:
Eusebio had been in Belfast before, and they talk about it even now. September 13 1967, and only the Black Panther's late goal stopped tiny Glentoran from dumping Benfica out of the European Cup competition in which they were to lose to the Ulsterman George Best and Manchester United in the final.

The Portuguese striker was also a drinking buddy in those days of Willie Henderson, the Rangers right-winger, an unlikely pairing that was all the more inexplicable because it was wee Willie who called the shots - so much so that he once had Eusebio don a chauffeur's cap to ferry him from pub to bookie.

That was a time when the Glasgow club's protestant heritage was rather overwhelming, to put it euphemistically. So Eusebio should have known the score, here of all places. He had played it perfectly, smiling as he lumbered to the centre circle, hand in hand with two delighted mascots. The crowd of 11,000 gave him a rousing ovation, as he meandered back to the sidelines, and he was genuinely moved.

Eusebio applauded all four stands and then, before the overwhelmingly loyalist crowd, he instinctively crossed himself. Time momentarily stopped. Perhaps, after all, Northern Ireland really is changing. In times gone by such a simple gesture would have sparked a near riot. But no one murmured a word of discontent and the afternoon's entertainment was nicely set up.

The pity was that Liverpool, clashing with Benfica in the decider of the annual Belfast Challenge Tournament, sometimes failed to reflect that mood. Several of their players engaged in pathetic, petulant skirmishes, with Vladimir Smicer a particular offender.

Michael Owen was nasty, too. Fouled in his own half, he immediately reacted with a cowardly follow-through on his hacker Carlos Marchena. This may be sanctimonious but it seemed to typify the type of arrogance fuelled by wage packets too fat and adulation too overweening.

Still, after two first-half misses, Owen did score a cracker, taking off to meet Markus Babbel's wayward right-wing cross. He was parallel to the ground and several feet in the air as he volleyed past Robert Enke from 20 yards.

Cruise control
That put Liverpool 2-0 up just after half-time and, without looking impressive, they were cruising. Benfica, with their new signing Pierre van Hooijdonk continually dropping his head in that infuriating manner which signals disappointment that his team-mates fail to meet his own high standards, were looking pretty poor.

They had gone behind to a Titi Camara diving header on 10 minutes, picked out by Smicer - who was replaced in the second half by Nicky Barmby - after a corner that never was, and made no inroads in a midfield in which Gary McAllister was the best player by a considerable margin. He played some lovely little backspin dinks, fine one-twos and through-balls and generally ran the show.

But with Dieter Hamann anonymous and Jamie Carragher, holding in Steven Gerrard's absence, out of his depth, Liverpool were over-reliant on a 35-year-old Scot. His withdrawal was always going to scupper the side. So it was to prove when Gérard Houllier pulled him off after 65 minutes, exacerbating the imbalance by putting on a striker, Erik Meijer.

Benfica began to dominate, with Karel Poborsky particularly impressive. His career with Manchester United guaranteed him Liverpool boos every time he touched the ball but his two-goal performance won him grudging applause when he was brought off just before the end.

His first was a wonderful scissor-kick as he lingered unmarked at the back post and his second again exposed defensive frailties. Three players backed off him as he ran from his own half to finish beyond Sander Westerveld, with Carragher the main culprit.

Liverpool held out for a draw and, having thumped Glentoran 4-0 in the first game, pipped Benfica to the silverware. It may be their only trophy come the end of the season.

They were, as usual, hamstrung with injuries. Robbie Fowler is out for six weeks after damaging an ankle against Glentoran and Gerrard, Emile Heskey and Jamie Redknapp were all missing. But they need to improve considerably and will be grateful that their first Premiership fixture sees the relegation favourites Bradford City visit Anfield on Saturday week.

Exposed
Houllier, who refused to discuss whether Middlesbrough's Christian Ziege is on his way, said: "It was a disappointing result because we were in command of the game. We let it slip. This is the type of match we need to learn from to help us prepare for the league ahead. We exposed ourselves on too many occasions, and there is no way that we can afford to let two-goal leads slip."

The other Saturday game in the four-team tournament saw the Irish league champions Linfield, who had lost to Benfica 3-2 earlier in the week, defeat the IFA cup winners Glentoran 2-0. The match doubled up as the Charity Shield decider and was of more immediate interest to most of those at Windsor Park.

But they were pleased to see leading teams visiting Northern Ireland, a rare enough occasion these days with the tough qualification demands for Europe. Memories become all the more important, such as the time Glentoran's player-coach John Colrain's ninth-minute spot-kick pushed 45,000 Glentoran fans into dreamland and almost dumped Benfica out of Europe.

Benfica (4-4-2): Enke; Calado, Madeira, Marchena, Escalona (Nunes, h-t); Poborsky (Miguel, 90min), Meira (Chano, 44), Maniche, Rojas; Sabry, Van Hooijdonk (Tomas, 70).

Liverpool (4-4-2): Westerveld; Babbel (Song, 62), Henchoz, Hyypia, Traore; Smicer (Barmby, 49), Hamann, Carragher, McAllister (Meijer, 65); Owen, Camara (Berger, 77).

webTitle: Yorkshire rattle the Sabres

fields.headline: Yorkshire rattle the Sabres
fields.standfirst:
Yorkshire Phoenix 249-3
Somerset Sabres 217
Yorkshire won by 32 runs
fields.trailText:
Yorkshire Phoenix 249-3
Somerset Sabres 217
Yorkshire won by 32 runs.
fields.body:
Paul Jarvis has been playing Sunday League cricket for 20 summers, and his best performance remains six for 27 at Taunton in 1989, when he was playing for Yorkshire against Somerset. But he must have suspected from the start that this was not going to be his day.

An early appeal for a leg-side catch behind was turned down by Nigel Cowley, the former Hampshire off-spinner adding to Jarvis's frustrations by awarding a wide. Shortly afterwards a beamer cost him a no-ball. And things were to get a good deal worse for the 35-year-old former England seamer, who was thumped for 19 in his last over by Anthony McGrath to leave him with embarrassing figures of one for 67.

Jamie Cox, Somerset's Australian captain, put an arm around Jarvis's shoulders as the home team returned to the pavilion, as if to apologise for asking him to bowl

The Sabres did not bowl or field like a team who could have gone top of the First Division with a win. There were a couple of dropped catches, numerous misfields and Graham Rose even took an ironic bow when he managed to collect a ball cleanly in the outfield.

Yorkshire, needing a win to ease their relegation fears, capitalised eagerly, with the young openers Victor Craven and Simon Widdup laying the platform for McGrath, Gavin Hamilton and Darren Lehmann to post a large total.

With David Byas out through injury, Lehmann was also making history as the first overseas player to captain Yorkshire - which could be a sign of things to come - and marked the occasion with 38 from 47 balls.

An unbroken fourth-wicket partnership of 124 in 18 overs between McGrath and Hamilton though really rattled the Sabres. McGrath's late assault on Jarvis including a straight six left him with a competition-best 85 from 77 balls.

Somerset's reply was frustrating to watch. All the top order started well only to self-destruct. Mark Lathwell chopped Matthew Hoggard on to his stumps after five crisp boundaries and Rob Turner unwisely tried reverse-sweeping Ian Fisher to backward point just short of a half-century.

Ian Blackwell, who had snatched victory for Somerset at Scarborough in the reverse match, hit 23 before holing out to deep midwicket, and the Sabres' last realistic chance disappeared when Peter Bowler fell for Gary Fellows's slower ball. Jarvis's day was complete when Matthew Hoggard yorked him for two.

webTitle: Trinity meets unbelievers in regeneration game flop

fields.headline: Trinity meets unbelievers in regeneration game flop
fields.standfirst: Punters remain unswayed by Caribbean crusade
fields.trailText: Vivek Chaudhary watches the punters remain unswayed by Channel 4's continuing Caribbean crusade.
fields.body:
There was a time when West Indians would come to watch their team in large numbers, creating a unique atmosphere as horns, drums and whistles greeted each boundary or wicket.

Sadly, gone are the legions of West Indian fans and the atmosphere now has to be artificially created.

After the players trudged off for lunch on Saturday, it was left to Trinity, a Jamaican reggae star performing on a stage overlooking the pitch, to try and remind us of what we had been missing.

As a heavy bassline echoed around the Old Trafford boundary, Trinity jigged from one side of the stage to another, trying to energise the crowd with his hip swinging and Jamaican lyrics that appeared to bemuse most of those present.

"Come on the English," roared Trinity at the crowd as nobody roared back. "Wave your hands in the air," he screamed at one section of the crowd; two people waved back. "West Indian posse, where are you?" he roared as if in need of some self-assurance.

"I love Brian Lara," screamed Trinity as one cricket fan moaned that he would rather hear the county lunchtime scores over the Tannoy than "this bloody racket".

The Jamaican star's appearance is part of an attempt by Channel 4 to inject some Caribbean atmosphere into the Test series and widen the game's appeal to a younger audience.

The reggae group Third World and Jools Holland played at the Lord's Test, and appearing with Trinity on Saturday was the Blood & Fire reggae sound system. In the evening a rave for 4,000 people took place featuring the drum-and-bass DJ LTJ Bukem and the reggae artists Dillinger and Trinity. Other leading groups are being lined up for the Tests at Headingley and the Oval, and artificial beaches are being created in Leeds and London for fans to come and watch matches on giant screens.

The valiant attempt to give cricket fans a taste of something different was not fully appreciated. Even before Trinity's appearance, many Lancashire members had asked for the noise to be turned down during sound checks. Moments after he took to the stage, dozens of members rushed to reception asking for complaint forms.

"Our members are not too pleased," said a flustered woman at the main reception desk. "We've been telling them that it's not our fault because the entertainment has been organised by the English Cricket Board and Channel 4. It's got nothing to do with us."

"It's bloody atrocious," said Frank Rainford, a steward at the Old Trafford pavilion. "It was too loud and we couldn't understand the words. Revitalising cricket is a big task but you are never going to do it like this. I would have preferred a good tenor singer; it would have been more appropriate for the crowd."

However, not all were as dismissive. "It's not really my scene but I quite liked it," said Tommy Robertson. "I never understood a word he was saying but I think the young folk might be into it. I would have preferred the Bee Gees."

"There's nothing wrong with the music but it's wasted on this lot," Tony Campbell said. "There's a lot of stuck-in-the-muds at cricket but you still have to try to change things."

If cricket organisers want a Caribbean flavour at their matches then they should ensure that people who originate from the Caribbean get into grounds and can then enjoy the game how they want. For example, fans are still not allowed to enter with musical instruments.

Many claim that West Indians are put off by high ticket prices, the dominance of corporate hospitality and having to buy tickets months in advance.

As Trinity waltzed off the stage to muted applause, Saturday's afternoon session saw five streakers run on to the pitch and a series of Mexican waves while a small group of West Indians managed to sneak in a bell and a horn, which echoed around Old Trafford for every Windies boundary. Now that's entertainment.

webTitle: Surrey spin a more comfortable cushion

fields.headline: Surrey spin a more comfortable cushion
fields.trailText: Surrey struck a significant blow in their determination to retain the County Championship title when with substantial help from their spinners Ian Salisbury and Saqlain Mushtaq on Saturday they crushed third-placed Lancashire by 272 runs at the Oval.
fields.body:
Surrey struck a significant blow in their determination to retain the County Championship title when with substantial help from their spinners Ian Salisbury and Saqlain Mushtaq on Saturday they crushed third-placed Lancashire by 272 runs at the Oval.

With Yorkshire limited to 10 points from their draw against Somerset, Surrey have opened an 11-point gap at the top, with Lancashire 19 points adrift in third place. Salisbury took five for 46 and Saqlain three for 45 as Lancashire, chasing 418, were toppled for 145, their first First Division defeat this season.

Yorkshire were given no hope of chasing victory at Taunton after unbeaten centuries by Peter Bowler (139) and Keith Parsons (108) saw Somerset declare on 368 for three, exactly 400 ahead.

Hampshire's Alan Mullally returned five for 95 at Derby to give him career-best match figures of 14 for 188, but his efforts were still not good enough to secure a second win of the season as a career-best innings of 79 by Luke Sutton, together with Michael Di Venuto's unbeaten 78, enabled Derbyshire to cling on for a draw.

The India leg-spinner Anil Kumble returned match figures of 10 for 105 but could not force a victory for Leicestershire over Kent, who had followed on 174 runs behind at Canterbury.

In the Second Division, Glamorgan's promotion push was interrupted by a 10-wicket defeat by Gloucestershire at Bristol, where Alastair Bressington had match figures of five for 49 on his debut.

In Colombo, Lance Klusener hit an unbeaten 50 to check a South Africa batting collapse against Sri Lanka yesterday on the first day of the third and final Test. When rain stopped play shortly before tea, South Africa had made 194 for seven after sliding to 103 for five.
