webTitle: Spear carriers join Lara on road to recovery

fields.headline: Spear carriers join Lara on road to recovery
fields.trailText: Donna Symmonds The West Indies showed an understanding of the necessary elemental construction of plays in defence and attack and the use of the respective skills of all concerned. Execution of same was evident too.
fields.body:
At the start of the fourth day it seemed either team's game, yet West Indies needed sterling performances to continue their comeback. If this match was being played a decade or so ago no one would have demurred at the thought of a West Indian fightback.

However, even the most die-hard West Indian fan - and there are a many at Old Trafford as, indeed, there have been for the series - had doubts as to the ability of the batting line-up to post a defiant and competitive second-innings total.

The reason for this, of course, has been the emphatic lack of consistency shown by this team. It has worried Jimmy Adams and he has been quoted repeatedly on the subject. Added to this must be the feeling that there is an over-dependence on the skill of Brian Lara, which cannot be good for what is essentially a team game.

What the West Indies showed in abundance on day four was an understanding of the necessary elemental construction of plays in defence and attack and the use of the respective skills of all concerned. Execution of same was evident too. That was the key to their success combined with less threatening conditions than might have been expected.

Time management was of as much importance as run-making, a factor clearly understood by the West Indies batsmen. Displaying great patience, Adrian Griffiths and Jimmy Adams got half-centuries on the day and both batted for over four hours. Yet there was always one player trying to keep the scoreboard moving, whether it was Hinds, Lara, Sarwan or Jacobs, and the running between the wickets displayed urgency.

Without doubt Lara is the anchor batsman and the momentum loss without him at the crease was obvious. In Lara's absence there were long periods of the day without the calypso cricket strokes that West Indies have perfected, could have patented and which Lara epitomises so fittingly. His absence did prove beneficial, however, in prompting an intelligent, methodical and solid approach from the others. Many such qualities that Lara himself embodies.

This will not be the future way of West Indies batting, but, in a crisis as it was, it served a purpose. For a team in the rebuilding phase with young players still evolving in all the facets of the game it was a valuable accomplishment.

This recovery from the shambles of the one-day series and the shaky start on resumption of the Test has inestimable worth. Its effect on the outcome of the series is still unknown but it has sent a blaring signal. This series will not be easily lost far less surrendered by the tourists.

Without doubt Lara is the anchor batsman and the momentum loss without him at the crease was obvious. In Lara's absence there were long periods of the day without the calypso cricket strokes that West Indies have perfected, could have patented and which Lara epitomises so fittingly. His absence did prove beneficial, however, in prompting an intelligent, methodical and solid approach from the others. Many such qualities that Lara himself embodies. This will not be the future way of West Indies batting, but, in a crisis as it was, it served a purpose. For a team in the rebuilding phase with young players still evolving in all the facets of the game it was a valuable accomplishment. This recovery from the shambles of the one-day series and the shaky start on resumption of the Test has inestimable worth. Its effect on the outcome of the series is still unknown but it has sent a blaring signal. This series will not be easily lost far less surrendered by the tourists.

webTitle: Edrich has leukaemia

fields.headline: Edrich has leukaemia
fields.trailText: The former England opener John Edrich has been diagnosed with incurable leukaemia.
fields.body:
The former England opener John Edrich has been diagnosed with incurable leukaemia.

The 63-year-old Edrich, who played 77 Tests between 1963 and 1976, said: "I hadn't seen a doctor for about 10 years but I'd been feeling tired for a while. Having taken blood tests, they discovered leukaemia.

"It was quite a shock. You can't fight it. You have to have faith in your consultant and the treatment," said Edrich, who was England's batting coach until five years ago.

"I think we've got to be grateful for what we've had. I did something which I loved and had the ability to play cricket at the highest level."

Edrich, who scored 33 not out while batting with two broken ribs in the fourth Ashes Test of the 1974-75 series in Australia, made 5,138 runs in Tests at an average of 43.

He scored 103 centuries in a career that saw him captain Surrey for five seasons in the 1970s before retiring from the game in 1978.

webTitle: Another twist of genius in the life of Brian

fields.headline: Another twist of genius in the life of Brian
fields.standfirst: Matthew Engel  watches Lara, half-fit and below his best, prove more than a match for England
fields.trailText: Matthew Engel watches Brian Lara, half-fit and below his best, prove more than a match for England.
fields.body:
The mass of people lead lives of quiet desperation. Even most professional sportsmen have a recognisable kind of career path, with the odd little peak, a few troughs and plateaux, and a good many ruts. For a handful - Botham and Warne in cricket, Gascoigne and Beckham in football - it is more like a soap opera. But it is hard to think of anyone whose life in sport has quite matched that of Brian Lara.

He is always either in clover or in crisis, being strewn with rose petals or pelted with rotten eggs, borne in triumph or crushed under the chariot wheels.

In cricket, a team game in which individuality is crucial, players effectively have stock prices that may have nothing to do with the overall state of the market. Lara shares would give their buyers heart failure. They do not rise and fall - they leap and crash.

But Lara is the Vodafone of the West Indian FTSE and yesterday, as his shares shot upwards once again, the prospects of the entire team rose with them. Forty-eight hours after their triumphal Friday England slunk off suddenly keen on the idea of a wet Monday in Manchester. And Lara was back in business only weeks after speculators were suggesting he might never play another Test match.

It was nowhere near his biggest innings. Indeed, of his five previous Test centuries against England, the lowest was 145 and it was somewhat surprising that Lord's did not issue a press release yesterday claiming his 112 as a triumph. It was nothing like his best either.

This was not the bat-for-ever Lara who made 375 and 501 within weeks of each other six years ago. It was not the stroke-playing genius who made 132 on a Perth pitch as fissured as the Grand Canyon three years ago nor the magician who turned the home series against Australia - single-handed, as near as dammit - a year ago.

It was the innings of a fallible cricketer who could have got out loads of times and, in an instant, handed the momentum, perhaps unstoppably, back to England.

It was in the second innings of the Old Trafford Test that Lara roused himself in 1995. If his cricketing powers have since waned, he can still be as single-minded as ever when he wants. And right now he wants. At lunch, on 49 not out, he chose to go and have a 20-minute net. "I just needed to keep my rhythm. I'd just got into a groove and I didn't want to sit in the dressing room."

He was not fully fit either and hinted that his dodgy hamstring might have been responsible for the run-out. But this innings was not intended as a one-off: it was a declaration of intent. Any doubt about that was dispelled when he got to his century and greeted the applause like an Oscar winner. One half-expected him to make a speech thanking his physiotherapist, his psychotherapist and everyone he has ever met in his life.

Instead he was smothered by his captain's embrace. Jimmy Adams hugged the Prodigal with something of the delight with which Mike Brearley greeted Ian Botham's comeback all those years ago.

West Indies with Lara playing anything-like are a completely different proposition from the team of two days ago. And he knows it. When the Guardian asked him to compare his form now with that of five years ago (when Old Trafford was followed by two bigger, series-saving centuries), he demanded: "Why? Are you worried?" "A bit," came the weak reply.

It was a Lara-Croft day. (There was a rumour, apparently false, that the Lara Croft of the computer game was named by a subversive cricket fan. If a future hero is called Ambrose Caddick, there may need to be further investigation.) It could have gone the other way. Even Lara's whacking straight six came the ball after an lbw appeal and another bout of Welsh lip-puckering, oohing and aahing.

But it never does seem to go poor old Crofty's way. One moment everyone gets at him for bowling flat, boring stuff. Now they complain he tries too many variations.

Still, something of Friday's spirit remained. Late in the day there was a chant of "C'mon England!" It was an anxious chant, one that home fans normally raise for a team in sudden trouble. It conveyed none of the derision that might have been expected even a few weeks ago.

webTitle: Hussain's hangover after lost weekend

fields.headline: Hussain's hangover after lost weekend
fields.trailText: David Hopps Faith in England remains measured in days rather than years. Two days earlier, a series victory seemed a formality. What a difference one Brian Lara century can make.
fields.body:
Faith in England remains measured in days rather than years. Two days earlier, an uplifting century by Alec Stewart had encouraged a mood in which the series, nay the world, was now a formality. One Brian Lara century later, and fears that defeat has become an awful possibility are impossible to ignore.

West Indies' lead of 235, with four wickets remaining, might still prove vulnerable today if they are dismissed in the first hour, but few will challenge Lara's assumption that his side is the likeliest to be pressing for victory.

"There is not much life in the pitch, but there are a few lbw decisions around for bowlers who bowl straight," said Lara. "It is going to be tough for England. We have shown a lot of character to fight back in the past two days and this is going to be their opportunity to do so."

Dominic Cork, the most economical member of England's attack, kept Lara in check as successfully as anyone. But Lara's own estimate that he went into the match "only 75% fit" understandably failed to convince a bowler who had just received a close-up reminder of his talents.

"There was no way that you could sense from 22 yards away that he wasn't fully fit," said Cork. "Probably it was more a case of match practice than match fitness. It was a good Test pitch and felt like a long day."

The second new ball, which was envisaged as the source of England's recovery, turned out to be their greatest embarrassment. At 223 for three, West Indies led by 76 and the speedy dismissal of Lara then would have convinced England's bowlers that a benign surface could yet yield victory.

Lara recognised it as "the critical time". Forty runs came from the next seven overs, and as the skies around Old Trafford lightened, the mood visibly darkened. Darren Gough huffed and puffed to little effect, while Andrew Caddick fretted over an absence of rhythm while all around him there was Caribbean carnival.

To retreat to the off-spin of Croft, as his name suggests, implied a meagre, subsistence existence. Most striking of the variations he has added to his repertoire (and which will probably not prolong his Test career) is the one where he freeze-frames in his delivery stride for a full second, as if being observed on a dodgy satellite link.

If only England could have freeze-framed the mood of Friday evening. Instead, after a summer of short, frantic Test matches, and one-day matches, the realisation gradually dawned that a five-day Test can sometimes be a reality.

The reality yesterday was a committed, team-orientated Lara, as one West Indian supporter, with his name daubed in huge letters across her cleavage, clearly recognised.

webTitle: Lara lashes England

fields.headline: Lara lashes England
fields.standfirst:
West Indies are back in business after the Prince of Port of Spain proves that practice makes perfect with a stunning century
West Indies 157 & 381-6
England 303
fields.trailText:
West Indies are back in business after the Prince of Port of Spain proves that practice makes perfect with a stunning century.
West Indies 157 & 381-6
England 303.
fields.body:
His team needed it, he wanted it, and, with the inevitability of the storm after the calm, Brian Lara duly delivered it. A century of stunning individuality and technical brilliance from the Prince of Port of Spain stole the high ground from England yesterday just as surely as Alec Stewart's equally memorable innings had pushed back West Indies on Friday evening. Indeed Lara may just have created the position from which his side can go on to win the third Test.

Lara made 112 in a little more than three hours of blissful batting either side of the lunch interval and may have made a whole bagful more had not Nasser Hussain's midwicket alertness and laser-like throw caught him backing up too enthusiastically. He and his phlegmatic captain Jimmy Adams, brow furrowed like an autumn field, added 138 for the fourth wicket, only 27 of them to Adams but who's counting.

Together they hauled West Indies from the dangerous waters of 164 for three - effectively 20 for three - to a much safer haven. The runs dried to a trickle with Lara's departure as England regained a hold, but by the close West Indies had reached 381 for six, Adams having become an lbw victim for Dominic Cork shortly before the close for 53 after 287 unflappable, unwatchable but vital minutes' batting.

The lead, then, is 235. England believe that even 250 is gettable on what has been a thoroughly good Test pitch, although the highest winning fourth-innings total on this ground is the 145 for seven made by South Africa 45 years ago. West Indies, with equal confidence, feel that such a lead would be more than defendable.

Paradoxically, the best chance of a result either way would have come had West Indies been bowled out last night. Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose will have observed with some anticipation the variable bounce that Andy Caddick and Darren Gough began to extract as the day wore on, and there are few bowlers better at exploiting such vagaries than them.

But however much they would like to do so, they cannot bowl for ever and, instead, the most likely outcome is a draw, given the increasingly sluggish pace of the pitch, the lack of first-rate bowling back-up to Walsh and Ambrose, the need for West Indies to put the game beyond England's reach, and a variable weather forecast.

Lara's was the innings of a great batsman who knew the destiny of his team in this match, and then possibly in the series as a whole, lay in his own success. He had brooded over this one. At the close of play on Saturday evening, before the teams had left the arena, he was down the pavilion steps and on to the pitch to practise drilling throwdowns into a back net.

Again yesterday morning, as the drizzle misted down, he was alone in the nets. Lunchtime came and, one short of a half-century by then, he spent the interval in the nets, perfecting the timing that had seemed to elude him for the early part of his innings, feeling the ball on the bat, maintaining his momentum and, above all, sending out the message that he meant business.

This was Lara at his most committed, the man who abandoned the usual ghosted drivel in his newspaper column to speak instead of the heritage of West Indian cricket and what it meant to him. He was aware, too, that the next generation was watching from the stands and when he rifled Cork through extra cover to reach his hundred, the first salute was to the youngsters of the West Indies Under-15 side sitting maroon-blazered and proud in the stands. They will not forget the gesture.

It was a struggle initially as first the England pace men and then Robert Croft, on a pitch affording promise for his offspin, contrived to bottle him up as best they could. There was a searing square slash off Gough and then he hit Croft massively over long on. But he took 46 balls to reach 30 and his half-century immediately after lunch, from 64 balls, contained only three fours and that six.

The advent of the second new ball, invitingly hard and arriving more readily on to the bat, signalled Lara's gear change. While Adams stood back, there was a calculated assault on Caddick that forced him out of the attack, and four overs from Gough produced 20 runs as 40 came in seven overs. Caddick changed ends and still Lara attacked him. The shot that took him to three figures from only 116 balls was his 12th boundary.

The end was as unexpected as it was a welcome respite for England. Adams had played Craig White to midwicket and almost immediately put his hand up to prevent the run. However Lara, already sprinting, heard Adams's urgent call too late and Hussain, darting in and relying more on instinct than dead aim, threw down the stumps at the bowler's end with the batsman a foot short of the crease.

webTitle: Scotland  round-up

fields.headline: Scotland  round-up
fields.trailText: The season is only two games old but the Scottish Premier League claimed its first casualty yesterday when Paul Sturrock resigned as Dundee United's manager following his team's dismal start.
fields.body:
The season is only two games old but the Scottish Premier League claimed its first casualty yesterday when Paul Sturrock resigned as Dundee United's manager following his team's dismal start.

United remain without a point after losing 3-0 to Hibernian on Saturday and Sturrock, who helped the club win their only Scottish championship as a player in 1983, has decided to step aside.

Maurice Malpas, who is coaching at the club, is likely to be among the front-runners for the vacancy.

Rangers prepared for their Champions League qualifier against the Danish side Herfolge on Wednesday with a 4-2 win at Kilmarnock, but Dick Advocaat was scathing about his players' performance.

Two goals from Andy McLaren gave Kilmarnock a 2-0 lead inside the first 10 minutes and they were overhauled only after Kevin McGowne had been sent off. Billy Dodds scored twice to level the scores, with the substitutes Kenny Miller and Tugay Kerimoglu sealing Rangers' second win.

"The players still seem to think they're playing friendlies," said Advocaat. "If you saw the way we played in the first half and gave the goals away you don't see that in amateur football. The only good thing is that we know that we've got to play better. From my own point of view, I know what is going wrong.

"We've not had a damaging result, which is probably the only thing I can take out of this game. The way we played in the second half is what we have to remember."

Celtic maintained their 100% start with a 1-0 win over Motherwell. Martin O'Neill's side had Jackie McNamara and Chris Sutton, on his home debut, sent off, but Stilian Petrov's goal secured the points. John Davies, the brother of Motherwell's coach Billy Davies, was also shown the red card.

"I thought the sending off of Chris Sutton was pretty hard on the lad," said O'Neill. "I was very surprised at Sutton's first booking and then his second one as well. I thought it was a 50-50 challenge and had the referee given it the other way it wouldn't have been a total surprise."

Goals in the last 10 minutes from Robert Tomaschek and Kris O'Neil gave Hearts a share of the points at St Johnstone last night. Keigan Parker gave the Saints the lead, finishing off a flowing move after half an hour. Graeme Jones doubled their advantage after 73 minutes.

Dundee are the early league leaders, thanks to their new Argentine strike force of Fabian Caballero and Juan Sera. Both scored penalties in the 3-0 win over Dunfermline at Dens Park.

Aberdeen , who play the Dublin side Bohemians in the first qualifying round for the Uefa Cup on Thursday, warmed up with a 2-1 win over St Mirren, Mark Perry's last-minute header giving the Dons their first win of the season. Arild Stavrum had given Aberdeen the lead with a fourth-minute penalty, before Ricky Gillies equalised for St Mirren.

"I don't know a lot about the Irish side, except that they have a very cool name," said Stavrum. "We expect it to be a hard game but hopefully they will be as laid-back as their name suggests."

Peterhead won their debut match in the Third Division, beating Montrose 2-0 in front of a crowd of 700. The league's other newcomers, Elgin City, were less fortunate, losing 2-1 to Brechin City.

"I don't know a lot about the Irish side, except that they have a very cool name," said Stavrum. "We expect it to be a hard game but hopefully they will be as laid-back as their name suggests." Peterhead won their debut match in the Third Division, beating Montrose 2-0 in front of a crowd of 700. The league's other newcomers, Elgin City, were less fortunate, losing 2-1 to Brechin City.

webTitle: Alarm  bells for FIFA and transfer system

fields.headline: Alarm  bells for FIFA and transfer system
fields.trailText: Football's entire transfer system could be scrapped if the European Union upholds a test case next month that would make the controversial Bosman ruling pale into insignificance by comparison and plunge the game into unprecedented chaos.
fields.body:
Football's entire transfer system could be scrapped if the European Union upholds a test case next month that would make the controversial Bosman ruling pale into insignificance by comparison and plunge the game into unprecedented chaos.

Payments of transfer fees for contracted footballers would become a thing of the past with, for instance, Manchester United's Roy Keane, the Premiership's highest paid player, able to move any time, anywhere without the club receiving a penny in return.

At the other end of the scale, smaller clubs who have nurtured and developed rising stars and desperately in need of funds would receive nothing when their most prized assets move on.

Until now, contracted players have been unaffected by the five-year-old Bosman ruling which changed the face of European football but only affects those who are out of contract and free agents. But the case now being studied in Brussels would, if upheld, extend Bosman to every professional currently employed in any EC country.

The alarming prospect of an end to the transfer system as we know it was the biggest single revelation made by Fifa at its two-day congress in Zurich at the weekend. So anxious is the world governing body to prevent what it believes would lead to total disruption that it has joined forces with Uefa in a rare combined assault on Brussels.

Fifa general secretary Michel zen Ruffinen says his organisation has received "signals" that the EU might be preparing to rule in favour of Italian club Perugia who have appealed against being forced to pay for a player it recruited from Belgium but who has now left the club.

Perugia's ground-breaking case apparently hinges on the fact that under normal employment law, it should not have had to pay anything even though the player concerned was still under contract.

In what is being widely viewed as a crucial test case for the future of the game, a preliminary hearing into Perugia's appeal is due to be held next month. If upheld, it could do away overnight with a system that has been in place for decades resulting in alarming ramifications.

"If we allow players under contract to leave without any compensation, it would be a disaster. It would kill football as we know it," Zen Ruffinen said. "It would be impossible to police." The combined Fifa-Uefa group of experts is expected to hold its first meeting within the next three weeks to formulate an urgent recommendation to Brussels.

"This is a very dangerous situation and one we need to address very quickly," zen Ruffinen said. "We may have to find some other kind of solution that binds a player to a club."

Apart from potential transfer chaos, a global agreement that the World Cup should be rotated in future was the other most significant item to emerge from Fifa's 203-nation congress.

Yet it is becoming increasingly clear that Africa may not be the only Continent bidding for the tournament when the principle of rotation begins in 2010.

It was only after being assured that the African Continent would be in pole position for 2010 that South Africa agreed reluctantly to withdraw its threat to take the controversial 2006 vote, which it narrowly lost to Germany, to a civil court.

But there is a growing body of opinion within Fifa that rotating the World Cup around the six Continents will not work.

One proposal already being studied is to let any Continent bid for the event provided it has not held either of the last two. Under such a plan South America, for instance, would be permitted to take on Africa next time.

"Let's face it, we wouldn't even be talking about rotation if South Africa had won 2006," said Fifa executive committee member Chuck Blazer. "Giving the tournament to only one continent each time stifles competition," he added.

webTitle: Friendlies round-up

fields.headline: Friendlies round-up
fields.trailText: The Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson at least saw encouraging displays from two of his new signings, the Australian Paul Okon and Cameroon's Joseph-Desire Job, in Middlesbrough's 2-0 defeat against Borussia Dortmund at the Riverside Stadium yesterday.
fields.body:
The Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson at least saw encouraging displays from two of his new signings, the Australian Paul Okon and Cameroon's Joseph-Desire Job, in Middlesbrough's 2-0 defeat against Borussia Dortmund at the Riverside Stadium yesterday.

Boro were off the pace in a friendly that also marked Robbie Mustoe's ten years at the club, but Okon was industrious and Job caused problems for Dortmund's central defenders.

Hamilton Ricard, by contrast, had a poor game and was withdrawn at half-time.

A strike from Victor Ikpeba and an own goal from the young Boro defender Jason Gavin won the game for the Germans.

Arsène Wenger will not have missed the irony as Barcelona, featuring his £30m cast-offs Marc Overmars and Emmanuel Petit, won Ajax's Centenary Tournament in Amsterdam on Saturday.

But the Arsenal manager is likely to have been more concerned about the lack of sharpness among his front-rank performers in the closing tournament game against Ajax as Arsenal went down 2-1 following defeat by Barca on Thursday.

Thierry Henry and Patrick Vieira, both substituted in the second half, looked sluggish, while Robert Pires and Lauren did little to show they will quickly fill the gaps left by Overmars and Petit.

Barcelona, who played Petit as a sweeper and brought Overmars on as a second-half substitute, clinched the title on goals-scored with a 3-3 draw against Lazio.

Aston Villa, who are expected to show off their new signing David Ginola in Friday's final pre-season friendly at Benfica, may have temporarily lost the services of their full back Mark Delaney after he sustained a suspected knee ligament injury during Villa's 1-1 draw at Tamworth on Saturday.

Fabien Barthez's debut for Manchester United was a losing one as his new team lost 3-1 to Bayern Munich in the final of that club's Centenary Tournament at the Olympicstadion.

David Beckham missed a second-half penalty and United's defence looked out of sorts for most of the game as the tournament hosts gained some sort of revenge for their defeat in the 1999 Champions League final.

The European champions, Real Madrid, who were beaten 1-0 by United on Friday, came from behind to beat the Uefa Cup holders Galatasaray 3-2 and take third place in the tournament.

Paul Gascoigne took part in Everton's 4-1 win over Exeter but was only brought on in the 69th minute, by which time his side had taken an unassailable lead with two goals from Alex Nyarko and one each from Niclas Alexandersson and Francis Jeffers.

George Weah's debut for Manchester City was the only bright spot in an unnerving 4-1 defeat at Stockport for Joe Royle's newly-promoted side.

Weah, who scored City's only goal, initially struggled to build a rapport with his new team-mates but improved as the game went on. "He hasn't lost any of his pace - but he needs a yard of sharpness," said Royle, who described the overall display as City's worst in two years.

The Tottenham manager George Graham left Ian Walker on the bench in favour of Neil Sullivan for the second successive warm-up game as he used 17 players in a 2-0 win over QPR in Danny Maddix's testimonial.

webTitle: Wanchope set to seal £4m City deal

fields.headline: Wanchope set to seal £4m City deal
fields.trailText: Manchester City will today complete the £4m signing of Paulo Wanchope after Bradford's late bid to secure the services of the Costa Rican striker collapsed.
fields.body:
Manchester City will today complete the £4m signing of Paulo Wanchope after Bradford's late bid to secure the services of the Costa Rican striker collapsed.

Although the Bradford chairman Geoffrey Richmond matched the fee agreed between Manchester City and West Ham earlier in the week the lure of teaming up with the former world footballer of the year George Weah ultimately proved too tempting.

Wanchope, who will join City after just one season at Upton Park following his £3.5million move from Derby last summer, gave serious consideration to both offers but his agent Dennis Roach confirmed: "At the moment, Manchester City are the favourites.

"We've just a few final bits and pieces to finish off with West Ham. Hopefully we will then travel to Manchester tomorrow afternoon or evening to finalise the deal."

City chairman David Bernstein is confident Wanchope will become Joe Royle's third signing since the club secured promotion into the top flight last May.

"We believe that he made his mind up on Saturday," revealed Bernstein. "We are expecting him at Maine Road tomorrow to have his medical and sign for us."

Wanchope's decision will come as a frustrating blow to both Richmond and the Bradford manager Chris Hutchings, who have been desperately searching for a striker throughout the summer months.

Despite the club's record bid for Wanchope, Bradford will now have to turn their attentions elsewhere. But with the new season only two weeks away, and other target Titi Camara now unlikely to leave Liverpool following Robbie Fowler's injury, the search is looking increasingly fruitless for the Valley Parade club.

As is Manchester City's quest to sign Aston Villa's central defender Ugo Ehiogu. Following the rejection of two bids in recent weeks Bernstein is beginning to lose patience with the Midlands club.

An initial bid of £6m was dismissed by Villa, who want to drive up the price of the 27-year-old given that his former club West Brom are set to receive 50% of any sell-on transfer fee. A subsequent bid, believed to be in excess of £7m, was also rebuffed.

"We have been talking to Aston Villa on and off for about six weeks now," said Bernstein. "I'm not sure they have made up their minds to sell him or not as they have got this major sell-on (clause) to West Bromwich Albion which they are trying to sort out.

"I think that's proving a problem for them. If we don't sort it out fairly soon then we will have to look elsewhere."

 Arsenal and Charlton, formerly Croydon, shared this year's Women's Charity Shield after yesterday's 1-1 draw at Craven Cottage. England's Marieanne Spacey gave the Gunners a 22nd-minute lead but Charlton snatched a late equaliser courtesy of Emily Arnold's 88th-minute tap-in.

webTitle: Golden future awaits Blue Wolf

fields.headline: Golden future awaits Blue Wolf
fields.standfirst: Sami Al Jaber is already a hero in Saudi Arabia, but he wants to make his mark on the English game, writes Adrian Milledge
fields.trailText: Sami Al Jaber is already a hero in Saudi Arabia, but he wants to make his mark on the English game, writes Adrian Milledge.
fields.body:
Wolves supporters could never be found guilty of being parochial in their choice of goalscoring heroes.

After being sustained for more than a decade by a feast of goals from their Black Country boy Steve Bull, they readily welcomed the Hackney-born Nigerian Ade Akinbiyi as a successor. Following his departure to Leicester City they are urging their manager Colin Lee to turn to a man from the desert to avert a potential goal famine.

"Sign him up, sign him up", they chorused at frequent intervals on Saturday as they were given their first sighting of Saudi Arabian striker Sami Al Jaber. Known as the Alan Shearer of his homeland, the 27-year-old Al Jaber is on a fortnight's trial at Molineux. He is also known to fans of his club, the Asian Cup winners and Saudi champions Al Hilal, as the Blue Wolf because of the colour of his shirt and his predatory instincts in front of goal.

Those have resulted in him scoring 200 goals in 420 appearances for the Riyadh-based club and 44 in 80 games for Saudi Arabia.

That tally of caps includes two World Cup finals and the match against England at Wembley this year. Despite those impressive credentials, it is a measure of Lee's determination to check out Al Jaber as thoroughly as possible that Wolves lost money on Saturday's match.

They agreed to the Department for Education and Employment's demand that, because Al Jaber does not have a work permit, all proceeds from the game should be given to charity.

If Lee does opt to make the 27-year-old an Old Gold wolf, Al Jaber's international record will not present any problems in securing a permit.

And though Lee would not confirm that he is set to pay in the region of £1.5m for the player, the manager appears to be leaning that way after studying videos provided by his agent Phil Graham and watching Al Jaber train and play in two friendlies.

"I think he has proved today he is a talent worth pursuing," Lee said after the match against Southampton. "If you give him the ball in the right areas he is quite exciting and makes things happen.

"He's a clever player and his performance against a couple of strong Premiership defenders is worth fairly high marks.

"I have got another week to look at him and then we will discuss his value and decide whether we are going to take him on."

Power and pace

As yet Al Jaber has not demonstrated his goalscoring prowess in England, failing to score in a private friendly with Leicester City on Thursday and against Southampton on Saturday. It was not for want of trying against the Saints as he went close on three occasions. But the part he played in setting up Wolves' goal on Thursday and his approach play against Glenn Hoddle's men suggest there is more to his game than being a typical target man.

Not that he is built like one: his height, physique and dark colouring bring to mind Ossie Ardiles. He is also very quick and resilient, emerging unscathed and unbowed by some crunching challenges from Talul Khahlej, Southampton¹s Moroccan defender.

It was Khahlej¹s compatriot Hassan Kachloul who settled matters at Molineux with a 54th-minute goal after the Latvian striker Marian Pahars had cancelled out Andy Sinton's opener for the hosts. The defensive lapses that resulted in those goals will concern Lee but he need not be worried about Al Jaber's motives for wanting to become the first Saudi to play in England. If he does so then he will add to the ever-increasing number of nationalities on view in the Premiership and Football League but, unlike some of them, Al Jaber is anything but a footballing mercenary.

By joining Wolves he would be exchanging the well-paid trappings of stardom in Riyadh, which include a villa with pool, playing in front of 40,000 crowds, and the desert sunshine, for cold January nights at such footballing outposts as Grimsby.

It is an exchange Al Jaber, who says Marco van Basten was his favourite European player, will make gladly. It is also long overdue.

"Until a year ago we were not allowed to play for foreign clubs, he explained. "The rule was ended because it was felt if players got experience of other leagues, especially in Europe, it would benefit the national team.

"Now one player is playing for a club in China and another in Holland.

"I hope to be the first to play in England because I want to widen my horizons and improve my game. I believe I can do it here with Wolves."

webTitle: Death of Sir Alec Guinness

fields.headline: The shy introvert who shone on screen
fields.trailText: Actors and film-makers today paid tribute to Sir Alec Guinness, the British double Oscar winner who died at the age of 86 in hospital on Saturday.
fields.body:
Actors and film-makers today paid tribute to Sir Alec Guinness, the British double Oscar winner who died at the age of 86 in hospital on Saturday.

Sir Alec, one of a generation of actors that included Sir Laurence Olivier, Sir John Gielgud and Sir Ralph Richardson, had reportedly suffered a long illness. He was taken to the King Edward VII Hospital in Midhurst, West Sussex by ambulance on Thursday after a routine call from his GP.

Consultant Dr Jenny Masding, a palliative care specialist at the hospital, who treated Sir Alec at the end, said he died at 9.50pm on Saturday. "His death is a real loss," she said.

Film-maker Ronald Neame, who produced the versions of Oliver Twist and Great Expectations starring Sir Alec, said he was shattered by the news. "He was one of the all-time greats of both stage and screen. Professionally and personally he was one of my greatest friends," he said. "He taught me more about acting than anybody else I have ever met or am likely to meet."

Sir Alec's acting career spanned 60 years and ranged from Shakespearian classics to Ealing comedies, and, of course, his acclaimed television portrayal of the spymaster George Smiley. His performance as the colonel in Bridge on the River Kwai (1959) won him an Oscar and led to a knighthood in the same year.

Obi-Wan Kenobi gave Sir Alec a role in Star Wars, one of the most successful films of all time, but the veteran actor professed to despise all the attention it brought him. In later years, Sir Alec said he threw away all Star Wars fan mail unopened, despite the 2% cut of the director's gross royalties he received from the blockbuster film. "He was one of the most talented and respected actors of his generation and brought an amazing range and versatility to his work," said Star Wars creator George Lucas. In 1980, he was awarded a second Oscar for his outstanding contribution to screen acting.

The son of a banker, Sir Alec always wanted to be an actor as a boy and often walked three miles from his home in Bayswater, central London, to the Old Vic to spend his pocket money watching performances there.

Fellow actor Sir John Mills said:"He was first of all, as you know, a very, very great actor but he was very, very retiring, shy, very charming and he had great humility."

Sir Alec leaves behind his wife of 62 years, playwright Merula Salaman, and son Matthew.

The son of a banker, Sir Alec always wanted to be an actor as a boy and often walked three miles from his home in Bayswater, central London, to the Old Vic to spend his pocket money watching performances there. Fellow actor Sir John Mills said:"He was first of all, as you know, a very, very great actor but he was very, very retiring, shy, very charming and he had great humility." Sir Alec leaves behind his wife of 62 years, playwright Merula Salaman, and son Matthew.

webTitle: The best smalltown bar scene: The Perfect Storm

fields.headline: The best smalltown bar scene: The Perfect Storm
fields.trailText: Gloucester, Mass. As the Andrea Gail plunges into the storm, the families of the crew wait for news in the local bar. The ship's owner Bob Brown (Michael Ironside) enters. Crew member Bobby Shatford's mother Ethel (Janet Wright) and girlfriend Chris Cotter (Diane Lane) look up as he walks in.
fields.body:
Gloucester, Mass. As the Andrea Gail plunges into the storm, the families of the crew wait for news in the local bar. The ship's owner Bob Brown (Michael Ironside) enters. Crew member Bobby Shatford's mother Ethel (Janet Wright) and girlfriend Chris Cotter (Diane Lane) look up as he walks in.

"If it were good news," mutters Ethel, "he would have called."

Brown addresses the bar.

"The news is, the rescue helicopter had to ditch. We can't raise the Andrea Gail."

Anger flashes across Chris's face.

"What does that mean?"

"We don't know anything. But if anyone can survive this, it's Billy Tyne - I'll give him that."

"What do you want?" Chris spits. "Credit for having the guts to walk in here?"

"I do."

Quentin, a grizzled old guy sitting alone at the end of the bar, speaks up.

"Well, give it to him."

Brown turns to Quentin.

"How you doing Quentin?"

"Pretty good."

"You're counting your money," Chris screams, "and my guy's out there - risking his life for a bunch of stupid fish!"

Brown catches her eye.

"That's the game."

"Well, I hate the game."

Suddenly, Chris lunges across the bar, flailing wildly at Brown.

webTitle: Sir Robin Day dies, aged 76

fields.headline: Sir Robin Day dies, aged 76
fields.standfirst:
Obituary
Comment: never a journalist, always an institution
fields.trailText: Sir Robin Day, the broadcaster best known for his many years on BBC1's Question Time and Panorama has died at the age of 76.
fields.body:
Sir Robin Day, the broadcaster best known for his many years on BBC1's Question Time and Panorama has died at the age of 76.

"Sir Robin died here last night. He had been in for a few days for an investigation into a cardiac condition," Michael Stroud, chief executive of the Wellington Hospital in St John's Wood, London.

"He died very peacefully at 9pm. His family weren't with him but his consultant was." He said Sir Robin had been in and out of the hospital several times over the last year for treatment for his heart condition. His friend and executor Sir Ronald Waterhouse, who announced the death this afternoon, said the broadcaster, who was feared by politicians for his interrogations, had suffered a blackout but doctors had been unable to find the cause of the problem.

Famous for his bow-ties and sharp conversation, Sir Robin Day was a pillar of the post-war broadcasting establishment, helping to found ITN at the start of commercial broadcasting in Britain and pioneering the art of the political interview.

Although a fixture on the political scene he never developed his early ambition to enter parliament, despite standing for the Liberal party in the 1959 election.

He played a central role in covering no fewer than eight general elections on television. On Radio 4, Sir Robin presented The World at One from 1979 to 1987.

webTitle: Labour's vital mission to carry on reforming

fields.headline: Labour's vital mission to carry on reforming
fields.standfirst:
Road to the manifesto
Special report: road to the manifesto
fields.trailText: Road to the manifesto - the constitution.
fields.body:
When the historians come to judge Labour's first term in office, they may well regard constitutional reform as its most radical achievement. A government condemned for control freakery in its handling of internal party management has in fact given away more power than any administration since Clement Attlee presided over the dismantling of the British empire.

Whether by creating a parliament in Scotland, assemblies in Wales and Northern Ireland or a mayoralty in London, Labour has remade the landscape of the British constitution. This is no abstract achievement, of interest only to political scientists and anoraks. For the way a nation governs itself affects how it is governed: by changing our constitution, we hope not only to get a neater looking system but also better railways, schools or hospitals.

Constitutions matter, and Labour's task for the second term is to sort out the confusion and outright messes left by the overhauls of the first - and then to reform some more. Devolution has certainly left a patchwork of confusion, duplication and redundancy. A second-term clean-up should seek to shift to Edinburgh those extra powers the Scots want and to give Wales (and, in time, Northern Ireland) much the same degree of autonomy - with the eventual aim of confining Westminster's workload to those decisions which affect the entire United Kingdom.

Decision-making for England should, where possible, move away from Westminster and towards either local or regional government: that way, power would shift dramatically closer to where people actually live. Perhaps an even clearer case of unfinished business than devolution is the House of Lords. Labour's partial reform of the second chamber, by removing all but 92 of the hereditary peers, was a welcome first step - but it has created a new set of problems. The Lords continues to hold up the government's programme, except now Labour cannot dismiss it as an entirely fraudulent body, overwhelmingly selected by aristocratic bloodline.

It has acquired a spurious legitimacy, even though it is barely more democratic than the blue-blood house it replaced. The government should move swiftly in the second term to put aside the timidly conservative proposals of the Wakeham commission and opt for a fully elected second chamber. It could be a much smaller body than the Commons, with members representing regions rather than constituencies - elected at different times from the lower house to ensure a different political complexion. That way it could do the job so sorely lacking in our current system of "fused" rather than separated powers: it could act as a genuine democratic check and balance, holding the executive to account.

Its committees might scrutinise new bills and monitor the progress of ones that have recently been passed, to see if they work in practice. They might also interview and then ratify key public appointments, from cabinet ministers to senior judges.

Chosen separately from the House of Commons, these committees would be wholly independent, entirely out of reach of government whips and unswayed by patronage from Downing Street. At last, we would have a legislature distinct from the executive, a feature of almost every advanced democracy but our own.

Labour should extend the separation of powers in another, much less discussed direction: by peeling the judiciary away from the executive. At present, judges are appointed by an unelected member of the cabinet, the lord chancellor. Instead, Labour should honour its earlier commitment to an independent judicial appointments commission: that body could nominate new judges, who would then be ratified (or not) by the justice committee of a reformed second chamber.

Nor can the Commons leave itself out of this process of change. So long as the executive is drawn from the majority party in the Commons, it is naive to expect the lower house to behave independently: the government, by definition, will always get its way in the end. More realistic is to seek reforms to the way the house works.

In 1997 Labour promised a referendum on a new voting system for the Commons: it should honour that promise in the next term. It should also make good on all its rhetoric of modernisation by dragging Westminster's working procedures out of the Victorian dark ages. Labour should say yes to normal daytime office hours, yes to electronic voting - and yes even to breastfeeding in the chamber.

One last piece of the constitution is left - and it is over-ripe for change. It is unrealistic to imagine any government altering the way we choose our head of state in a single term of office.

But Labour can at least give a formal seal to the process of debate - a debate which is already under way in the country. The government should establish an "unroyal commission" to look at the monarchy and to imagine how Britain might choose its head of state once the Queen is no longer on the throne. This should be no panel of the great and the good, but rather a standing forum for dialogue - a kind of constitutional convention for the 21st century.

Pledges

1. A fully elected second chamber

2. Referendum on a new voting system for the House of Commons

3. Independent appointment of senior judges

4. An "unroyal commission" to debate the selection of Britain's head of state

5. Abolish "Whitehall" and move beyond the old rigid government department

webTitle: Sir Robin Day: 1923-2000

fields.headline: Sir Robin Day: 1923-2000
fields.standfirst: Sir Robin Day dies aged 76
fields.trailText: Sir Robin Day, who has died aged 76, was the most outstanding television journalist of his generation. He transformed the television interview, changed the relationship between politicians and television and strove throughout his career to assert balance and rationality into television's treatment of current affairs.
fields.body:
Sir Robin Day, who has died aged 76, was the most outstanding television journalist of his generation. He transformed the television interview, changed the relationship between politicians and television and strove throughout his career to assert balance and rationality into television's treatment of current affairs.

He was the youngest of four children by nine years. His father, a Lloyd George Liberal, was on the administrative staff of the Post Office. Robin was educated at Bembridge School, had an uneventful wartime period in the Royal Artillery, became a captain, and went to St Edmund Hall, Oxford, in 1947 at the age of 24.

He made his mark at Oxford as a memorable president of the union. Then he had a brief spell at the bar, but decided after two years that the prospect of success was too distant. He spent one year with the British information services in the United States, was briefly employed, on a temporary basis, by BBC Radio. In 1955 he joined Independent Television News, at its launch, as one of its new breed of newscasters.

ITN made him. It gave him, by his own account, his happiest four years in television. He was not an instant success. It was originally felt, by his colleagues as well as critics, that he was too unsympathetic and harsh in manner, but this view changed as he developed an entirely new style of interviewing.

In the pre-Day era, interviews were almost always respectful, generally dull and stiff, often insipid. Day asked the direct question pointed like a dagger at the jugular. The turning point in his career was an interview with Sir Kenneth Clark, chairman of Independent Television, at a time when proposals were mooted to cut ITN's time and money. Day asked him questions about ITN's future which dumbfounded colleagues and television critics alike by their directness. It was unprecedented at that time that the person in ultimate charge should be questioned about his responsibilities by one of his own employees. The interview made a dramatic impact.

There followed a number of historic interviews which established Day's reputation: with Egypt's President Nasser after the Suez war, when Day sought to pin him down on whether he accepted the existence of the state of Israel; with ex-US president Harry Truman: "Mr President do you regret having authorised the dropping of the atomic bomb?"; and notably with former British prime minister Harold Macmillan in 1958: "the most vigorous cross-examination a prime minister has been subjected to in public" (Daily Express).

This interview made Macmillan - forever known afterwards as - Supermac into a television personality and was probably the first time that television became a serious part of the political process. Day also made parliament come alive (years before it was shown on television) with his unscripted reports of the heated debates during the Suez war.

In 1959 Day moved to Panorama, then the most prestigious programme on current affairs. The BBC never really made the best use of his talents, except at elections and eventually in Question Time. The fashion turned against "talking heads" and "government by debate" with which he, above all others, was identified. He was gradually sidelined, as a chairman who simply opened and closed programmes, or even not used at all.

He described his pre-Question Time period at the BBC as 10 years in the wilderness. There was even a period of nearly two years when he never appeared on the box at all.

In the early-1970s he became more deeply involved in radio, where he again proved an innovator with It's Your Line, a national phone-in programme that enabled ordinary people for the first time to put questions directly to the prime minister and other politicians. This in turn spawned Election Call.

He also presented The World At One for eight years but he never felt that radio was his metier. He was not at his best reading from a prepared script, particularly towards the end of his time on The World At One and it is significant that in his memoirs he dismisses his eight-year contribution with a single sentence.

General elections were the time when all the grand inquisitor's talents as cross-examiner were on full display, when the television public saw "the scowling, frowning, glowering" Robin Day "with those cruel glasses" (Frankie Howerd's description), as well as the relieving shafts of humour. But his most satisfying role in television came relatively late, in 1979, with Question Time. At last he was given his own show with an audience, which he had long asked for, though late at night, as a temporary, six-month "filler" and mainly as a way of giving him something to do. Its success in becoming, under his chairmanship, the most popular and effective current affairs programme on television reveals a great deal about his talents.

Why did Robin Day become a national institution, one of the most immediately recognised persons in the land, outshining in reputation and respect other TV stars whose shows commanded far larger audience figures (and, as he much resented, far higher salaries)? It was because he had a unique combination of qualities. He was a very big personality in the true sense, with immense authority. He was extraordinarily witty. A collection of good Day jokes would fill a minor anthology. Question Time also brought out his charm and showmanship.

He was inordinately proud of his Old Time Music Hall gifts and would insist on showing visitors to his flat videos of his appearances on the Morecombe and Wise Christmas shows and especially of his Flanagan and Allen rendering of Underneath the Arches on the Des O'Connor show, in which he out-starred and out-sang O'Connor. But, above all, he was one of the most well-informed, widely read and serious political figures in public life.

Robin Day imbibed politics almost from the day he was born. His father brought him up to revere parliament and great parliamentarians. As a nine-year-old he was taken to hear Churchill speak (in the rain). Respect for parliament and the traditional institutions of British life, such as the monarchy and the legal profession was at the heart of his political philosophy all his life.

It might be said that his interests were somewhat conventional and narrow. He was almost fixated by parliament and seemed to think that if someone had made a great parliamentary speech they had won a great battle, when in fact it was events outside parliament that were transforming British politics. His world was one of party politics and current events, rather than long-term trends. He was not particularly interested in industrial affairs or economics or developments in European countries.

Gradually his private views became more and more conservative, at times rather narrowly nationalist, although he did not allow his personal prejudices to show in public or influence his professional performances. But within the boundaries of his particular interests he applied his formidable powers of argument and his extensive knowledge to devastating effect, in private as well as public.

He believed passionately in "government by debate" and in the need for television to balance pictures of current events with reasoned analysis. Otherwise the powerful visual impact of television would distort and trivialise.

He was equally dedicated to the principle that the interviewer had a duty to be well-informed. Many observers commented on his careful preparation. Few realised how assiduous he was. He would read every current biography and autobiography and nearly every government White Paper. Without research assistants to supply him with background briefings, he would generally be better informed than the cabinet ministers he interviewed. No wonder prime ministers treated him as their equal, and lesser mortals on the political scene regarded him with awe.

Day's contribution to British public life was not confined to the media. For 25 years he campaigned tirelessly, and eventually successfully, for the televising of parliament, not in the interests of television but of parliament itself. He claimed that he was the first to present the detailed arguments in favour, in a Hansard Society paper in 1963.

He also played a major part in the establishment of the National Lottery. When the Rothschild commission on gambling was set up in 1979, he wrote a letter arguing in detail for the kind of lottery we have today. Lord Rothschild wrote back questioning his arguments. Day replied refuting all criticisms. His arguments prevailed and the eventual report recommended the scheme Day had originally proposed. He followed up with endless letters to successive ministers with relevant responsibilities.

In his private life Robin Day had two personalities. To those who did not know him he could at times appear aggressive and insensitive, seemingly interested only in those who were important because of their fame, public success or wealth. He sometimes found it difficult to talk naturally to intelligent women. He might, to some, have seemed the quintessential member of the all-male Garrick club, one of his favourite haunts.

To those who knew him well he was the most stimulating, amusing, convivial and warm of companions. He was one of those rare people who was genuinely loved by his friends and will be sorely missed. He was prepared to take infinite pains on their behalf. He was also surprisingly modest. Despite his obvious success in public life, he frequently talked of his career as a relative failure, because he had not achieved anything solid.

He regretted that he had never entered parliament and contributed to the real world of politics instead of playing a secondary role through television. He thrived on his public fame and was proud to be the first television star to be knighted, but privately seemed genuinely to feel that his achievements did not compare with those of others who had made their mark in the more traditional professions, especially the law, or by writing learned books.

He married Katherine Ainslie, an Australian, then a law don, at St Anne's College, Oxford, in 1965 and had two sons. The marriage was dissolved in 1985. One of the tragedies of his life was that his eldest son had a fall as a child which caused multiple fractures to the skull from whose effects he never entirely recovered.

Some years ago Robin Day had a coronary bypass and he suffered from breathing problems that were often evident when he was on the air. He had always fought against a tendency to put on weight. As an undergraduate he weighed 17 stone and claimed that in the course of his life he had succeeded in losing more weight than any other person.

No wonder prime ministers treated him as their equal, and lesser mortals on the political scene regarded him with awe. Day's contribution to British public life was not confined to the media. For 25 years he campaigned tirelessly, and eventually successfully, for the televising of parliament, not in the interests of television but of parliament itself. He claimed that he was the first to present the detailed arguments in favour, in a Hansard Society paper in 1963. He also played a major part in the establishment of the National Lottery. When the Rothschild commission on gambling was set up in 1979, he wrote a letter arguing in detail for the kind of lottery we have today. Lord Rothschild wrote back questioning his arguments. Day replied refuting all criticisms. His arguments prevailed and the eventual report recommended the scheme Day had originally proposed. He followed up with endless letters to successive ministers with relevant responsibilities. In his private life Robin Day had two personalities. To those who did not know him he could at times appear aggressive and insensitive, seemingly interested only in those who were important because of their fame, public success or wealth. He sometimes found it difficult to talk naturally to intelligent women. He might, to some, have seemed the quintessential member of the all-male Garrick club, one of his favourite haunts. To those who knew him well he was the most stimulating, amusing, convivial and warm of companions. He was one of those rare people who was genuinely loved by his friends and will be sorely missed. He was prepared to take infinite pains on their behalf. He was also surprisingly modest. Despite his obvious success in public life, he frequently talked of his career as a relative failure, because he had not achieved anything solid. He regretted that he had never entered parliament and contributed to the real world of politics instead of playing a secondary role through television. He thrived on his public fame and was proud to be the first television star to be knighted, but privately seemed genuinely to feel that his achievements did not compare with those of others who had made their mark in the more traditional professions, especially the law, or by writing learned books. He married Katherine Ainslie, an Australian, then a law don, at St Anne's College, Oxford, in 1965 and had two sons. The marriage was dissolved in 1985. One of the tragedies of his life was that his eldest son had a fall as a child which caused multiple fractures to the skull from whose effects he never entirely recovered. Some years ago Robin Day had a coronary bypass and he suffered from breathing problems that were often evident when he was on the air. He had always fought against a tendency to put on weight. As an undergraduate he weighed 17 stone and claimed that in the course of his life he had succeeded in losing more weight than any other person.

webTitle: The ball-breakers

fields.headline: The ball-breakers
fields.standfirst: Nora, Medea and Lulu - three women bound by male fantasy, or wielding sexual authority?  Michael Billington sees the fringe get serious
fields.trailText: Nora, Medea and Lulu - three women bound by male fantasy, or wielding sexual authority? Michael Billington sees the fringe get serious.
fields.body:
Women are very much on top at Edinburgh this year. Not only are the most substantial new plays coming from women writers, but three major fringe productions have reminded us of the extent to which women have always provided mythical theatrical archetypes. Seeing variations on Ibsen's Nora, Euripides's Medea and Wedekind's Lulu in close proximity you understand how independence is only achieved through terrifying personal sacrifice.

The mystery about the National Theatre of Norway's outstanding production of A Doll's House at the Lyceum is why it is only playing three performances on the fringe; it cries out to be a part of Brian McMaster's international festival. While respecting Ibsen's text, it brings out more clearly than any version I have seen the way Nora is forced into a life of domestic prostitution. Having forged a document to pay her husband's life-saving medical bills, she is driven into all kinds of sexual humiliation to conceal the truth.

Anneke von der Lippe's Nora, a vivacious brunette in a low-cut red dress, is clearly accustomed to private whoring. The bird-noises she makes as she literally leaps into Torvald's arms are part of a masochistic sexual ritual. When she tells him that "the skylark will do tricks" she goes on all fours and provocatively wiggles her bum at him. Sex is this Nora's secret weapon. But its over-use reduces her to bulimic, suicidal desperation as she vomits up the macaroons she constantly stuffs in her mouth. Her final declaration of independence becomes all the more powerful because we have seen the humiliations imposed on her by marital captivity. It is a brilliant performance in a first-rate production by Kjetil Bang-Hansen.

Where Nora leaves her children, Medea, in Liz Lochhead's pugnacious adaptation for Theatre Babel at the Assembly Rooms, deploys them as an instrument of revenge, then murders them.

What is startling about Lochhead's version is that Medea emerges as neither superhuman goddess nor foreign witch, more an archetypal example of the wronged woman driven to retaliatory violence. Maureen Beattie endows Medea with a European refugee accent, a vehement dignity and an unusual degree of complicity with the audience. Informing us that women wronged in bed will "have your guts for garters", she reaches out to the front row with a terrifying balls-crunching gesture.

Beattie's performance has tremendous visceral power and sexual authority. My only cavil about Lochhead's version and Graham McLaren's production is that they mitigate the horror of Medea's infanticide. Medea's justification of their murder - that she is saving them from the hands of her enemies - is treated as a cool political ploy and the play becomes a straightforward feminist endorsement of her actions. But it gains a propulsive contemporaneity that has men in the audience shifting uneasily in their seats.

After this, a Danish cabaret version of Lulu, based both on the Wedekind play and the Pabst movie, presented by Odense Internationale Musikteater at the Assembly Rooms, comes as light relief. Chris Jordan's songs have echoes of Weill, Wagner, Bizet, Christmas carols and country-and-western, and the show has a smoky, late-night loucheness. But behind the atmosphere of sophisticated decadence we are reminded that Sonja Richter's Lulu, the sexual free-spirit finally destroyed by Jack the Ripper, is close kin to Nora and Medea. She is the exotic other who sacrifices herself on the altar of male fantasy and suffers accordingly. She also proves that, so far at the Edinburgh fringe this year, it is women who are calling the shots and defining the shits.

webTitle: Arts: Edinburgh festival diary

fields.headline: Festival diary
fields.trailText: Considering the roaring success of Scotland's national opera and ballet companies (combined deficit last year: somewhere north of £1.5m), it is only natural that this newly devolved nation should hanker after a national theatre too. Arts institutions are like Pokémon cards: every country wants the complete set.
fields.body:
Considering the roaring success of Scotland's national opera and ballet companies (combined deficit last year: somewhere north of £1.5m), it is only natural that this newly devolved nation should hanker after a national theatre too. Arts institutions are like Pokémon cards: every country wants the complete set.

Until recently only Nationalists of the Alex Salmond persuasion would lobby openly for a national theatre, while theatre pros were reluctant to back the idea on the record in case it seemed they were applying for the job of director. Here's the Royal Lyceum's artistic director, Kenny Ireland, back in 1997: "I have no interest in running the Scottish National Theatre."

But things change, and there is the whiff of opportunity in the air as the Scottish Executive tries to establish its pro-culture credentials. Anyone who is anyone in Scottish theatre showed up to a meeting at the Lyceum at the weekend to discuss the new plan, with the fragrant Siobhan Redmond chairing proceedings from the set of A Doll's House. "This is the closest I'll ever come to playing Nora," she quipped, which must be an Ibsen in-joke.

As one sceptic pointed out, Scotland already has shares in a national theatre - the British national theatre, which sits on London's South Bank. But up here everyone knows that it is really as English as Morris dancing.

Now don't run away with the idea that a Scottish national theatre might have stalls, a stage and a crush bar. Oh no. This theatre will be rather more conceptual, and it's only tangible embodiment is likely to be a bus, which would take top-drawer theatre to Scotland's more remote regions. This would be a company of no fixed address, drawing on the combined talents of Scotland's theatre folk under the control of what is described as "a mover and shaker".

Ireland, the undisputed heavyweight champion of Scottish theatre, can move and shake with the best of 'em but it's not clear if his hat is in the ring. Whoever does get the job would also need that key managerial skill of bangin' heids together. A national theatre made up of every theatre company in the nation sounds like a turf-war waiting to happen.

Back on the streets, where the brows are somewhat lower, the Pleasance has been having a laugh. In the movie business they call it "standee-jacking". A standee is one of those lifesize cut-outs of movie stars used to promote the latest Hollywood blockbuster in cinema foyers. In Edinburgh at this time of year, Nicholas Parsons rates as A-list and the standee to advertise his live chat show was duly jacked. An anonymous call was received and at the agreed hostage drop, Parsons was returned along with a collection of photos taken during his AWOL day on the town. He looked particularly fetching in one of those tartan bunnets with integral ginger wig beloved of the Tartan Army. Ah, the first publicity stunt of August...

This diary won't all be filth, we promise, but it's as well to get it out of the system early. And there is no finer filth in Edinburgh than a show called Sodom, which was dashed off by the Earl of Rochester, circa 1670. Due to its extreme profanity and hardcore stage directions, there is no record of this play having been performed in public. Until now. Naturally the Diary was ringside for this historic occasion, which featured simulated "swiving" and "quiddling of the cods". No fish were harmed. Our favourite couplet went something like this: "They say he swives women into a trance/So will you when you see his lance."

The Dairy is no scholar of Restoration comedy, but could it be that no one has staged this play because it's not very good? Strictly for public-school boys and textual analysts.

webTitle: Treeless hills send torrents into india

fields.headline: Treeless hills send torrents into india
fields.trailText: More than 100 people have been killed and 2m left homeless by floods and landslides in north-eastern India and Bhutan during the weekend.
fields.body:
More than 100 people have been killed and 2m left homeless by floods and landslides in north-eastern India and Bhutan during the weekend.

Scientists say the extent of the flooding that has accompanied the monsoon season - which began two months ago - can be partly explained by the massive deforestation of hill areas across south Asia.

Bangladesh and Nepal have also suffered. In Nepal more than 100 people are missing as a result of the floods and hundreds of hectares of farm land has been washed away.

The army has been called in to help in Bhutan, where 87 people have died in landslides since late on Friday. Officials said a 40-mile area was affected, between Chukha and Kharbanda township in the south of the small country. Road links to the capital, Thimphu, have been severed and power lines washed away.

Troops in the Indian states of Assam and West Bengal have mounted a massive rescue operation in their areas after the floods, which were caused by monsoon rains.

Assam was last night cut off from the rest of the country with main roads and railways submerged. The rising waters of the Brahmaputra river have flooded more than 2,000 villages; thousands of stranded people were rescued over the weekend by soldiers. Many others are still missing.

Air force helicopters were reported to have made more than two dozen sorties to drop food to those who remain cut off.

Two express trains due to return to Delhi last Thursday were instead stranded in Assam's capital, Guwahati, waiting for railway authorities so to restore damaged tracks.

Refugees are camping by the roadside. "Thousands have set up temporary homes along the highway," one rescue worker said last night.

Floods have also caused great destruction in Bihar, India's poorest and most chaotic state, where nearly 1m people spread over hundreds of villages have been affected.

Reports suggest crops worth £1.25m have been damaged by the floods and some 3,000 houses destroyed. Boats with divers have been deployed to the area while 30 tonnes of rice has been dropped by helicopter.

The most recent floods come only a week after a northern Indian state, Himachal Pradesh, was hit by its worst ever floods. One hundred people died after the Sutlej river, which flows through a gorge, rose 12 metres (40ft) in a matter of minutes. Dozens of bridges were washed away and villages submerged in a sudden and furious torrent.

The state's chief minister, Prem Kumar Dhunal, last night blamed China for the floods, which he said were caused by the unprecedented rise of a lake in neighbouring Tibet.

He demanded that the central government give £160m in relief. Among those who died was a man in the village of Romtak, Karam Dass,who had rescued a neighbour only to be carried away by the water himself. His wife and his daughter died too.

webTitle: Arms seizure raises fears of dissident attacks

fields.headline: Arms seizure raises fears of dissident attacks
fields.trailText: Arms and ammunition seized in Northern Ireland last night were connected to dissident republicans opposed to the Good Friday agreement, it is now believed.
fields.body:
Arms and ammunition seized in Northern Ireland last night were connected to dissident republicans opposed to the Good Friday agreement, it is now believed.

One man was arrested by the RUC after a security operation on the M1 motorway in Northern Ireland last night, in which detonators, ammunition, a submachine gun and a sawn-off shotgun were recovered.

The weapons were found in a Vauxhall Cavalier car heading towards Belfast. During the operation, police closed part of the M1 at Sprucefield Junction.

Ulster Democratic Party leader Gary McMichael said: "I am concerned that dissidents are moving weapons from the border areas into the city and fear that they intend to mount attacks on Belfast in the future."

The find suggested that dissident republican terrorists were planning to carry out attacks in Belfast, he claimed.

It was vital that security forces continued to concentrate on eliminating the threat posed by the renegades, added Mr McMichael, whose party has links with the outlawed Ulster Freedom Fighters and Ulster Defence Association.

The find comes at the height of Northern Ireland's marching season, and was followed today by the parades commission's decision to delay a ruling on whether the disputed Apprentice Boys march on Belfast's Lower Ormeau Road can go ahead.

Nationalists on the lower Ormeau Road objected to the "feeder" march by several dozen Apprentice Boys, which was to be followed on Saturday by a large march in Belfast. An announcement will now not be made before Wednesday.

fields.headline: Poker, Racing and Gaming
fields.trailText: CRIME DOES PAY
fields.body:
CRIME DOES PAY

Last Friday, cunning Arsene Wenger faxed a take-it-or-leave it offer to Bordeaux for their striker Sylvian Wiltord. And that offer - £7.36m, £8m or £13m depending on which educated guess you chose to believe - came with a strict deadline. Give us Wiltord by Monday, said a poker-faced Wenger, otherwise we'll send Pat Rice to fiddle with your vineyards. And the deal will be off.

And who says crime (or at least hard-nose bargaining) doesn't pay? Because according to today's London Evening Standard, Arsenal "look certain" to complete Wiltord's transfer this week, with the paper claiming that "talks have continued and the belief at Highbury is that the French club will accept an offer of £10.5m." But are things that clear cut? Remember it's the French we're dealing with here, and the Fiver - who, along with its trusty white van, is a veritable veteran of the Dover to Calais early-morning fags run - knows that you're never safe until you've got the contraband back, safe and sound in Good Ol' Blighty.

And what do you know? Despite Arsenal's optimism, Bordeaux chairman Jean-Louis Triaud today told L'Equipe that the deal is far from certain, because he wants to buy a replacement for Wiltord before selling him. "We are looking for a new player, a forward. But we don't want anyone," he said moodily. What kind of player are Bordeaux looking for then? "In front of goal, we need a killer," chirped in Bordeaux coach Elie Baup. Well, we've got 800 Gitanes in the back of our van, but you can't play those up front. Can you?
