A KOOGAN AT THE RACES

We haven't heard much from Kelvin Koogan since E*** 2***. The Fiver wondered what he was up to. Perhaps he was touring around the continent learning from the coaching styles of his peers. Perhaps he's been locked away in his garden shed seeking forgiveness and coming up with some new ways of keeping possession. Or perhaps he's been idling around, learning nothing, and only raising his head to, well, gee up a few horses.

Koogan was at Ascot today to do some publicity for the Blue Square Shergar Cup (a horsey version of the Ryder Cup). Koogan will be coaching the European team, and he used today's photo opportunity to draw some parallels between racing and unsuccessful football management. "If you fall short of your goal you've got to learn lessons. We fell short in Euro 2000, that's a fact, but we know we're better than that," Koogan said. "It's a bit like a horse who ran below par. We can blame the going, we can blame the track or we can blame the jockey, but I'm always reluctant to do that." Particularly seeing that the jockey in this analogy is Koog himself.

So it seems that while he is desperate to learn lessons, Koogan doesn't want to take any of those on offer, and is more likely to sign up for another OU course in motivational psychology. This does not bode well for England's friendly with double-winners France next month, but Koog doesn't seem to be bothered - what with the geegees in close proximity. "I'm looking forward to a win to boost me before I pick the England squad," he said, clutching a wad of betting slips. "It's a long time since I lifted a trophy but I'm confident we have the horses and jockeys to win on Saturday." So that'll be an easy win for the States, then.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"They should put up or shut up. If they are still waiting for a response to their bid, then they have already had it - we are not interested. We have something they want. We do not particularly want to sell. They should either pay what Ugo Ehiogu is worth or go away and keep quiet" -Is there any club (or player, come to think of it) that John Gregory hasn't offended yet? Today it's Manchester City's turn.

MEDAL MEDDLE

It's that time of the year again. Yes, it's the beginning of the 364-day period when a row between Leeds United and Soccer Australia could kick off at any moment. And sure enough, here's a new one (number 15,785 for those of you counting): Harry Kewell has announced that he wants to play for Australia in the Olympics next month. Yes, even if that means he'll miss the early stages of the Worthington Cup.

"Those know-alls who have written me off for the Olympics are way off-beam," wrote a patriotic Kewell in his Sydney Sunday Telegraph column. "I always love playing for my country - for Australia - and it's very important for me to also play at home in the Sydney Olympics," the player who, along with Mark Viduka, is likely to leave for a pre-Olympics training camp the day after Leeds kick off their season against Everton on August 19th. "I would like to play but as yet I haven't discussed it with [David O'Leary O'Leeds]," Kewell said, as if O'Leeds's opinion would make the slightest bit of difference.

All this Antipodean activity will mean Leeds doing without two of their biggest stars for up to six weeks (the Olympics don't finish until the beginning of October). Which is tough. But at least Leeds haven't also been knocked back once again in their bid to sign Rio Ferdinand. Oh, hang on. "I don't want Rio to go to Leeds," Harry Redknapp told London's Evening Standard today, "but if a club like Barcelona came in it might be different." Who needs former colonies when you can have a good old bitch-up at home?

THE RUMOUR MILL

Marcelo Salas is tempted by a move to Manchester United. "If Mr Ferguson wants to come and talk, I will be happy to consider what he has to say," Lazio's Chilean striker said today.

Newcastle will not accept bids of less than £7m for Duncan Ferguson, according to reports. Everton are still interested in re-signing their former captain, but Newcastle do not want to be seen to take a sizeable loss on a player they signed for £8m last year.

Egil Ostenstad's time at Blackburn looks like coming to an end, and Coventry could be his next destination. Rovers boss Graeme Souness said today that the Norwegian striker is not part of his plans, and the former Southampton striker has been earmarked by Gordon Strachan as a replacement for Robbie Keane.

Roma could be set to sell Japanese phenomenon Hideotoshi Nakata to Lens only 8 months after they bought him for £11m. The midfielder is said to have scheduled talks with the Lens board this week.

NEWS IN BRIEF

fields.bodyText: CRIME DOES PAY Last Friday, cunning Arsene Wenger faxed a take-it-or-leave it offer to Bordeaux for their striker Sylvian Wiltord. And that offer - £7.36m, £8m or £13m depending on which educated guess you chose to believe - came with a strict deadline. Give us Wiltord by Monday, said a poker-faced Wenger, otherwise we'll send Pat Rice to fiddle with your vineyards. And the deal will be off. And who says crime (or at least hard-nose bargaining) doesn't pay? Because according to today's London Evening Standard, Arsenal "look certain" to complete Wiltord's transfer this week, with the paper claiming that "talks have continued and the belief at Highbury is that the French club will accept an offer of £10.5m." But are things that clear cut? Remember it's the French we're dealing with here, and the Fiver - who, along with its trusty white van, is a veritable veteran of the Dover to Calais early-morning fags run - knows that you're never safe until you've got the contraband back, safe and sound in Good Ol' Blighty. And what do you know? Despite Arsenal's optimism, Bordeaux chairman Jean-Louis Triaud today told L'Equipe that the deal is far from certain, because he wants to buy a replacement for Wiltord before selling him. "We are looking for a new player, a forward. But we don't want anyone," he said moodily. What kind of player are Bordeaux looking for then? "In front of goal, we need a killer," chirped in Bordeaux coach Elie Baup. Well, we've got 800 Gitanes in the back of our van, but you can't play those up front. Can you? Register for free at http://www.sky.com/games/fantasia2000/guardian A KOOGAN AT THE RACES We haven't heard much from Kelvin Koogan since E*** 2***. The Fiver wondered what he was up to. Perhaps he was touring around the continent learning from the coaching styles of his peers. Perhaps he's been locked away in his garden shed seeking forgiveness and coming up with some new ways of keeping possession. Or perhaps he's been idling around, learning nothing, and only raising his head to, well, gee up a few horses. Koogan was at Ascot today to do some publicity for the Blue Square Shergar Cup (a horsey version of the Ryder Cup). Koogan will be coaching the European team, and he used today's photo opportunity to draw some parallels between racing and unsuccessful football management. "If you fall short of your goal you've got to learn lessons. We fell short in Euro 2000, that's a fact, but we know we're better than that," Koogan said. "It's a bit like a horse who ran below par. We can blame the going, we can blame the track or we can blame the jockey, but I'm always reluctant to do that." Particularly seeing that the jockey in this analogy is Koog himself. So it seems that while he is desperate to learn lessons, Koogan doesn't want to take any of those on offer, and is more likely to sign up for another OU course in motivational psychology. This does not bode well for England's friendly with double-winners France next month, but Koog doesn't seem to be bothered - what with the geegees in close proximity. "I'm looking forward to a win to boost me before I pick the England squad," he said, clutching a wad of betting slips. "It's a long time since I lifted a trophy but I'm confident we have the horses and jockeys to win on Saturday." So that'll be an easy win for the States, then. webTitle: Bradford set to announce secret signing

fields.headline: Bradford set to announce secret signing
fields.trailText: Bradford have announced they expect to make "the most exciting signing in the history of the club" tomorrow - and controversial Italian Benito Carbone is the favourite to be unveiled.
fields.body:
Bradford have announced they expect to make "the most exciting signing in the history of the club" tomorrow - and controversial Italian Benito Carbone is the favourite to be unveiled.

According to the club website terms have been agreed "with a new striker who is set to put pen to paper tomorrow evening when he signs his contract at a secret destination."

The website doesn't say who the player is, but Carbone - who is without a club after refusing to return to Aston Villa at the end of last season - seems to fit the bill.

Manager Chris Hutchings told the club's website: "The signing will raise a few eyebrows in the world of football."

And chairman Geoffrey Richmond added: "I believe that it will be seen by supporters as the most exciting signing in the history of the club. However like all transfers at this stage there is always the possibility that things can go wrong."

The Yorkshire club expect to unveil their new signing at a Valley Parade press conference on Thursday morning at 11am.

The signing will be some solace after Bradford failed to steal Paulo Wanchope from under the noses of Manchester City. The Costa Rican international today completed a £3.65m move to Maine Road.

webTitle: Sucking up to the digital dregs

fields.headline: Sucking up to the digital dregs
fields.standfirst: College students are among the most wired of all groups. On many US campuses, 100% of students (and faculty staff) have net access - if not via their own PCs, then through campus computer labs and libraries. By Steve Outing
fields.trailText: College students are among the most wired of all groups. On many US campuses, 100% of students (and faculty staff) have net access - if not via their own PCs, then through campus computer labs and libraries. By Steve Outing
fields.body:
College students are among the most wired of all groups. On many US campuses, 100% of students (and faculty staff) have net access - if not via their own PCs, then through campus computer labs and libraries. Online penetration in universities far exceeds that of the general US population.

Yet websites serving campuses have, until recently, been pretty dull. Sites run by colleges themselves - featuring class descriptions, student directories, etc - have been largely utilitarian, lacking the pizzazz of commercial sites. The websites of campus newspapers, meanwhile, have offered little more than "shovelware" - articles and content copied from the print edition. It's a rare college newspaper that has the resources to be at the leading edge of online publishing.

This is all changing. American colleges are getting flashy websites featuring the latest in internet technology, as the dot.com industry figures out ways to "monetise" students by creating local websites to serve them. Three types of site are emerging to serve individual college and university campuses:

1) The campus newspaper's portal. While many internet-savvy journalism students would no doubt love to build state-of-the-art online newspapers, a simple lack of resources has prevented this on most campuses. But Campus-Engine.com, a California-based company, is riding to the rescue with a plan to turn campus newspaper websites into local "portal" sites, leveraging the content of local papers and adding slick new features and services.

The company, which was founded late last year and already has deals with 71 college newspapers, provides sophisticated web publishing tools and services that the small, typically independently run papers couldn't afford on their own. A CampusEngine-powered newspaper site offers such services as free web email (similar to hotmail), an auction service that students can use to sell textbooks, and community publishing tools to allow student groups to self-publish on the web.

All this costs the newspapers nothing up front - just a negotiated share of advertising revenues brought into the campus portal. CampusEngine's strategy is to sell national advertising to an aggregated audience of students. CEO Jack Crawford says that the campus-paper deals represent a reach of 1.5m students so far.

2) The school-sponsored commercial portal. The competition for the campus-newspaper portals will come from school-run portal sites operated by commercial entities on the schools' behalf. Typical of this model is a new company called zUniversity.com, based in Connecticut. zUniversity creates commercial campus portal sites that are affiliated with the schools. In effect, they become the commercial arm of public institutions.

Where typical .edu websites are basically intranets serving staff and students, the zUniversity sites can provide a variety of services - entertainment listings, or online ticketing for off-campus events. Schools retain their .edu sites, but users are referred to the zUniversity portal for commercial services.

While "z" sites have the school partners as sources of official news and information, they don't have the advantage of a student newspaper, which generates local news and event listings (most US college newspapers are independent of the school administration). zUniversity operates a small "field operation" on each affiliate campus, with an editorial correspondent and interns providing local content for the portal site.

zUniversity is also aiming its sites at ex-students. By affiliating with alumni associations as well as the schools themselves it hopes to keep its users coming back for life. And, like CampusEngine, zUniversity aims to make much of its money from selling national advertising across its network of college sites. (zUniversity's CEO was a founder of web advertising titan Doubleclick.)

3) Taking .edu sites to the next level. The final category involves taking the existing .edu website, supercharging it with the latest technology, and paying for it with advertising. This approach is represented by companies like Campus Pipeline. The Campus Pipeline platform integrates with a school's databases, providing web features such as online registration for classes, web-based email, and online academic results.

The one hitch in this model is that these handy hi-tech features don't come cheap. Currently, schools are either paying for the technology themselves, or allowing advertising on their websites to pay for it - which doesn't always sit well with academic constituencies.

For students, all this campus web activity means lots of online choice. Not only are .edu sites improving the services they provide, but commercial entities are offering a tremendous amount of local content and services. Students are going from the digital dregs to a digital cornucopia as .edu joins forces with .com.

webTitle: The new economy's explosion into print

fields.headline: Boom time for dead wood
fields.standfirst: If you reckoned print was on the way out in the new economy - think again. David Rowan reports on the expanding market for periodicals dealing with business on the web
fields.trailText: If you reckoned print was on the way out in the new economy - think again. David Rowan reports on the expanding market for periodicals dealing with business on the web.
fields.body:
Here's some bad news if you like to keep up with the new economy: your reading list is about to get even longer. You won't merely need to catch the monthly print editions of Red Herring (482 pages in a typical issue), Fast Company (404 pages), Business 2.0 (410) or Upside (290) - not forgetting Wired (merely 266), and weeklies such as the Industry Standard, Revolution and New Media Age. Prepare now for the next global burst of internet brands - a raft of new local editions of established magazines. If you're lucky, you'll get through August's editions by December.

Future Publishing has just imported Business 2.0 from Brisbane, California, in a slimmed-down localised UK edition, soon to be followed by German, French and Italian versions. Haymarket's Revolution is about to launch a Hong Kong edition, only months after entering the US market. And, in an ambitious global expansion that is causing some twitching among local competitors, San Francisco's Industry Standard - a trade title that happened last year to sell more display-ad pages than People magazine - is about to launch a pan-European edition from London, as well as a series of local-language versions from Scandinavia to South Korea.

"The new economy is both an American and a local story," explains Michael Parsons, London-based editorial director of the Industry Standard Europe. "This is all about the flow of investment into the tech sector. A lot of money is now coming into the European theatre, and people here are desperately hungry for information about where the deals are, where the money is going. That interest won't go away as the American money won't go away."

Parsons has been with the Standard since its launch in April 1998 as a mere 64-pager; today the issue size has to be capped at 365 ad-crammed pages "as the printer can't cope". He is busy recruiting big names in net journalism for an October launch: Mike Butcher from New Media Age, Chris Nuttall from the BBC and Georgia Cameron-Clarke from the Telegraph will be among 25 journalists working on the European edition under editor James Ledbetter. Up to half of the magazine will comprise material from the US edition, allowing access to the material produced by 130 people in the US. "The success of First Tuesday shows there's clearly a tremendous interest at a grassroots level about what people can do in their own markets," says Parsons. "We will be a bridge between the experience of the US entrepreneurial and investment community and the rest of Europe. UK web companies are thinking of themselves as European - everything else is provincial."

Several US net magazines have long been cult items among UK net entrepreneurs, offering the lessons - lately, the mistakes - of west coast start-ups, and hundreds of pages of intimidating advertising from financial institutions boasting of $2bn mergers and follow-on offerings. Comag, the UK's largest magazine importer, now handles 20 internet magazines among its 500 titles. It estimates the internet magazine sector's annual market value at about £11m - compared with £5.6m in March 1999. "Generally when there is a UK edition we stop importing the US edition as they compete with each other," says Sarah Marshall of Comag. "The arrival of a local edition is a sign that the market is picking up for that sector."

And picking up it is. Research from Future Publishing points to increasing demand for tech-market coverage in the UK - led by advertisers as well as subscribers. "The American market is clearly important in this sector because of the development of new technology, but the European market is becoming important in its own right," says Jessica Burley, publishing director of Future Publishing's business and internet group, whose titles include Business 2.0, .net and PCPlus. Despite the downturn of tech stocks, venture capital continues to move into Europe in the quest for that successful business model. And that means booming advertising for what Burley calls "indigenous-facing" magazines as start-ups - and the banks and software firms seeking their business - try to make noise in their local marketplace.

Business 2.0 currently claims a US circulation of 270,000. Future Publishing is guaranteeing advertisers 50,000 for the UK edition's first ABC, and is planning Italian, French and German launches later this year. "You'll see us roll out the brand into large countries around the world," says Burley. Britain, she says, is currently "an emerging market" with its own needs. UK consumers may not favour the "fat books" of the US titles but we do apparently demand specific coverage of web businesses where Europe appears to be leading the US, notably in mobile technologies.

There are clearly risks in localising titles that earned their reputations in the US, where the new economy is still generally held to be months, if not a year, ahead of Britain. The UK version of Wired, backed by the Guardian, folded after what some said was its premature arrival in a market where not enough of note was happening.

"One of the reasons people buy American magazines is to see what's happening in America - but the number of these people is quite small," says Richard Lord, editor of Revolution. "To make a publication succeed in the UK, you need to strike a balance between this and mass-market demands." Revolution has recently taken this publishing trend from the other direction: selling its knowledge of the European market to US consumers. Its solution has been to go "micro-niche" - focusing purely on internet marketing. An early lesson Revolution learned in New York was that design templates do not travel: "Americans can't stand sans serif body faces, so they had to go, and we had to increase the leading to improve readability."

Lord believes Business 2.0 has "made an admirable attempt to localise itself" with its UK edition, and is not too bothered about the competition. "There is a market for us all as long as we realise what we're good at and focus. Red Herring is serving an audience that cares about the financing of companies." Besides, Lord notes, there is no sign of a slowdown in the ad market: "We grew in six months to take weekly what we had taken monthly."

Keeping up as a reader, however, offers a broader challenge. "It's simply impossible to read through all this stuff," says Mike Nutley, editor of New Media Age - a mere 76 pages this week. "People value NMA because it's a quick read. Who wants telephone-directory-sized magazines?"

 David Rowan is editor of Guardian Unlimited

"One of the reasons people buy American magazines is to see what's happening in America - but the number of these people is quite small," says Richard Lord, editor of Revolution. "To make a publication succeed in the UK, you need to strike a balance between this and mass-market demands." Revolution has recently taken this publishing trend from the other direction: selling its knowledge of the European market to US consumers. Its solution has been to go "micro-niche" - focusing purely on internet marketing. An early lesson Revolution learned in New York was that design templates do not travel: "Americans can't stand sans serif body faces, so they had to go, and we had to increase the leading to improve readability." Lord believes Business 2.0 has "made an admirable attempt to localise itself" with its UK edition, and is not too bothered about the competition. "There is a market for us all as long as we realise what we're good at and focus. Red Herring is serving an audience that cares about the financing of companies." Besides, Lord notes, there is no sign of a slowdown in the ad market: "We grew in six months to take weekly what we had taken monthly." Keeping up as a reader, however, offers a broader challenge. "It's simply impossible to read through all this stuff," says Mike Nutley, editor of New Media Age - a mere 76 pages this week. "People value NMA because it's a quick read. Who wants telephone-directory-sized magazines?"  David Rowan is editor of Guardian Unlimited

webTitle: The BBC is totally rethinking its ad campaigns

fields.headline: No more soft focus
fields.standfirst:
The BBC is totally rethinking its ad campaigns.

Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: The BBC is totally rethinking its ad campaigns. Belinda Archer reports.
fields.body:
Three years ago the BBC set TVs aglow with an extravagant promotional spectacular, the much-celebrated Perfect Day video. The four-minute film starred a glittering cast, from Tom Jones to Elton John, each crooning a segment from the famous Lou Reed track which was then patchworked into a whole. It was dubbed one of 1997's most beautifully crafted "commercials", and possibly the creative highlight of the year by ad industry bible Campaign magazine.

More importantly, the video was a departure for BBC marketing, the first in a number of lavish, big-budget, generic films promoting sections of its TV and radio - from sports to comedy to education, news, children's programming and music.

Then last week, it emerged that the BBC is abandoning the strategy. It is plotting a radical shift in the way it promotes programmes and services, ditching such corporate blockbusters in favour of targeting individual programmes, as well as specific audience groupings.

Perfect Day and subsequent branding films such as Curiosity (which plugged its natural history output), Shaggy Dog Story (40 stars from the cream of British comedy telling a joke) and Future Generations (in which a five-year-old boy strolled through the history of kids' TV) have gained numerous creative plaudits and been well-respected by the marketing community.

Perfect Day alone won a Gold at Creative Circle in 1998, was a finalist in the corporate image category at Cannes International Advertising Festival and won a silver pencil at D&AD. Future Generations won a silver at D&AD and the BBC overall landed the Marketing Society grand prix of Marketeer of the Year in 1998. So why the comprehensive rethink?

Jane Frost, the former controller of corporate and brand marketing responsible for the videos, says: "We've been running corporate brand campaigns for three or four years and they've been phenomenally successful, but the market changes and our strategy with it. There are more people talking to consumers now and more competitors in the marketplace."

Industry whispers of an impending strategy shift began when director-general Greg Dyke staged a dramatic overhaul of the marketing department in April, which resulted in Sue Farr's departure as marketing director and put Matthew Bannister, former chief executive of BBC production and controller of Radio 1, in the new board position of director of marketing and communications.

Almost a year ago the BBC, for the first time, put responsibility for marketing the BBC brand and its channels and services together under the new banner of BBC public service marketing. Budgeting for the corporate spectaculars began to be pruned, and more was pumped into promoting programmes and channels. Then in February, a review of the BBC's advertising agency roster was announced. Leagas Delaney, its core corporate agency and the creative force behind most of the branding films, was put on alert, alongside its other agencies, the possibility being that the new approach may require less input from external creative sources.

Robert Senior, a managing partner at Fallon, which handles Radio 1, says: "Since Greg and Matthew have come on board, the focus has been on the audience. Everything starts with them and their needs, and works back from that. Inevitably, communications are going to become more rifle-shot against target groups. But there will still be a need for brand footprint work and corporate advertising. They have just turned the telescope round."

The BBC insists the Perfect Day approach was successful. Industry observers claim it was a timely, adroit reminder to the public of the BBC's stature and creativity. Frost adds: "There was a sea change in attitude to the BBC, what it was and what it stands for. It was not intended to drive viewers - it was about 'this is us and this is what you're paying for'."

The films also upped the creative ante, and many of the BBC's commercial rivals have since tweaked their corporate communications tactics and even corporate logos. But there was criticism of the strategy, not least from inside the BBC. "Those films were lovely to watch, but how could their impact on consumers and the BBC's services be quantified? What were consumers doing differently as a result of them? There was also the thought that we couldn't afford that sort of advertising any more," says one insider.

It was certainly a controversial approach: rival stations raged at the blatant commercial exploitation of BBC airtime (the films were each about three minutes long) and stoked licence-payer anger about "abuse" of their cash. Perfect Day was said to have cost around £2m to make and took more than a year to film. The others were said to be similar "chequebook productions".

Either way, the focus is now on what viewers are likely to see in the place of these big branding videos, and when. Punters will still be treated to campaigns promoting individual BBC "services" such as Radio 1 or BBC1, and there will be the usual appointment-to-view trails plugging specific programmes such as Panorama, "coming up at 9pm" or "a week on Tuesday". But what of the new umbrella campaigns?

The full new marketing blueprint is to be unveiled in October, with the rejigged agency roster announced in November and work to follow soon after. It is likely that the new-look campaigns will be "service-specific" (ie to do with one of the radio networks, TV channels or separate programmes) but, crucially, they will be directed at particular segments of the population. "Audience focus" is critical and there will be increased "coherence between campaigns", says the BBC. There might be, for example, a trail aimed at "youth", saying something like, "If you like Radio 1, you'll also like this programme on BBC2".

"It's about thinking laterally across the services and about what a Radio 1 listener might also like within the BBC family. It's about leading them seamlessly from one area to another," says one source.

No doubt there is wisdom in the approach and Bannister and Dyke will hatch a tough, results-oriented strategy. Perhaps the lavish branding work had run out of steam: they'd done comedy, natural history, music and news, so what was left? Some form of broad brush corporate communication will obviously continue, but it seems, to paraphrase the fabled song, we'll just have to keep hanging on for another perfect day.

webTitle: Roy Greenslade: Why is the Sun in the shade?

fields.headline: Why is the Sun in the shade?
fields.trailText: • The nexus between the News of the World and the Mirror in their campaign for Sarah's Law - a public register of convicted paedophiles - was unprecedented. No Mirror title has ever got so close to a Murdoch paper before.
fields.body:
 The nexus between the News of the World and the Mirror in their campaign for Sarah's Law - a public register of convicted paedophiles - was unprecedented. No Mirror title has ever got so close to a Murdoch paper before.

Though the Mirror stopped short of supporting the NoW's "naming and shaming" exercise, editor Piers Morgan recognised that it played the key role in galvanising public support and provoking the authorities into a debate they had long avoided. So Morgan was happy to take up the cry along with his former colleague, NoW editor Rebekah Wade. Evidence of how they happily coordinated their campaign emerged last week when the parents of murdered Sarah Payne were chauffeur-driven in a News International limousine from Wapping to the Mirror office in Canary Wharf for an interview.

But why did the NoW's stablemate, the Sun, not jump on Wade's bandwagon? Surely it can't have anything to do with editor David Yelland's antipathy towards Wade? There must be many Sun readers wondering why their newspaper shunned the Sarah's Law campaign. Including, presumably, Mr Murdoch.

*It is not in the least bit interesting that the Times's old-fashioned diary is to die. The fact that it will be replaced by "an opinionated column" by Giles Coren is a recognition of the Times belatedly catching up with a rival. Without wishing to doff the cap to my employers (on the other hand, why not?) Guardian readers have long enjoyed the pleasures of a bylined diary. Step forward, Matthew Norman, friend of Mandy, Ali and Mr Tony.

There are also diaries graced with pseudonymous titles which do nothing to conceal their authors' identities, at least from the rest of Fleet Street's cognoscenti. So we know that dear Peter McKay masquerades as the Daily Mail's Ephraim Hardcastle, and that the charming Christopher Silvester wields the knife as Brutus in the Daily Express. Both are noted for offering us plenty of their opinions, though I sometimes wonder whether McKay slips in a thought or two from his editor. (Alan, is that how you wanted it phrased?)

The Daily Telegraph's Peterborough column is always by-lined nowadays, an innovation rightly prompted by its best writer of recent years, Quentin Letts. At the Independent, its Pandora columnists come and go too fast to warrant fame. Perhaps that paper will soon imitate the Times's move into the 21st century.

*Why, as if I didn't know, is everyone being so beastly to Tony Blair about his ban on christening pictures of baby Leo? Here is the dilemma he faces. If he decides to organise photo-calls at various points in the baby's life - christening, first birthday, first tooth - then he will be accused by his press critics of "using" the baby for political ends (not to mention usurping the royal family's role).

On the other hand, if he refuses to allow any pictures of the baby, he is accused of being "absurdly heavy-handed" by censoring "charming photographs", to quote the Mirror. As Edwina Currie said on radio the other evening, Blair is damned if he does and damned if he doesn't. An uncharacteristic piece of pomposity by Alex Chancellor in the Daily Telegraph echoes that point. He argued that "no prime minister would carry his baby in public if he didn't want him photographed". Really Alex! Is he supposed to leave it to his wife? Or a servant?

* What is going to happen to the Express titles? Since United News & Media sold off its television interests to Granada, the future for the Daily and Sunday Express and the Daily Star has been a matter of intense interest, mainly to the journalists who feel they have been left in the dark.

Does chief executive Clive Hollick want them or not? At the company's announcement of its interim results on Friday, the official line was clear. Well, sort of. Hollick said he had "no plans" to sell the papers. It wasn't an unequivocal statement that he won't sell, of course, so I sought out United's public affairs manager, Nigel Main. He repeated the Hollick line and talked of "plans to drive the business forward" and investment in web businesses.

Which brings us to the company's web division, called Xilerate. Express staff haven't taken too kindly to the way in which this internet offshoot has been hived off into a separate division. It hasn't been much fun at the Express for 25 years, and it's even less amusing nowadays.

webTitle: MPs draw up 'third way' for hunting

fields.headline: MPs draw up 'third way' for hunting
fields.trailText: MPs have today launched details of a "third way" out of the vexed issue of foxhunting, aiming to reduce animal welfare concerns while protecting the right to hunt.
fields.body:
MPs have today launched details of a "third way" out of the vexed issue of foxhunting, aiming to reduce animal welfare concerns while protecting the right to hunt.

The cross-party Middle Way Group called for the creation of a new independent hunting authority, which would issue licences for hunting with hounds and enforce a new code of conduct.

The proposals are expected to influence a promised government bill which will lay out the various options for MPs to decide upon, ranging from an outright ban to leaving the present laws untouched.

Under the Middle Way proposals, a national team of inspectors would make spot checks to ensure that the code, designed to protect animal welfare, was being adhered to.

The authority would have the power to punish breaches of the code, including minimum times in which the quarry must be killed, by suspending the licences of offending hunts or individuals and imposing fines of up to £2,000.

Hunting without a licence would be a criminal offence with a maximum penalty of up to six months in jail.

The Middle Way Group, which is jointly chaired by Tory MP Peter Luff, Liberal Democrat Lembit Opik and Labour's Llin Golding, argues that an outright ban would be unenforceable and achieve little in terms of animal welfare, with farmers simply turning to other methods of controlling the fox population which could cause even greater suffering.

Launching their proposals at Westminster today, Mr Opik acknowledged that support for the plan among MPs was limited at the moment, but insisted that it would increase as people studied the arguments in detail. "I feel a genuine dialogue is beginning to open up," he said. "If people are going to be fundamentalist about this issue, appeals about logic and reason will probably fall on stony ground.

"But we found a middle way about Sunday shopping. Perhaps we will find a middle way about this."

However, Labour MP Mike Foster, who has led the parliamentary battle to ban foxhunting, said the proposals did not address the cruelty of the sport.

"The chase is cruel and the manner in which the fox is killed - being torn apart by a pack of dogs - is cruel," he said.

webTitle: Who is Joe Lieberman?

fields.headline: Who is Joe Lieberman?
fields.standfirst: Mark Tran gets the low-down on Al Gore's running mate in the US presidential elections
fields.trailText: Mark Tran gets the low-down on Al Gore's running mate in the US presidential elections
fields.body:
Connecticut senator Joseph Lieberman has been chosen as democrat Al Gore's running mate in the US presidential elections - the first Jewish vice-presidential candidate in American history.

Now in his second term, Mr Lieberman won the biggest upset victory in the country by just 10,000 votes in 1988. Six years later, he made history by winning the biggest landslide victory ever in a Connecticut race for a US senate seat, with a margin of more than 350,000 votes - or 67 per cent of the vote.

He is known chiefly for being one of the first senators to criticise the president, Bill Clinton, for his tryst with former White House intern Monica Lewinsky. "Having criticised Clinton gets him points from the other side," said Howard Reiter, a political science professor at the University of Connecticut.

His colleagues agree. "A lot of problems [vice-president] Gore is having in attracting white men and suburban women come from the connection to the Lewinsky situation," said senator John Breaux of Louisiana. Mr Lieberman's decision to criticise Mr Clinton, a fellow Democrat, opened the floodgates for the Republicans to attack the president, who were previously not quite sure how to proceed on such a delicate matter. In choosing Mr Lieberman, Mr Gore is sending a not-so-subtle message that he is turning his back on his mentor on the issue of character.

Mr Lieberman's denunciation of the president on the senate floor was considered significant as he was seen as a personal friend of Mr Clinton. However, White House aides scoffed at the notion that the two men were close. They did attend Yale law school at the same time and Mr Clinton worked on Mr Lieberman's state senate campaign.

In 1992, Mr Lieberman returned the favour by being the first politician in the north-east to endorse Mr Clinton's presidential bid. But to call the two men friends was a stretch, White House officials said.

In 1998, Mr Lieberman and conservative former education secretary William Bennett began handing out "Silver Sewer awards" to shame producers of sexually explicit and violent films, music, television programmes and video games.

However, in his most recent financial disclosure forms, Mr Lieberman listed holdings of stocks in the broadcasting companies Fox and CBS - two firms awarded Silver Sewer status, leaving him open to the charge of being a hypocrite.

Although he carved a niche for himself as a liberal reformer during his 10 years as a state senator, Mr Lieberman's move to the right gives him appeal among Republican voters and politicians. On social issues, Mr Lieberman is a liberal who votes for abortion rights, gun control and tax increases, but he is more conservative when it comes to issues such as defence spending and family values.

In Connecticut, Mr Lieberman has gained admiration from Republican governor John Rowland, who recently called the senator "a great friend of mine; while endorsing Mr Lieberman's senate rival.

In endorsing his re-election in 1994, the New York Times wrote: "Congress would be a better place if more of his veteran colleagues were as good. In only one term he has influenced the course of federal legislation for the benefit of Connecticut and the nation."

He is the first ever Jewish running mate of a presidential candidate and is a strong supporter of Israel. However, in 1992 he supported F-15 sales to Saudi Arabia. Nathan Diament, director of the institute for public affairs of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations, believes that Mr Lieberman is as much a centrist on Jewish matters as he is politically. "He's not just tolerant, but feels a kinship with traditional and non-traditional Jews alike."

On Israel, Mr Lieberman believes that it its counterproductive for the US to pressure too publicly, a sentiment that will hardly endear him to the Palestinians who think Mr Clinton sided too much with the Israelis in the recent Camp David talks.

When the administration's Middle East policy collapsed at one point and the Jewish leadership fell to bickering, he organised a group of senators to warn Mr Clinton that "public pressure against Israel" would be "a serious mistake - particularly unfair and counterproductive."

Mr Lieberman has said he will vote on legislation and participate in important meetings on the Sabbath - but won't campaign. He skipped one of his state nominating conventions because it was held on the Sabbath.

"This election is a battle for who wins the American middle," Senate minority leader Thomas Daschle said before Mr Gore made his choice. "With the Gore-Lieberman ticket, you see a real opportunity for Democrats to pick it up."

On social issues, Mr Lieberman is a liberal who votes for abortion rights, gun control and tax increases, but he is more conservative when it comes to issues such as defence spending and family values. In Connecticut, Mr Lieberman has gained admiration from Republican governor John Rowland, who recently called the senator "a great friend of mine; while endorsing Mr Lieberman's senate rival. In endorsing his re-election in 1994, the New York Times wrote: "Congress would be a better place if more of his veteran colleagues were as good. In only one term he has influenced the course of federal legislation for the benefit of Connecticut and the nation." He is the first ever Jewish running mate of a presidential candidate and is a strong supporter of Israel. However, in 1992 he supported F-15 sales to Saudi Arabia. Nathan Diament, director of the institute for public affairs of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations, believes that Mr Lieberman is as much a centrist on Jewish matters as he is politically. "He's not just tolerant, but feels a kinship with traditional and non-traditional Jews alike." On Israel, Mr Lieberman believes that it its counterproductive for the US to pressure too publicly, a sentiment that will hardly endear him to the Palestinians who think Mr Clinton sided too much with the Israelis in the recent Camp David talks. When the administration's Middle East policy collapsed at one point and the Jewish leadership fell to bickering, he organised a group of senators to warn Mr Clinton that "public pressure against Israel" would be "a serious mistake - particularly unfair and counterproductive." Mr Lieberman has said he will vote on legislation and participate in important meetings on the Sabbath - but won't campaign. He skipped one of his state nominating conventions because it was held on the Sabbath. "This election is a battle for who wins the American middle," Senate minority leader Thomas Daschle said before Mr Gore made his choice. "With the Gore-Lieberman ticket, you see a real opportunity for Democrats to pick it up." webTitle: Young City lawyers pay price for salary rise

fields.headline: Young City lawyers pay price for salary rise
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Law firms in London are increasing the salaries of their first year associates by as much as 30% to stop poaching by Wall Street firms and dot.com start-ups.
fields.body:
Law firms in London are increasing the salaries of their first year associates by as much as 30% to stop poaching by Wall Street firms and dot.com start-ups.

Recruits to elite law firms can command salaries of £35,000 to £40,000, but there is concern in the profession about the welfare of young lawyers, as employers demand higher returns to recoup the higher pay. The drop-out rate after two years in the job has increased dramatically, while a helpline set up by the Law Society's young solicitors group has recorded a significant increase in callers complaining of stress and being unable to cope.

One City law firm has installed sleeping cubicles so that staff can work through the night, while others have onsite medical and dental facilities so staff do not have to leave the office. "If you wanted to, you could stay here 24 hours a day," one recruit said.

Sara Chandler, who chairs the young solicitors group, said that it was time big City firms addressed overworking. "Firms are failing to regard their young solicitors as an asset that might get worn out. Remuneration is not the only aspect of their employment package," she said.

The bottom line is billing targets: the hours per day a lawyer charges clients for work done on their accounts. To be profitable, solicitors have to bill up to three times their salary to also cover overheads, and as a result of the rises firms demand more billable hours a week than ever.

A young associate at one of London's "magic circle" firms advised any graduate thinking of taking up the profession to read John Grisham's novel, The Firm, to get an idea of the working conditions. "The hours are ferocious," she said. "You hear about it before you start and think 'I can handle it', but it really doesn't prepare you for the reality. Higher salaries have increased the harshness of the regime. If you don't hit targets your job security is much less, and you're more likely to find yourself hauled before a partner. It's not the cosy world it used to be."

The rises are a response both to US law firms and to staff joining dot.coms. According to the Law Gazette, the start was made by Gunderson Dettmer Stough Villeneuve Franklin and Hachi, a small law firm in California's silicon valley which raised first year associates' basic to $125,000 (£83,000). The rest of silicon valley followed suit, and in weeks the revolution had spread to New York; these firms also raised salaries in their London offices, initially paying a "mid-Atlantic rate".

A survey of 30 US law firms in the City found that newly qualified solicitors could earn up to £102,000 plus bonuses. In response English firms joined the bandwagon. Clifford Chance was the first, offering first year assistant solicitors an unprecedented £42,000 base salary plus bonuses.

But there is a penalty. A partner at one top firm said: "It is turning them into wage slaves in the marxist sense. They thrive and get the money or, because the performance pressure is jacked up, they may get kicked out."

webTitle: In brief and the latest casting news

fields.headline: In brief and the latest casting news
fields.standfirst: Frears's fans, Demi Moore eyes music move, Deneuve could be going back to her roots, and animal magic for Rob Schneider
fields.trailText: Frears's fans, Demi Moore eyes music move, Deneuve could be going back to her roots, and animal magic for Rob Schneider
fields.body:
 George Clooney, Dustin Hoffman and John Cusack are expected to be among the star-studded audience at a tribute to British director Stephen Frears (pictured) at this year's Toronto Film Festival. The Leicester-born director whose hits include My Beautiful Launderette, Dangerous Liaisons and High Fidelity, will also premiere his new film, Liam - a gritty portrayal of a family in Liverpool in the 1930s - at the festival.

 Demi Moore is attempting to revive her flagging career with a move into the music business, according to IMDb News. Apparently she has been in secret talks with Sony Music chairman, Tommy Mottola, and is hoping to emulate the success of Jennifer Lopez's pop career. At the height of her success, the 37-year-old Moore used to be able to command a hefty $13m a film, but nowadays it's more likely to be a paltry $1.5m.

 Catherine Deneuve looks set to star with Gary Oldman, Mena Suvari and Nick Moran in an independent film based on D'Artagnan, the fourth muskateer. Director Peter Hyams should begin shooting this month in Belgium, Luxembourg and France. Deneuve, who co-starred in the 2000 Palme d'Or winner Dancer in the Dark, would portray the queen of France.

 Rob Schneider - most recently seen in Deuce Bigalow: Male Gigolo - is to play a man whose internal organs have been replaced by those of various animals in his next film Animal, due for release in 2001, The script co-written by Schneider and Tom Brady, will be produced by Adam Sandler.

webTitle: A battle over a domain name

fields.headline: A battle over a domain name
fields.standfirst: When Katie started getting emails from strangers revealing details of sexual abuse, she knew something was up
fields.trailText: Katie Tarbox, a young American writer, has been making headlines since May, when her autobiographical book, Katie.com, the story of her seduction by an online paedophile, was published in the US. The book is touted by her publishers as: "An honest, eye-opening account of a young woman who was bitterly betrayed by the information age."
fields.body:
Katie Tarbox, a young American writer, has been making headlines since May, when her autobiographical book, Katie.com, the story of her seduction by an online paedophile, was published in the US. The book is touted by her publishers as: "An honest, eye-opening account of a young woman who was bitterly betrayed by the information age."

But another Katie, this time a Londoner, is feeling bitterly betrayed by Penguin, the book's US publishers. Katie Jones, 28, owns the internet address Katie.com, which since May has been inundated with a flood of attention thanks to Tarbox's book. The victim of an unfortunate case of electronic mistaken identity, she is also the proprietor of UKChat.com, one of the most popular independent chat sites in Britain, generating some 40,000 visitors a day.

The book describes in graphic detail how Tarbox met a 41-year-old serial sex offender in an internet chat room, and later met up with him in a Texas hotel room, where he molested her. Penguin's publicity machine won Tarbox a review of the "cautionary memoir" in People magazine. The New York Times called it "a testament to the wonders of the modern adolescent". CNN called Tarbox on to discuss the dangers of "cyber-predators". And America's grande dame of morning talk show hosts, Katie Couric of NBC's Today Show, advised parents and teenagers alike to use the book as a guide of what not to do on the internet.

In the space of a single day, Jones' personal website had more than 100,000 visitors, and the south London internet entrepreneur started to get emails from hundreds of Tarbox sympathisers, sharing their own experiences of molestation and rape. Jones, who managed chat services for MSN and AOL before leaving to start her own online chat company in 1998, is worried that the stigma of paedophilia and chat-room abuse addressed in the book will seep over from her personal site into her business activities.

"Lots of people know me as Katie Jones, online community person, and I'm known in this industry as the person who owns and runs UK Chat. Now the domain name is always going to be associated with this book," she says. "It's not mine any more, it's theirs, and they didn't even ask me if they could have it."

Single-name domains such as Katie.com or Bob.com are increasingly valuable as good, simple web addresses are becoming more difficult to get hold of. Bob.com was recently valued at more than $1m.

Katie.com used to house Jones' personal CV, pictures of her young son, and a link to her professional site, UKChat.com. But with the release of the American book, with its disturbing subject matter, Jones has closed the site indefinitely. "I started getting emails from people wondering if I was [the subject of the book]," she says. "The site was attracting the wrong kind of attention from the wrong kind of people."

Jones, through a US lawyer, contacted the book's publishers to inform them of her prior rights on the name Katie.com, but says the only response was a stiff reply insisting that she had no legal leg to stand on.

This isn't the first time that two parties have squabbled over a domain name, but Jones' case is unique in one aspect. There are countless numbers of cyber-squatters who have registered domain names of large companies, and tried to extort large fees from the companies in exchange for relinquishing the names. A whole body of law now addresses the rights of companies to extend their trademark to web addresses. But no one has yet tested the right of web address owners to extend their trademark to other offline media.

In November 1999, the US congress passed the Anti-Cybersquatting Consumer Protection Act, which gave companies recourse against misuse of their trademarks in internet domain names. It expanded previous trademark law in the US, giving better protection against domain name piracy. The trouble for Katie Jones? For starters, Britain doesn't have the same expanded protection against cyber-squatters, and her use of Katie.com isn't a trademark, but for personal use. She is fighting Penguin on the grounds that her privacy has been invaded, rather than trademark infringement.

"It's a grey area of the law. There's no precedent for this," she says. "This is a test case. You don't want to be a test case. It's a horrible thing, but this is an issue that needs addressing."

Lawyers specialising in internet law say that while Penguin's move may not have been illegal under current law, in today's world, it was certainly clumsy. There's a certain naivety in publishing a book about the internet, with a web address in the title, and publicising the book online (from the website www.KatieT.com), and making no attempt to buy or secure the logical domain name. "Why would naming the book KatieT.com devalue it in any way?" Jones asks.

Tarbox's editor, Laurie Chittenden, was au fait with the etiquette and practice of online chat rooms. In 1997 as an assistant editor at Simon & Schuster, she hosted monthly, hour-long chat sessions on AOL called "Ask the Editor."

In one notable session, she met a young author, Franklin White, and later signed him to a six-figure, two-book deal. Chittenden told Publisher's Weekly that the online world is a good place to spot trends. "To be on AOL and the internet, you're on the cutting edge of the ideas that are being transferred back and forth," she said. "Years ago, you had the Parisian salons where people discussed philosophy and literature, and I see online newsgroups and chat forums as similar to this."

Chittenden, Penguin, and Orion, the book's British distributors, did not respond to requests for comment, but it appears the book's name was changed between when the publisher bought rights to the book, and when it was published. In early publicity, the manuscript was called "Girl.com." The enterprising assistant at Penguin who decided to look up that web address earned their wages, since any sympathetic reader pointing their browser to www.girl.com would find something more titillating than Katie Jones' baby pictures and CV.

Jones' lawyer, Jonathan Taylor with Townleys Solicitors, says she's in a dangerous position going up against the likes of publishing giant Penguin.

"Penguin retains America's leading First Amendment lawyer, and he's the person who's responded [to our complaint]," Taylor says. "They recognise it's a serious issue, and they're saying 'we've got the money to defend this to the hilt.'" Taylor said that the first communique from Penguin's lawyers indicated that as Jones hadn't trademarked the name "Katie.com," she couldn't expect to have exclusive use of the name. "I can see this as being a legitimate analysis, but it's hardly a responsible attitude to take," he says. "Yes there's freedom of speech, but not absolute freedom. To effectively print a book with someone's address on it goes too far."

Jones and Taylor both feel they're at the mercy of a large multinational publishing concern with unlimited resources. "If somebody wrote a book about dodgy booksellers, and called it Amazon.com, they wouldn't stand for it. They have huge resources and I don't have any," Jones said. "I have every sympathy with this girl; clearly something awful happened to her. But at the same time, that doesn't justify them using my domain name, whether it was her doing or the publishers."

Polly Sprenger writes for The Industry Standard Europe, which launches in October

webTitle: Need to know:  Pat Malone

fields.headline: Need to know:  Pat Malone
fields.trailText:
Age?
44.
fields.body:
Age?
44.

Who is he?
Internet editor of talksport.net. Former print journalist.

What's the clever idea?
"Introducing audio email through Talksport's website. We're the first radio station in the world to broadcast VoizMail - voice rather than text emailing - live to air. We launched on July 18 and already have 140,000 unique users."

What's the thinking behind it?
"We're a phone-in radio station. At any one time, hundreds of people are trying to get through, but we have perhaps half a dozen lines, and can only take one caller to air. We do get an enormous amount of email, but people want to hear their own voices on radio, asking presenters, guests and stars specific questions, making comments, as if they were there. Also, it's not just about a greater audience, allowing voice access to those people who couldn't get to us on the telephone. The producer knows the question - it enables us to structure programmes better, pace them better."

How does it work?
"You need a PC with a sound card, which most PCs have, and a microphone, which we're giving away through the website. You go to www.talksport.net, click on the VoizMail button and that gives a step-by-step graphic prompt on how to do it. Then you simply say your piece, add your email address and click, it's gone. Very user-friendly. We then access that, play it over a microphone, write out a three or four-word synopsis, enter it on the studio's audio system and it's available for the producer to use. They just key it straight in, push the button, it immediately plays and the guest or whoever answers the question. It's very much an experimental system. We've done it three times now, with Shane Warne on each occasion. The quality has been surprisingly good."

Possible shortcomings?
"There is no direct interface between our studio sound system and the email at the moment, so we have to put it on a minidisk and carry it to the studio first. It's also not a telephone call. You don't get the same interaction. The penetration of microphone dimension is pretty low at the moment, although we're giving them away through the website."

What's next?
"We're going to take VoizMail across the whole station. Everybody will be getting a piece of it. We're talking about people coming to accept and use it in the same way as email or the telephone. Also, the thing about radio and the internet is they're perfectly suited to each other and there are so many new things coming along all the time. It won't be long before we're streaming our own video, because we're in the audio production business, on the radio side, and have a number of ideas for expanding our own web presence."

webTitle: New media diary

fields.headline: New media diary
fields.trailText: Channel 4's Big Brother (made by Bazal Productions which is part-owned by the Guardian Media Group) has already become a victim of its own success.
fields.body:
* Channel 4's Big Brother (made by Bazal Productions which is part-owned by the Guardian Media Group) has already become a victim of its own success. The website (www.channel4.com/bigbrother), launched last month, has been dogged by technical problems.

First there were rumours of a hacker at large - Intel suspected a massive "denial of service" operation at large - but with 2m page impressions and 1m video streams a day, the likely scenario is that Channel 4's system just can't cope with demand (as of this week they are having to double their bandwidth). One other theory for the chatroom is that Sada, who was evicted last week, has molecularised herself and is causing havoc inside the machine. Either that or something is watching Big Brother.

*Trinity Mirror New Media took advantage of the flat-rate net access dispute last week to launch its ic24's After Eight service, offering free surfing for its users between 8pm and midnight. Marketing director Jill Playle heroically called on the industry to stop confusing customers with offers that "are not what they seem", calling it free access while charging a set-up or monthly fee. All well and good, but four hours of free surfing hardly equals a free internet.

webTitle: My media:  Sada

fields.headline: My media:  Sada
fields.trailText:
Newspapers:
I would be lying if I said I didn't despise the tabloids. I bought them this week and I will never, ever buy one again.
fields.body:
Newspapers:
I would be lying if I said I didn't despise the tabloids. I bought them this week and I will never, ever buy one again.

Magazines:
I have never really bought into that glossy ethos. The National Geographic and Time I like. And Inventory, a cultural, semi-academic but tongue-in-cheek journal started by some friends. And Third Text, which is about contemporary non-white culture. I love the Face because it's so uncluttered and visually quite relaxing to read.

Books:
OK, my favourite book is one which helped me understand yoga in a really beautiful way - Awakening the Spine, by Vanda Scaravelli. At the moment I'm reading The Power of Now by Eckhart Tolle, which is a guide to spiritual enlightenment. But it's diluted Buddhism and all too yankee-doodle-day for me. I'm also reading Alain de Botton's Essays in Love. I think he's cool. And Jackie Kay's Trumpet.

Film:
Last film I saw was Being John Malkovich. I liked the idea of portals that led you into the mind. There was a parallel with how people treated me when I came out of Big Brother, because they think they own you and know all about you. I absolutely love Doctor Zhivago and Rivette's La Belle Noiseuse - meaning "The beautiful troublemaker", which I thought was quite fitting. I'm also a fan of Francois Truffaut and Woody Allen.

Television:
My favourite show is Blouse and Skirt. It's a black comedy show and it's just too funny. I also love Smack the Pony and Ali G. Absolutely loathe gameshows and docusoaps, ironically enough.

Radio:
Radio 4, because it's soothing. They had my yoga teacher on. And Kiss FM for light reggae in the late mornings.

Ads:
The gridlock one, I think for Malibu. Two black guys in the Caribbean and the voice-over says: "It's a gridlock". It's really funny. And the Motorola mobile phone ad.

Multimedia:
Don't own any of it.

Sada Walkington, the first Big Brother evictee, is co-author of the forthcoming The Babes' Bible

webTitle: John Humphrys responds to recent criticism

fields.headline: 'I don't snort'
fields.standfirst: Poor old George Robertson, says the BBC programme complaints unit over his 'mauling' by John Humphrys. Meanwhile, 95% of listeners say what are they playing at? But what does the Today programme presenter himself say?
fields.trailText: Poor old George Robertson, says the BBC programme complaints unit over his 'mauling' by John Humphrys. Meanwhile, 95% of listeners say what are they playing at? But what does the Today programme presenter himself say?
fields.body:
Does John Humphrys snort? Scoff, yes. Snigger, perhaps. But snort? Humphrys himself is not convinced. "I have to say I don't think I'm a snorter. I'm not sure I even know how to snort. But I could try to do it now I suppose," he says, before volunteering a pig-like "oink" and a rather ambiguous "hawf hawf". "No, I may be a pig-like person but I don't think I do things like that. I don't think I snort."

We are talking, of course, about the 56-year old's habits as presenter of Radio 4's Today programme. Snorting is on the agenda since Lord Robertson, the Nato secretary general, complained to the BBC about a series of interruptions and unwelcome noises made by Humphrys during an interview in February. The BBC programme complaints unit (PCU) last week ruled in favour of Robertson, adding: "The tone of questioning was inappropriate at times, and the frequency of interruption was ill-judged."

By the time I reach him, Humphrys is well and truly reeling from the reporting of his reprimand. He uses words like "childish" and "silly" to describe a Guardian leader dedicated to the issue and his claws are out. "Yes, can we start getting a few facts here?" he says abrasively, when I ask for his side of the story. The suggestion by the Telegraph that Lord Robertson was justified in thinking Humphrys used the interview as a platform for his own views has more than agitated him: "They rejected the claim," he says, before repeating slowly: "They specifically rejected the complaint that I used the interview as a platform for my own views. I was not doing that, I was putting to George Robertson the views of other people. That is what I'm paid to do."

Nevertheless, a gentle slap of the Humphrys wrist has been executed. Does he feel repentant at all? "The PCU is entitled to its view," he says with the same kind of question evasion you'd expect from some of his more adept guests. "It was certainly a robust interview, it didn't strike me as any more robust than a hundred other interviews I've done, but it's a matter of judgment and in the judgment of the PCU I overstepped the mark. Well, they're entitled to their view. So be it." He says it so abruptly you'd think that the faceless figures behind the PCU (not the BBC governors as reported, Humphrys is quick to point out) have done the undoable: rattled him.

Not according to Humphrys they haven't. "I mean, I'm not bothered about it," he is quick to add. "Had it been as was reported in the newspapers, had the governors reprimanded me because I used the interview as a platform for my own opinions, that would have been a very serious matter indeed. I would have to consider my position, as would the BBC governors. And if there was evidence that the public thought I had overstepped the mark and if that happened consistently then that would be serious too. In this event neither of those things happened."

The message is clear: Humphrys may be on the ropes, but his predicament is little more than an uneasy wobble. Throughout our conversation he frequently suggests his own dismissal - "If the public thinks that I'm getting it wrong then the BBC should get rid of me" - with the confidence of a man who knows he is safe in his job. It's hardly a surprise. Humphrys is a hydra: cut off one of his heads and he'll grow back stronger. After Jonathan Aitken labelled him "rude, interruptive and partisan", there was a surge in audience support for him. And in 1993, when he and Jeremy Paxman were criticised by the BBC governors for being too aggressive, the public responded by voting Humphrys one of their favourite presenters and the Today programme notched up a Sony award.

But recently questions of his objectivity have come into play. In regularly penning a column for the Sunday Times some see his ready acceptance of the Murdoch shilling as eroding his impartiality. Humphrys disagrees. "I suppose if you take the view that journalists shouldn't work for four of the biggest circulation newspapers in Britain then that's fine, but I think it's slightly odd." There is no conflict of interest, he says. "I do not express political opinions and nobody would be able to judge from my columns what my political views are. The BBC does not require its presenters not to have any views on anything, it requires its presenters not to make their own political views explicit, for very obvious reasons."

With the majority of politicians on-side it's clearly a skill Humphrys has mastered. "Far be it for me to be hugely immodest but I was voted political journalist of the year by politicians this year," he reminds me. "I mean, it's a bit bizarre that the very people whom I am supposed to mercilessly pillory and savagely and ceaselessly attack should vote for me voluntarily in competition with every political hack in Britain. They can't think that I'm such an ogre."

Still, words like "rottweiler", "pugnacious" and "biting" appear throughout articles dedicated to the broadcaster, alongside references to the time he interrupted Ken Clarke 32 times and the encounter when he reduced Harriet Harman to a quivering wreck. It's an image he doesn't wholly embrace. "That's the trouble. Once you get a couple of high-profile stories or attacks on you for your style of interviewing then you're saddled with that forever. The truth is if you listen to the overwhelming body of my work then you'd find that the majority of interviews that I do are free from interruptions."

John Birt was not a fan of the confrontational style and famously launched an attack on sneering interviewers (from which Humphrys was neatly excluded with a handwritten letter saying that it was not actually him that got Birt's goat). But Humphrys will not be drawn on the subject of his new director-general. "It's early days," he says, " and I have absolutely no way of knowing what Greg's view of my sort of interviewing is. I think Greg has far too much on his hands at the moment to worry about whether Humphrys is asking rude questions on the Today programme."

Which brings us back to "this business with George Robertson", as Humphrys likes to label it, and how the public have responded. "For what it's worth we've had a very large numbers of emails and faxes and so far about 95% have said: 'What on earth does the BBC think it's playing at?' They are cross that Robertson complained and they take the view that this is what the business of interviewing is about."

It is for Humphrys, anyway. "It would be a pretty bizarre and pathetically inadequate interview if all I ever did was politely question: 'Mr Brown, have you ever done this?' Or: 'Mr Brown, do you believe every pensioner in Britain is happy with their pension?' Yes, I could do an interview like that. Equally I could work on Blue Peter." Could he? "Well, I haven't been asked recently. Apparently it's because I don't look good enough in a skirt. But then they haven't seen my legs, so how would they know?"
