webTitle: A station of two halves

fields.headline: A station of two halves
fields.standfirst: The appointment of sport fanatic Beob Shennan as new controller of Radio 5 Live signals an attempt to unite the two parts of the stations, news and sport, into a more rounded whole
fields.trailText: The appointment of sport fanatic Beob Shennan as new controller of Radio 5 Live signals an attempt to unite the two parts of the stations, news and sport, into a more rounded whole
fields.body:
Bob Shennan, the new controller of Radio 5 Live, is making it very clear, in his quiet but insistent manner, that he has indeed landed his dream job. "I feel I've been in training for it since I joined the BBC. I wanted it. It doesn't come up very often."

Radio 5 Live has never looked back since the high-profile relaunch by Jenny Abramsky six years ago, and Shennan is only the third controller of the highly rated sports and news network, which now attracts more than 6m listeners a week.

Abramsky, now reaping the rewards of her endeavours as director of BBC Radio (the most senior manager), first handed the baton over to the canny Roger Mosey - like her, a former editor of Radio 4's Today programme.

Mosey, backed up by executives such as Steve Kyte, has introduced a range of changes, including the versatile Nicky Campbell in the mornings. But then the competition suddenly became more fierce, and more vociferous, as Kelvin MacKenzie's Talksport switched its priorities from chat to sport, in an attempt to woo advertiser-friendly, cash-rich young males.

The thing that distinguishes Shennan from his two predecessors is that instead of coming from a news background he is a sports expert through and through - well versed in the tricky radio sports-rights market and in handling sporting stars.

"Just as Roger Mosey was absolutely the right person after Jenny - even though it was predominantly driven in audience terms by sport - I think I'm the right person now. I don't think it really matters what people's backgrounds are. It's how they want to move the radio station forward."

At 38, he is swapping that unhappy billet, head of BBC sport production for television and radio, for the pleasure of running a service still in possession of the crown jewels of sport. And he is doing so as the BBC news empire loses control of 5 Live, allowing it to slot in alongside the other four national radio channels under Abramsky. This, says Shennan, represents a perfect opportunity for the station to redefine itself. "I want Radio 5 Live to feel like a real radio station, not a BBC network made up of two strands, news and sport.

"When people come in to work here, I want them to feel they are working for 5 Live, as they do in Radio 1 and Radio 2. I want to blur the edges, smooth out the gear changes for listeners," he adds, referring to the abrupt shifts between hot news inputs and live sport. "There is a bumpy sound to some parts of the schedule."

The tension of being a hybrid and having to play two roles can't entirely be wished away with snazzier jingles or more sports news programmes. But Shennan sees strength coming from melding the two elements more carefully. For example, drive-time's Peter Allen co-presented the Open from St Andrews last month, and the breakfast show was broadcast from there in much the same way that the Today programme moves to Brussels or Washington for key political events.

Over the past 18 months or so, Shennan notes approvingly that there's been a push to beef up the role of sports news. "It's about making sure the whole of the radio station recognises the value of sport. I don't want there to be a sense that there are times when sport switches on and everyone in news goes home, or vice versa. It does happen. It's a very, very ambitious network with diverse tones of voice," he says.

Shennan, educated at Lancaster grammar school, joined the BBC from Cambridge University armed with an English degree and a stint at Radio Hereward. A radio sports trainee, he rose to become head of radio sport as the first, unsuccessful version of Radio 5 Live stumbled onto the air. He is surprised at how slow the commercial operators were in the early days to spot the potential of radio sport.

Given this pedigree, it is hardly surprising that Shennan is less keen on by-elections, prime minister's questions and rolling news. The news wing of Radio 5 is making fearful noises in private. Shennan, however, claims they have nothing to worry about. "There is not going to be a huge shift or a dramatic move away from news. I want to evolve the station, not revolutionise it."

Indeed, with digital radio expansion still some years away, 5 Live is unlikely to eliminate news or a commitment to breaking stories, such as the Paddington rail crash or by-election declarations. "My role is to build a sense of one radio station. I want to make a strength of the fact that we have these two distinctive strands."

The question of competition, specifically in the form of MacKenzie's Talksport, is one that he is keen to bring up: "I am very alive to the challenges we face."

Radio 5 Live gave an early demonstration of this new awareness when it finally took action this summer against Talksport's practice of covering events to which the BBC owned exclusive rights. After a year of hand-wringing, lawyers were employed when Talksport commentated on televised Euro 2000 matches.

"It's very sensible for the BBC to protect its investment, and increasingly, rights-holders will be pleased, rather than having to take action themselves. I see Euro 2000 as quite straightforward. We bought the rights to broadcast live and exclusive, and Talksport was not around when the whole process was negotiated.

"There were no national sports broadcasters when we launched. There certainly are now. Inevitably, we are challenged. The key part of our strategy is going to be maintaining that portfolio [of sports rights] in every way we can."

Radio 5 Live, he agrees, already has a healthy budget of £65m. Will it get more? It sounds possible. Negotiations are just opening for radio rights to the Premiership - 5 Live has them for one more year.

"We have to make sure we maintain the integrity of the output. We will bid competitively for Premier League rights. Holding on is very important for us," promises Shennan.

But, as he points out, 5 Live has done well (certainly far better than television) in holding on to the crown jewels - cricket, the Open, Six Nations rugby, formula one and the FA Cup.

But he could be inheriting the station as it peaks: "There is still potential; it could go further. It will depend on a number of things working in our favour. Maybe sports audiences are quite close to their maximum."

The key, therefore, is probably more attractive news programming and fresh thinking. Nurturing articulate sports stars with a background in professional sport is one of Shennan's pet projects. "I want to develop new, key talent," he says. He points to the way Gary Lineker, Steve Cram and Clare Balding have been brought on.

"I want to introduce new voices. Ian Wright and Mark Bright - now that could be a strong team." He goes on to praise John Inverdale, one of Radio 5 Live's stars, who has been tempted across to television. "He's not going to disappear - he's very symbolic of what 5 Live is about. He's a terrific journalist, with all-round knowledge, and a wonderful tone of voice."

What Shennan's appointment means for David Mellor's Football 606 - already moved from its Saturday slot - is less clear. "He's been a tremendous success at 5 Live. He's been here a long time, and he'll do it for the next season. But it's always my job to think about the future and refresh things."

'No-one else does it'

March 1994
Five months after being given the go-ahead, Radio 5 Live is launched with a new 24-hour news and sports format, replacing BBC Radio 5. "Nobody else does it," says its controller, Jenny Abramsky. Its £30.2m budget includes an unprecedented £1m advertising allowance. Personality presenters such as Ian Botham and David Mellor are among extra staff recruited.

August 1994
First detailed listening figures show a gain of 500,000 listeners over 5 Live's predecessor, with 4.7m tuning in each week.

February 1995
Talk Radio UK is launched, competing for the same listeners.

April 1996
Radio 5 Live is named UK station of the year at the Sony Radio awards for its sports broadcasting in particular - "so engaging that it makes listeners feel they are actually there at the event itself". Sport provides the largest audience, with up to 800,000 listeners.

October 1996
The editor of the Today programme, Roger Mosey, is appointed new controller of 5 Live.

March 1997
Football presenter Danny Baker is fired for urging listeners to doorstep a referee and make his life hell. Talk Radio signs him up.

March 1997
The audience for 5 Live's breakfast programme has risen to one-third of Today's 5m. Its listeners are younger, more regional and less upmarket.

December 1997
"There's enough sport around not only for 5 Live, but for us too," says the boss of Talk Radio, Peter Robinson.

April 1999
Radio 5 Live loses winter Test cricket rights to Talk Radio. However, it has 5.2m listeners a week, up from 4.7m in April 1994.

August 2000
Figures show a fall from 5 Live's record reach of 6.2m in the previous quarter to 5.8m. Slight share fall from 4.4% to 4.1%. Moves under Jenny Abramsky's control.

At 38, he is swapping that unhappy billet, head of BBC sport production for television and radio, for the pleasure of running a service still in possession of the crown jewels of sport. And he is doing so as the BBC news empire loses control of 5 Live, allowing it to slot in alongside the other four national radio channels under Abramsky. This, says Shennan, represents a perfect opportunity for the station to redefine itself. "I want Radio 5 Live to feel like a real radio station, not a BBC network made up of two strands, news and sport. "When people come in to work here, I want them to feel they are working for 5 Live, as they do in Radio 1 and Radio 2. I want to blur the edges, smooth out the gear changes for listeners," he adds, referring to the abrupt shifts between hot news inputs and live sport. "There is a bumpy sound to some parts of the schedule." The tension of being a hybrid and having to play two roles can't entirely be wished away with snazzier jingles or more sports news programmes. But Shennan sees strength coming from melding the two elements more carefully. For example, drive-time's Peter Allen co-presented the Open from St Andrews last month, and the breakfast show was broadcast from there in much the same way that the Today programme moves to Brussels or Washington for key political events. Over the past 18 months or so, Shennan notes approvingly that there's been a push to beef up the role of sports news. "It's about making sure the whole of the radio station recognises the value of sport. I don't want there to be a sense that there are times when sport switches on and everyone in news goes home, or vice versa. It does happen. It's a very, very ambitious network with diverse tones of voice," he says. Shennan, educated at Lancaster grammar school, joined the BBC from Cambridge University armed with an English degree and a stint at Radio Hereward. A radio sports trainee, he rose to become head of radio sport as the first, unsuccessful version of Radio 5 Live stumbled onto the air. He is surprised at how slow the commercial operators were in the early days to spot the potential of radio sport. Given this pedigree, it is hardly surprising that Shennan is less keen on by-elections, prime minister's questions and rolling news. The news wing of Radio 5 is making fearful noises in private. Shennan, however, claims they have nothing to worry about. "There is not going to be a huge shift or a dramatic move away from news. I want to evolve the station, not revolutionise it." Indeed, with digital radio expansion still some years away, 5 Live is unlikely to eliminate news or a commitment to breaking stories, such as the Paddington rail crash or by-election declarations. "My role is to build a sense of one radio station. I want to make a strength of the fact that we have these two distinctive strands." The question of competition, specifically in the form of MacKenzie's Talksport, is one that he is keen to bring up: "I am very alive to the challenges we face." Radio 5 Live gave an early demonstration of this new awareness when it finally took action this summer against Talksport's practice of covering events to which the BBC owned exclusive rights. After a year of hand-wringing, lawyers were employed when Talksport commentated on televised Euro 2000 matches. "It's very sensible for the BBC to protect its investment, and increasingly, rights-holders will be pleased, rather than having to take action themselves. I see Euro 2000 as quite straightforward. We bought the rights to broadcast live and exclusive, and Talksport was not around when the whole process was negotiated. "There were no national sports broadcasters when we launched. There certainly are now. Inevitably, we are challenged. The key part of our strategy is going to be maintaining that portfolio [of sports rights] in every way we can." Radio 5 Live, he agrees, already has a healthy budget of £65m. Will it get more? It sounds possible. Negotiations are just opening for radio rights to the Premiership - 5 Live has them for one more year. "We have to make sure we maintain the integrity of the output. But, as he points out, 5 Live has done well (certainly far better than television) in holding on to the crown jewels - cricket, the Open, Six Nations rugby, formula one and the FA Cup. But he could be inheriting the station as it peaks: "There is still potential; it could go further. It will depend on a number of things working in our favour. Maybe sports audiences are quite close to their maximum." The key, therefore, is probably more attractive news programming and fresh thinking. Nurturing articulate sports stars with a background in professional sport is one of Shennan's pet projects. "I want to develop new, key talent," he says. He points to the way Gary Lineker, Steve Cram and Clare Balding have been brought on. "I want to introduce new voices. Ian Wright and Mark Bright - now that could be a strong team." He goes on to praise John Inverdale, one of Radio 5 Live's stars, who has been tempted across to television. "He's not going to disappear - he's very symbolic of what 5 Live is about. He's a terrific journalist, with all-round knowledge, and a wonderful tone of voice." What Shennan's appointment means for David Mellor's Football 606 - already moved from its Saturday slot - is less clear. "He's been a tremendous success at 5 Live. He's been here a long time, and he'll do it for the next season. But it's always my job to think about the future and refresh things." "Nobody else does it," says its controller, Jenny Abramsky. Its £30.2m budget includes an unprecedented £1m advertising allowance. Personality presenters such as Ian Botham and David Mellor are among extra staff recruited. August 1994 First detailed listening figures show a gain of 500,000 listeners over 5 Live's predecessor, with 4.7m tuning in each week. February 1995 Talk Radio UK is launched, competing for the same listeners. April 1996 Radio 5 Live is named UK station of the year at the Sony Radio awards for its sports broadcasting in particular - "so engaging that it makes listeners feel they are actually there at the event itself". Sport provides the largest audience, with up to 800,000 listeners. October 1996 The editor of the Today programme, Roger Mosey, is appointed new controller of 5 Live. March 1997 Football presenter Danny Baker is fired for urging listeners to doorstep a referee and make his life hell. Talk Radio signs him up. March 1997 The audience for 5 Live's breakfast programme has risen to one-third of Today's 5m. Its listeners are younger, more regional and less upmarket. December 1997 "There's enough sport around not only for 5 Live, but for us too," says the boss of Talk Radio, Peter Robinson. April 1999 Radio 5 Live loses winter Test cricket rights to Talk Radio. However, it has 5.2m listeners a week, up from 4.7m in April 1994. August 2000 Figures show a fall from 5 Live's record reach of 6.2m in the previous quarter to 5.8m. Slight share fall from 4.4% to 4.1%. Moves under Jenny Abramsky's control.

webTitle: Don't shackle the political interviewers

fields.headline: Don't shackle the political interviewers
fields.trailText: Every so often, a bright spark decides the professional broadcast interview is dead. How much better, he or she says, if the public can interact with the decision-makers: remember that old lady who ran rings around Margaret Thatcher? Or what if politicians cross-examine each other? Great format!
fields.body:
Every so often, a bright spark decides the professional broadcast interview is dead. How much better, he or she says, if the public can interact with the decision-makers: remember that old lady who ran rings around Margaret Thatcher? Or what if politicians cross-examine each other? Great format!

In fact, nothing is better calculated to show the skill of the interviewer than when he or she is shut out of the game. For every Diana Gould on the Belgrano, there are dozens of phone-in callers who kick the ball into their own net. A BBC debate during the London mayoral campaign suggested that the candidates, however decent as politicians, were pretty hopeless questioners.

And these, remember, are formats in which the people asking the questions have only one topic on their mind - and can spend hours thinking through what they're going to say. Contrast that with a presenter on a show in which there are multiple interviews on multiple subjects to carry out against the clock. And the interviewees range from bolshie politicians to camera-shy inarticulates.

Sceptics may say that's precisely why they invest their licence fee in John, Jim or Jeremy. They are the hired professionals. But that underestimates the high-wire act they perform in every interview. They need to know their own facts are correct and they have to be able to spot the whoppers. They have to ask the questions the audience wants to ask, and also set the tone of a live broadcast.

John Humphrys and I once worked together on an interview with Mrs Thatcher. This was going to be a reflective interview - and John started with the reasoned question he'd concocted. Mrs T hit back at him like Mike Tyson with a toothache, so he jabbed in a sharper follow-up. Before long there was a rough equivalent of world war three being enacted in the studio. Afterwards, Mrs T exuded hostility. "We get what we expect from the BBC," she said, "we get what we expect."

That points to one of the reasons that broadcasters sometimes bridle when critics listen to interviews days later and decide it could all have been much better. It's right that people who think they were badly treated should have recourse to a complaints procedure. But the shock horror of a "reprimand" from the BBC's programme complaints unit should be put in the context of the thousands of interviews that pass off well. A public service broadcaster need have no hesitation in admitting there are some things that go wrong if it has the confidence that most of its output is soundly based.

That mustn't mean seeking a quiet life. Some years ago, research was commissioned that seemed to have the agenda of proving a public appetite for super-polite interviewers who never interrupted. To the pleasure of many of us, it proved nothing of the sort. Audiences value Paxman and Humphrys because they won't let politicians get away with waffle and evasion. It's equally dangerous to suggest that interviewers should eschew interruption. Chopping up guests a few seconds after they've opened their mouths isn't a good idea. But neither is it acceptable for a politician to filibuster without being brought back to the point.

I was talking to one of our best new broadcasters the other night. "The fact is," he said, "an interview can be made or broken by an intervention a couple of seconds too early or a word out of place." He's right. If it seems effortless, it disguises the legs paddling hard below the surface. And while criticism is always healthy, it would be daft to let one-offs cloud the bigger picture. There's a lot to lose if we shackle the political interview.

Roger Mosey is head of TV news and a former editor of Today and controller of Radio 5 Live

webTitle: How the Big Brother format saved CBS

fields.headline: News from nowhere
fields.standfirst: The US television network CBS dumped its credibility as a news provider and grabbed the Big Brother format with both hands in an attempt to boost ratings. It worked, and now housework is breaking news
fields.trailText: The US television network CBS dumped its credibility as a news provider and grabbed the Big Brother format with both hands in an attempt to boost ratings. It worked, and now housework is breaking news
fields.body:
It wasn't exactly the birthday present she'd been expecting. Sure, the day had started well enough: "It's the crack of dawn and we're barbequeing - Oh, I'm so excited!" Jordan squealed for what must have been the 10th time in a television minute, as she and the eight remaining humiliation hunters waited for Big Brother to turn on the hot water at 7am.

But it wasn't long before the harsh reality began to dawn on the 27-year-old former stripper from Minneapolis: she was about to become the second contestant banished from the US camera- and microphone-infested house. "I could have looked so much better," she whined later that day, as voyeur-voters around the country were phoning in on Wednesday with the ugly truth. "Look, my abs are gone," she said, pulling up her shirt for the two-way mirror.

Some 78% of the audience apparently agreed, and the birthday girl was banished - no doubt straight from CBS primetime television to the pages of Playboy, where the latest bikini-clad evictee from the CBS sister show, Survivor, 23-year-old Jenna Lewis, looks set to show off her naked ambition for a reported $500,000.

Smiling bravely as she hugged her housemates goodbye, Jordan seemed less sure of her own prospects as she was debriefed moments later by Big Brother, otherwise known as the CBS morning news anchor Julie Chen (it's her voice those still in the house hear), her own reputation compromised by her network's ratings-driven blurring of the lines between news and "reality" entertainment. Would Jordan consider posing for a nude photo-spread? "I'd consider it," Jordan told her, "but the chances are close to none."

Indeed, punters may already have seen enough of Jordan. During the programme, viewers saw plenty of the topless club where she had danced for two years. "She'll be back," predicted her old colleague Blake. "She hasn't cleaned out her locker."

But Americans, it seems, can't get enough of "reality" fare. Network audiences overwhelmingly opted for the Survivor castaways and Big Brother housemates over the more stage-managed offerings of the Republican National Convention last week - zapping CBS to another ratings high as coverage of the convention slipped to the week's lowest viewing figures.

Wednesday's live hour of Big Brother drew in 17.4m viewers, suggesting George W Bush would have been better advised to take a cameo role in the hit series. "It's pretty hard to compete," admitted one Republican pollster.

One can only imagine how flush with cash the estate of George Orwell might have been if the man who coined the phrase Big Brother had been able to stretch his imagination beyond 1984. If he'd really seen into the future, he might have registered it as a brand. Just think of the millions being made from all the voyeurs around the world now hooked on the mundane antics of all the supposedly "ordinary" fame and fortune hunters.

Here in the US, CBS paid $20m just to buy the rights to the Big Brother TV format from its Dutch originators Endemol. And the investment is paying a handsome dividend for the once-struggling network: it is winning back the young viewers so coveted by national advertisers. But at a big price: the credibility of its once vaunted news division is in question, as it stuffs its news broadcasts with the latest "news" from the Survivor and Big Brother sets.

Every Thursday morning, the network's struggling breakfast news programme, The Early Show, devotes almost an hour of its airtime to the latest developments on Survivor, including a half-hour panel discussion and the first interview with the latest cutie cast adrift by his or her tropical island rivals as they compete for the coveted $1m prize.

As for Big Brother, Early Show newsreader Chen also hosts a half-hour primetime interview with every week's Big Brother cast-off, along with her new-found acting role as the voice of Big Brother. She then hosts a long segment on The Early Show every Friday morning to discuss the previous night's banishment; and on Monday mornings, after a weekend of compulsory psychological counselling, the exiled cast member is flown to the CBS news studio in New York for the first interview.

And as if all that blatant cross-promotion weren't enough, CBS's local radio and TV stations have been breathlessly reporting on the latest developments on the two shows - sometimes leading their bulletins with them, even when there is real news of the traditional, important kind, be it from the Middle East peace negotiations at Camp David or the campaign trail.

Not that any of that concerns the suits at CBS. Even the network news president Andrew Heyward can defend it with a straight face. "It's an experiment well worth taking on," he says. "I understand the traditional view that says we shouldn't do something like this, but I'm very comfortable with it."

CBS, which spent $30m on a revamp of its morning news show last autumn only to lose yet more viewers to NBC's Today and ABC's Good Morning America, admits it had become desperate. "We were really struggling, but now we've won over hundreds of thousands of new viewers," says The Early Show's executive producer Steve Friedman.

US media watchdogs may grumble, but their words have little impact in a celebrity-driven culture where the news agenda is increasingly dictated by profit margins. The difference from Orwell's nightmare is that viewers can always tune out, says CBS. But as long as millions tune in and log on for a daily dose of the banal, household chores and petty bickering will continue to pass for breaking news. If it makes money, it makes the news.

Everyone, it seems, wants to play the fame game, or at the very least, live vicariously through those who succeed at it, for whatever dubious reason.

And although there is mounting evidence to suggest Americans are increasingly alarmed by online invasions into their privacy, thousands are still flocking to audition for the growing number of so-called "reality shows" now monopolising the airwaves. Few seem to feel in any way compromised by being spied on, or uncomfortable about spying on others in a culture where un-earned and accidental celebrity is becoming a way of life.

Even Jeffrey Rosen, whose new book, The Unwanted Gaze, defines the perils to privacy brought by the digital age, seems unfazed by the Big Brother phenomenon. "It's silly to huff and puff about watching lurid television. It's a human impulse," he says, adding that the embarrassing exhibitionism of the contestants, even to the point of prime-time national humiliation, is understandable in the post-Monicagate era.

"Being on TV is now seen as more important than being a good citizen," Rosen recently told the New York Times. "Bill Clinton showed that in a culture of exposure, shamelessness is a self-defence; no amount of bad behaviour is embarrassing as long as you continue to be on television. The distinction between fame and infamy has been eradicated."

And banished along with it, so it would seem, is the distinction between reality and unreality. Come November when Americans go to the polls to elect their next president, it will be interesting to see how many of those voting each week in the Big Brother popularity contest actually show up at the polling booth that really matters.

webTitle: Rare punishment for protesting grandmother

fields.headline: Rare punishment for protesting grandmother
fields.trailText: A 70-year-old grandmother who campaigns against nuclear weapons was today given the rare punishment of being confined to a courtroom for one day for non-payment of a fine.
fields.body:
A 70-year-old grandmother who campaigns against nuclear weapons was today given the rare punishment of being confined to a courtroom for one day for non-payment of a fine.

Joan Meredith had been prepared to go to jail for seven days as part of her protest against the Trident nuclear programme. But magistrates in Alnwick, Northumberland, said sending the retired teacher to prison would serve no useful purpose.

Instead they invoked a little-used power under Section 135 of the Magistrates' Court Act to detain Mrs Meredith within the precinct of the court until the close of business at 4pm today.

The grandmother was told to find a comfortable seat and to sit through the remainder of the cases appearing before the Bench today. When Mrs Meredith arrived at court today, she had a bag prepared with what she would need for her expected prison sentence.

The campaigner had been given a suspended jail sentence last month for the non-payment of a £100 fine handed out by Argyll and Bute court in Helensburgh earlier this year.

She had been found guilty of breach of the peace following a sit-down protest at the Faslane Naval Base near Glasgow last May.

But the grey-haired campaigner refused to pay the fine claiming that her protest had been taken on moral grounds against the Trident submarines based at Faslane.

Before the hearing today Mrs Meredith, of Rock Moor, near Alnwick, said she was prepared to go to prison for her beliefs. She said: "I don't want to go to prison but it is something I am prepared to do because of my beliefs, I am not the first campaigner to face going to prison and I don't think my age has anything to do with the issue.

"My children are supporting me, I would not say that they are proud, but they understand the reasons for my action."

Later she told magistrates why she had refused the pay the fine. "I have not paid because I am a member of Trident Ploughshare which is working for nuclear disarmament and the dismantling of the Trident submarines," she said.

"I have pledged to work with them and the non-payment of the fine is part of the protest."

She told the court she did not relish the prospect of going to prison but was prepared for any decision of the court.

She said her original protest at Faslane had been morally correct, saying: "I think I have the right as a citizen to make a protest against nuclear weapons."

Magistrates retired for 20 minutes before returning with their order that Mrs Meredith be detained for the rest of the day.

Magistrates retired for 20 minutes before returning with their order that Mrs Meredith be detained for the rest of the day.

webTitle: Surfing from home more common - internet survey

fields.headline: Surfing from home more common - internet survey
fields.standfirst: Oftel
fields.trailText: Logging onto the Internet at home is becoming more common with almost a quarter of the UK's population surfing the net from their residence, figures today show.
fields.body:
Logging onto the Internet at home is becoming more common with almost a quarter of the UK's population surfing the net from their residence, figures today show.

A survey by telecoms watchdog Oftel showed that around 14m people in the UK, or 22% of the population, were logging on to the Internet at home. The survey also showed that around 6m homes in the UK are hooked up to the net.

Oftel said the report showed that consumers were continuing to make use of the choice of products available and were interested in new high-speed services such as fast Internet access.

However, the survey found only 18% of consumers felt that companies were providing enough information for them to find the best Internet access package.

Chris Kenny, Oftel director of regulatory policy, said: "This research into consumer behaviour will help us to ensure that we are implementing our strategy effectively."

The survey also found that a third of Internet users now use more than one Internet service provider (ISP).

webTitle: Wanchope plumps for Maine Road

fields.headline: Wanchope plumps for Maine Road
fields.trailText: Paulo Wanchope today completed his £3.75m move from West Ham United to Manchester City. City fought off the late attentions of Bradford City to sign the Costa Rican, who has signed a four-year contract at Maine Road.
fields.body:
Paulo Wanchope today completed his £3.75m move from West Ham United to Manchester City. City fought off the late attentions of Bradford City to sign the Costa Rican, who has signed a four-year contract at Maine Road.

City manager Joe Royle said he was pleased with the signing despite the criticism Wanchope endured last season for his performances in claret and blue. "I am pleased we have got him and in modern terms the fee for a proven 24-year-old striker is not unreasonable," he said.

"People say he was not successful in London but I don't agree - I hope he is as unsuccessful here!

"We flatter ourselves - and this is no disrespect to West Ham - that we can help him improve. We want him to enjoy himself and score goals."

Wanchope scored 23 goals in 72 league games for Derby before joining the Hammers for £3.5m last year, where he scored 12 league goals.

Wanchope becomes City's third major signing of the summer, following the arrival of former World Footballer of the Year George Weah last week and the £2.5m signing of Alfie Haaland from Leeds.

webTitle: Websites say sucks to big business

fields.headline: Websites say sucks to big business
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The right to set up a really rude website aimed at undermining the public image of big businesses and religions is being fought for by civil rights activists in the US.
fields.body:
The right to set up a really rude website aimed at undermining the public image of big businesses and religions is being fought for by civil rights activists in the US.

The battle comes in the wake of action by leading multinational companies like Wal-Mart and McDonald's to stem the growth of websites which add "sucks", "kills" or "stinks" to the brand name.

"This has become a constant issue," Barry Steinhart of the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) said in New York yesterday. "The big trademark holders are trying to gobble up all the names."

What has angered companies is the proliferation of sites that provide damaging and cheeky information about particular multinationals and churches and use the trade name of the chosen target somewhere in the title of the website.

This means that the idle surfer interested in a company or church can view scurrilous information on the internet.

The ACLU and the Consumer Project on Technology, which was set up by the Green party presidential candidate Ralph Nader, have come to the aid of sites under attack by the big guns.

"This is not a cybersquatting issue," Mr Steinhart said, referring to the practice whereby people register websites in well-known names in order to sell them on to the company concerned at an inflated price.

"This is about a First Amendment right. The trademark laws are designed to protect the public from being confused, but when a name is clearly so derogatory, such as walmart.sucks, the public can well understand it."

Some companies have taken pre-emptive strikes. Volvo owns Volvo.sucks.com and Chase Manhattan has Chase.stinks.com.

Mr Steinhart said the right to free speech should include the right to set up websites which might offend.

While it is mainly big companies that seek to save themselves from embarrassment by buying up potentially rude sites, the Church of Scientology has also been unhappy about the use of its name in derogatory sites.

The ACLU is anxious to fight on behalf of the threatened sites so that they can create a new American adage: always giving a sucks an even break.

webTitle: Iraqis pay price of a pointless deadlock

fields.headline: Iraqis pay price of a pointless deadlock
fields.standfirst: 10 years of sanctions have achieved little and caused horrific suffering for the people of Iraq, but there is scant hope of an end in sight, writes Simon Tisdall
fields.trailText: 10 years of sanctions have achieved little and caused horrific suffering for the people of Iraq, but there is scant hope of an end in sight, writes Simon Tisdall.
fields.body:
The 10th anniversary of the imposition of United Nations sanctions on Iraq was marked at the weekend by noisy protests by campaigners in Baghdad, London and Washington, including a symbolic "die-in" today outside the Foreign Office in London.

In contrast, the US, British and Iraqi governments have kept largely quiet about the ongoing embargo that was put in place four days after President Saddam Hussein sent his troops into neighbouring Kuwait on August 2, 1990.

The anti-sanctions protesters, once in a minority, now have the active or tacit backing of many countries which supported the US-led alliance that launched Operation Desert Storm in January, 1991.

The French government, which contributed troops at the time, now favours a suspension of non-military sanctions. So, too, do two other permanent members of the UN Security Council - Russia and China. These countries argue that the sanctions have become counterproductive and are blocking development of Iraq's enormous oil and gas reserves (in which they have a keen interest).

Most Arab governments, many of which, like Syria and Egypt, supported former president George Bush's campaign to reverse the invasion, now favour some form of easing of the sanctions regime. Several Gulf states, the very same countries that in 1990 most feared Iraqi aggression, have restored diplomatic links with Baghdad.

A plethora of reports over the past year has provided much evidence that the sanctions are being actively subverted by Iraq's neighbours, including Turkey and Iran. The US suspects Russia of being deeply involved in selling contraband Iraqi oil and recently intercepted a Russian-registered tanker in the Gulf carrying Iraqi crude.

But despite this shift in opinion, and the bypassing of the international controls, the US, backed by Britain, remains adamantly opposed to a suspension or lifting of sanctions until UN weapons inspectors, charged with locating and destroying Iraq's nuclear, biological and chemical arms, have completed their work.

The inspections were suspended in 1998 amid much acrimony and the UN team was obliged to leave Iraq. A new wave of US and British bombing followed. The inspectors have not been back since.

A recent UN security council resolution attempted to give the Iraqi regime an incentive to comply by offering a phased suspension of sanctions, simultaneous with the resumption and completion of weapons inspections. But this idea was rejected by Baghdad which said that the plan gave no guarantee that sanctions would be ended, or when.

The impasse has been further entrenched by the US presidential election campaign. Until the result of November 7's American polls is known, neither Republican candidate George W Bush, nor his Democratic rival, Al Gore, are likely to show any flexibility.

The main problem for the Americans and the British is a moral one. It is fairly clear that after 10 years, the sanctions regime has achieved little or nothing in political or military terms.

But as the protesters point out, while that impasse may not matter very much as long as peace is maintained in the region, the sanctions continue to cause horrific suffering among Iraq's civilian population.

A Unicef report published last year said that in many areas of Iraq mortality rates among children under five years have more than doubled since 1990. Iraq itself says 1.5 million Iraqis, young and old, have died as a result of sanctions, largely caused by the collapse of Iraq's health services, sanitation, resulting diseases, and by poor nutrition.

President Saddam's henchmen, the army, and Iraq's wealthy elite, who carry the principal responsibility for the Gulf war, have not suffered in this way, of course. Instead, say the protesters, it is the Iraqi people who pay the price of a continuing, pointless deadlock.

It would be nice to say that this situation will change soon. But with the positions of both sides entrenched, there is at present no prospect of a breakthrough. And there may be yet more, gloomy anniversaries to come.

webTitle: British child killed in French coach crash

fields.headline: British child killed in French coach crash
fields.standfirst: Seventeen injured as bus overturns near Clermont Ferrand
fields.trailText: A British teenager has died and 17 passengers have been injured, up to five of them seriously, after their coach crashed and overturned in France earlier today.     Two parties of children aged between 13 and 17, from Romford, Essex, and Edinburgh were heading to the Dordogne for an adventure holiday when their coach crashed at about 6.25am local time on the A71 motorway near the village of Vierzon near Clermont Ferrand.
fields.body:
A British teenager has died and 17 passengers have been injured, up to five of them seriously, after their coach crashed and overturned in France earlier today. Two parties of children aged between 13 and 17, from Romford, Essex, and Edinburgh were heading to the Dordogne for an adventure holiday when their coach crashed at about 6.25am local time on the A71 motorway near the village of Vierzon near Clermont Ferrand.

The boy who died has been named as Craig Norsworthy, of Leith, Edinburgh. He was 15. Police said the accident was thought to have been caused by the driver falling asleep at the wheel. Jean-Pierre Smith, of Bourges gendarmerie, which is coordinating operations, said those injured had been taken to three hospitals and the local council had set up a centre for survivors in Vierzon.

Keith Wilkinson, the head teacher of Chadwell Heath Foundation school in Romford, said five children from his school were among the injured.

Chief executive of the Boys Brigade in the UK, Sydney Jones, said the boys in the Scottish party were from the 44th Edinburgh Boys Brigade, based at Duddingston Kirk in the east of the city and were aged between 12 and 18. He said the Boys Brigade headquarters, in Hemel Hempstead, Herts had been flooded with calls from anxious parents.

Alan Nicholls, an adult member of the Boys Brigade party, said one of the boys from his group was unaccounted for. "It's a tragic incident but the rest of the boys are coping very wellMost of the people taken to hospital had superficial injuries. I think there was one broken leg but basically it was just cuts and bruises." The children were being looked after at a nearby gymnasium and food and drink had been provided by the French authorities, he added.

Holiday operator PGL Travel has set up a helpline for worried parents on 01989 764211. The company is arranging to take parents out to see the children where necessary, a spokesman said.

John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, said today: "Our thoughts and sympathy are with the families of the children and teachers involved in this terrible accident.

"Our gratitude goes out to the French emergency services and hospital staff for all of their actions after the incident. I have spoken to the French authorities to thank them and offer any assistance that may be required in the inquiry into why this tragic accident occurred."

The Foreign Office has set up an emergency hotline for worried relatives. The number is 020 7839 1010.

webTitle: Leeds' season tarnished by golden dream

fields.headline: Leeds' season tarnished by golden dream
fields.trailText: Leeds are facing up to the possibility of losing two of their biggest stars for the first six weeks of the season, after Mark Viduka and Harry Kewell confirmed their desire to play in the Olympic Games for Australia.
fields.body:
Leeds are facing up to the possibility of losing two of their biggest stars for the first six weeks of the season, after Mark Viduka and Harry Kewell confirmed their desire to play in the Olympic Games for Australia.

Both Kewell and Viduka have been selected in the Socceroo squad for the Sydney Olympics which start on September 15th, but they have also been asked to join a training camp which commences on August 20th, the day after the start of the new Premiership season. If both players choose to join the squad, there is nothing Leeds can do to stop them.

Kewell expressed his desire to turn out for his country in a regular column for the Sydney Sunday Telegraph. The 20-year-old, currently suffering from an achilles tendon injury said: "Those know-alls who have written me off for the Olympics are way off-beam.

"Sure I'm injured right now but contrary to reports I'm still hopeful of playing the first Premier League match of the season for Leeds at home to Everton on Saturday week.

"I'm still focused on the Olympic Games as much as I ever was. Why wouldn't I be? It's a case of looking at the bigger picture. And that picture includes the Olympic Games."

Viduka echoed his compatriot's sentiments in an interview this weekend. "I always love playing for my country, for Australia," he said, "and it's very important for me to also play at home in the Sydney Olympics. I would like to play but as yet I haven't discussed it with David O'Leary."

Leeds' third choice goalkeeper, Danny Milosevic, has also been called up to the Socceroo squad.

webTitle: US relegates lottery film to TV slot

fields.headline: US relegates lottery film to TV slot
fields.trailText: After a year's deliberation, Miramax, the American distributors of an Anglo-French production of Alan Ayckbourn's The Revengers' Comedies have decided not to release the film in the US
fields.body:
The credentials of lottery-funded British movies have been called into question yet again, with the news that Hollywood has rejected another lottery-funded project.

After a year's deliberation, Miramax, the American distributors of an Anglo-French production of Alan Ayckbourn's The Revengers' Comedies have decided not to release the film in the US, reports the Daily Mail.

Fearing they would not recoup their costs in American cinemas, the distributors have sold the rights to cable TV company, Showtime, instead. Miramax executives felt the film would not appeal to an American audience and even Showtime's executive, Matthew Duda admitted 'It is a very British black comedy'.

The Revenger's Comedies is the story of a depressed businessman, played by Sam Neil who, meets unhinged aristocrat Helena Bonham Carter on Tower Bridge where they are both contemplating suicide. The two join forces to wreak revenge on the individuals who have caused them so much misery. The film also features Martin Clunes, Kristin Scott-Thomas and Steve Coogan. The project was a joint production between the BBC and a number of European companies. It was part-funded with £950,000 from the Arts Council and the lottery. However it failed to reach cinemas in Britain and was instead shown on the BBC last Christmas.

The film joins the growing ranks of other lottery-funded flops, including the 1996 slasher film Crimetime, which received £302,000 in lottery funding but only took £13,000 in its first week, and the £5.6m production Wilde, starring Stephen Fry, which received £1.5m of lottery money but despite good reviews performed poorly at the box office.

 Stills from the film on a Sam Neill fansite

webTitle: Alan Mullally on the two best balls of his career (and 12 other wickets)

fields.headline: Alan Mullally on the two best balls of his career (and 12 other wickets)
fields.standfirst: Every Monday wisden.com goes behind the scenes to get the  lowdown on one of  the performances of the week. Today we talk to Hampshire's Alan Mullally
fields.trailText: Alan Mullally's haul of 9-93 in Derbyshire's first innings against Hampshire at Derby last week was the best bowling of his career. The one wicket he did not get was that of Mathew Dowman, who made a century - and was dropped off Mullally four times. In the second innings Mullally bagged another five-for to end up with 14-188 in the match from 70.3 overs. Mullally has played 18 Tests for England, the most recent in the two-innings fifth Test against South Africa at Centurion earlier this year. We caught up with him after the match against Derbyshire had ended in a draw and asked him to talk us through his first-innings performance.
fields.body:
Alan Mullally's haul of 9-93 in Derbyshire's first innings against Hampshire at Derby last week was the best bowling of his career. The one wicket he did not get was that of Mathew Dowman, who made a century - and was dropped off Mullally four times. In the second innings Mullally bagged another five-for to end up with 14-188 in the match from 70.3 overs. Mullally has played 18 Tests for England, the most recent in the two-innings fifth Test against South Africa at Centurion earlier this year. We caught up with him after the match against Derbyshire had ended in a draw and asked him to talk us through his first-innings performance.

"I started off on a good note. The left-hander [Steve Stubbings] moved back and across to the first ball and was caught at gully. The ball was on the money - I always try to make 'em play first up. In fact, I make all the batsmen play a lot more now and it's worked - from averaging 22-23 I'm averaging around 14 this year.

"[Michael] Di Venuto played a few shots in his innings - it was like watching the highlights at times - but I bowled one closer to the stumps on middle-and-leg, it seamed away and was nicked to Kenway [Derek, the wicketkeeper]. The one I got Steve Titchard with was the second-best ball of my career: I'd moved round the wicket and bowled two successive inswingers before the Magic Ball, which seamed back in and clipped off stump. I reckon the best ball of my career was the one I bowled today to the night-watchman [to Kevin Dean in the second innings on Saturday]. Warnie came over and said, "Al, the Magic Ball." It was a round-the-wicket inswinger to the left-hander - I went for gold and clipped off stump.

"For Rob Bailey [in the first innings] there was a similar ball. He looked to get forward, but he edged it. Sutton reached 36 [having put on 91 with Mathew Dowman] before I got him with an over-the-wicket ball which he tried to drive, but just nicked to second slip [Laney]. Paul Aldred was over the wicket again, an inswinger that hit middle stump. Shah's wicket was a regular ball - on the left-hander's off-stump - and he hit it straight to the Judge [Robin Smith] at mid-on. Tim Munton was bowled with an inswinger on off-stump and to finish it off I bowled Dean, another left-hander, through the gate.

"The only wicket I didn't get was Dowman, but I had him dropped four times, twice before 19! But you never know - if I'd got him out, someone else might have come on and taken a couple of wickets later on, so you can't necessarily say I'd have got all ten. I did get him out though! [laughs] I went for a few, but I bowled quite a lot of overs in the innings and I had a decent strike rate, something like a wicket every four overs. It's a shame we dropped the catches we did - they probably cost us the game.

"I got five more today [in the second innings, for 95] which is good - I'm here to win trophies and gain respect from the lads. You speak to Warnie, he'll tell you that pressure is just the fear of failure. You've just got to accept that you have better days than others, and the lads here know I'm always trying my best. In fact, I'm in the best form of my career at the moment - Robin Smith will tell you how much I've improved. I'm enjoying my cricket now and I'm much more relaxed. webTitle: Gore selects Lieberman as running mate

fields.headline: Gore selects Lieberman as running mate
fields.trailText: US vice president and Democratic party candidate Al Gore has selected Connecticut Senator Joseph Lieberman to be his running mate - the first Jewish vice presidential candidate in American history
fields.body:
US vice president and Democratic party candidate Al Gore has selected Connecticut Senator Joseph Lieberman to be his running mate - the first Jewish vice presidential candidate in American history

Gore planned to offer Lieberman the job in a telephone call later today, according to several Democratic party sources. Lieberman has indicated he will accept.

The sources said Gore made his decision after discussions late Sunday night and early this morning with top advisers, including former Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who headed up his search process, his brother-in-law Frank Hunger, his wife Tipper and campaign chairman Bill Daley.

The vice president and his running mate are expected to appear together at a noon rally tomorrow in Nashville. Lieberman, 58, beat five other finalists: Senators Evan Bayh of Indiana, John Edwards of North Carolina, John Kerry of Massachusetts; House of representatives minority leader Dick Gephardt of Missouri and New Hampshire governor Jeanne Shaheen.

The Gore campaign hoped Lieberman's selection would be a bold stroke heading into next week's Democratic national convention in Los Angeles. He trails rival George W Bush in polls after last week's Republican convention.

A Democratic centrist, Lieberman would amplify Gore support of fiscal discipline and middle class tax cuts, the sources said.

Gore considers his pick a respected voice of independence and integrity, and the sources drew a contrast to the Republican ticket's ties to special interests. Lieberman was an outspoken critic of President Bill Clinton's conduct during the impeachment controversy.

Polls show Bush benefiting from the so-called "Clinton fatigue." Gore's selection of an Orthodox Jew is a first.

Because he and his wife Hadassah observe the Jewish Sabbath from dusk Friday to dusk Saturday, Lieberman is ostensibly prohibited from working then. The senator has interpreted this to mean he may still work during that time, but only to promote "the respect and protection of human life and well-being."

webTitle: Guinness: quotes and links

fields.headline: Sir Alec Guinness: In his own words
fields.trailText: • As a young man he would spend many evenings at the Old Vic, where he once summoned up the courage to ask John Gielgud for acting coaching. Years later Sir Alec said: "I think he mistook me for some well-off member of the brewing family."
fields.body:
 As a young man he would spend many evenings at the Old Vic, where he once summoned up the courage to ask John Gielgud for acting coaching. Years later Sir Alec said: "I think he mistook me for some well-off member of the brewing family."

 His first drama teacher, after giving him 10 lessons at £1 an hour, returned his money telling him, "You'll never learn to act".

 Sir Alec claimed it was he who persuaded director George Lucas to kill off Obi-Wan in the Star Wars films. He is reported to have said: "What I didn't tell George was that I couldn't go on speaking those bloody awful, banal lines. I'd had enough of the mumbo jumbo."

 His considerable fame left Guinness unmoved. "You can only be your own personality,'' he once said. "And I'm just happy to be an actor. If I tried to swan around, I wouldn't know how to behave. If I tried to be a superstar, I'd be a laughing stock!''

 "An actor is an interpreter of other men's words, often a soul which wishes to reveal itself to the world but dare not, a craftsman, a bag of tricks, a vanity bag, a cool observer of mankind, a child, and at his best a kind of unfrocked priest who, for an hour or two, can call on heaven and hell to mesmerise a group of innocents."

 "I gave my best performances, probably, during the war - trying to be an officer and a gentleman."

 "I am always ashamed of the slowness of my reading. I think it stems. . . from the fact that when I come across dialogue in a novel, I can't resist treating it as the text of a play and acting it out, with significant pauses and all." From his 1997 memoirs My Name Escapes Me.

 In one of the stories he told about himself, Guinness checked his hat and coat in to a restaurant cloakroom, and asks for the claim ticket. "That will not be necessary,'' the attendant smiles. Pleased at being recognised, Guinness later retrieves his garments, puts his hand in the coat pocket and finds a slip of paper on which is written, 'Bald with glasses.'

 "I always expected to die at 64. I hope to die in what they call a state of grace and in good order."

webTitle: Study to 'rule out' BSE link to milk

fields.headline: Study to 'rule out' BSE link to milk
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: The government has ordered an inquiry into whether there is a link between BSE and milk and dairy products.
fields.body:
The government has ordered an inquiry into whether there is a link between BSE and milk and dairy products.

The research, announced by Nick Brown, the minister of agriculture, follows assurances that dairy products are safe from causing variant CJD, the human form of BSE.

The food standards agency has asked scientists to carry out a three-year study into possible links "as soon as possible". They are also being told to re-examine previous studies which have given milk and dairy products the all-clear.

A spokeswoman for the Ministry of Agriculture said that the inquiry would cost £800,000. It followed a recommendation by the spongiform encephalopathy advisory committee (Seac), set up by the government to monitor the brain-wasting disease.

"Milk is safe but this research is to put it beyond doubt," the spokeswoman said. "It is a precautionary measure and previous studies have shown milk is safe."

CJD deaths have so far been blamed on eating meat from infected cattle. But some scientists are concerned that earlier studies are unreliable, and that the infective agent could be passed on through milk.

Fourteen Britons died from CJD in the first six months of this year - as many as in the whole of 1999. Since 1995 it has claimed 69 lives and Seac said that the incidence of the CJD was increasing by between 20 and 30% a year.

Last week it was reported that there have been 76 definite and probable cases of CJD in Britain, including seven possible victims still alive.

Last month the government launched an inquiry into a cluster of CJD deaths around the village of Queniborough in Leicestershire. Three of the four victims died within weeks of each other. Robert Will, head of the government's CJD surveillance unit, said at the time that baby food and school meals may have been a source of the village outbreak.

Gill Turner of the CJD Support Network welcomed news of the three-year research. "CJD is still a poorly understood disease and we welcome any research and money that is going to be invested into it.

"The concern is not knowing whether there is a risk from cow's milk. Athough there has been no evidence up to now that you can get CJD from milk, further study has to be a good thing."

Milk safety has been questioned since an interim UK study suggested that BSE could be transmitted from cow to calf. The report raised fears about possible BSE infection through milk and led to some German states blocking imports of British dairy products.

webTitle: US troops mass to fight fire

fields.headline: US troops mass to fight fire
fields.standfirst: Rockies ablaze •  Forests burn out of control
fields.trailText: Thousands of troops have been deployed across the western United States as hundreds of wildfires yesterday burned out of control, apparently impervious to bombardments by flying water tankers attempting to halt the blaze.
fields.body:
Thousands of troops have been deployed across the western United States as hundreds of wildfires yesterday burned out of control, apparently impervious to bombardments by flying water tankers attempting to halt the blaze.

President Bill Clinton is due to visit areas stricken by what has been described as the worst outbreak of forest fires in half a century. The government is spending $15m a day (about £10m) to support 20,000 civilian and military firefighters from 46 states and Canada.

The national interagency fire centre (NIFC) in Boise, Idaho, reported yesterday that there were now more than 70 large fires engulfing more than 750,000 acres in 11 states, notably Montana, California, Colorado, Nevada, Idaho and Wyoming.

Officials are alarmed that the blazes have come earlier than the usual fire season and that they are proving more difficult to contain. Some of the fires are thought to be so well established that they will only be extinguished by the arrival of snow in October or November.

"The northern Rockies is the hottest place in the country at the moment," said Lynn Pisano-Pedigo of the NIFC yesterday. She cited "dry lightning" as one of the main causes of the latest outbreak.

The weather conditions that produce dry lightning are expected to continue for several weeks - a combination of high temperatures, low humidity and rainless thunderstorms.

Temperatures have also been at record highs in many areas. Weather officials report "triple digit" temperatures in central California, making the land even more susceptible to the blazes.

Hamilton in Montana is at the centre of the main blazes and yesterday residents were warned to remain indoors because of the thick smoke engulfing the area.

More than 300 homes have been evacuated so far, and a further 300 were expected to be evacuated by late last night.

A total of 16 large fires were raging in the state, covering 135,000 acres. In Nevada, a helicopter carrying a firefighting crew crashed near Elko, killing one member and injuring three others.

In Colorado, the Mesa Verde national park was having to deal with a blaze that threatened the park's research centre and museum. More than 400 firefighters were trying to save the threatened parts of the forest, which is a popular holiday place, aided by helicopters and seven air tankers flying in to drop water on the blaze.

In California, the US forest service reported that there were more than 100 wildfires blazing and that some were in areas of brush that have not burned in more than 100 years. Two hundred people were evacuated from Jackson, Wyoming, three days ago and have still not been able to return to their homes.

Troops are being trained as temporary firefighters. More than 500 soldiers were dispatched from Fort Hood in Texas yesterday after training, to join 500 other soldiers and 500 marines fighting the fires in Idaho. A further 500 were sent to Montana to back up a beleaguered and exhausted fire crew.

The head of the US forest service, Mike Dombeck, said yesterday that the situation was now so serious that Canadian firefighting crews were having to be brought in to help.

Since the start of this year, there have been about 62,000 wildfires across the US. They have engulfed 3.76m acres of forest, almost double the 10-year average.

One of the reasons for this dramatic increase has been that people are going deeper and deeper into forested areas in the search for seclusion. Wherever there are humans, there is the risk of fires - usually started accidentally, from cigarette ends and barbecues, but sometimes lit deliberately.

It is now relatively common for people to start fires and then call the fire service and give themselves a heroic role in fighting the blazes.

However, while it would make ecological sense to stop people living in such areas, there would be a political price to pay in restricting residential areas.

Marines have been using various techniques to try to contain the blazes, ranging from bombing the fires from above with a mixture of slurry and water, to fighting fire with fire - burning swaths of undergrowth themselves to create firebreaks.

But unless weather patterns change, they appear to be fighting a losing battle.

webTitle: Sir Alec Guinness

fields.headline: Sir Alec Guinness
fields.trailText: The best-known and loved English actor of the 20th century, Sir Alec Guinness who has died aged 86, was by nature an unostentatious and reserved man. Though he undertook a great variety of roles, all were informed, at heart, with the wisdom of the sad clown.
fields.body:
The best-known and loved English actor of the 20th century, Sir Alec Guinness who has died aged 86, was by nature an unostentatious and reserved man. Though he undertook a great variety of roles, all were informed, at heart, with the wisdom of the sad clown.

It was that spiritual severity, together with those clear, wide-open eyes - capable of melting in close-up on screen into the most reassuringly serene of smiles - which lent his performances force and authenticity. In his later career, he became something of an icon of spirituality and enlightened human understanding - especially after his 1977 performance as Obi-Wan Kenobi in Star Wars.

His contract with George Lucas, guaranteed him two per cent of the profit: though the role had been much reduced, and he had almost left the production. The resulting financial security made this already fastidious actor even choosier about live stage roles. After Star Wars he appeared in only two West End plays, and was an unusual and sensitive Shylock at Chichester (1984).

But Guinness was not the first great actor to find the ability and the inclination to learn parts after 70 much reduced. He had avoided the theatre for six years before starring as TE Lawrence in Rattigan's Ross in 1960. More than any other English star of his generation, he was equally at home on stage, in film and on the television screen - where he had an Indian summer as John Le Carré's spymaster George Smiley.

Guinness had an impecunious childhood, and a modest south-coast boarding school education. At 18 he found employment as a junior copywriter in an advertising agency.

He describes in his discreet autobiography Blessings In Disguise (1985) how the acting bug had bitten him. On the recommendation of John Gielgud he contacted the formidable and eccentric Martita Hunt - the first woman he had ever met with silk trousers and painted toenails, he later wrote. She coached him for a RADA Leverhulme scholarship audition. But RADA was not giving the award that year, so he enrolled instead at the Fay Compton studio for as long as his money lasted (John Le Mesurier was a fellow student) and then went to work in the London theatre, debuting aged 20 in Libel! at the Playhouse.

In his unpretentious and beautifully written book, he exorcised a long-suppressed anxiety about his origins. He was, he made clear, illegitimate - his name a mystery, his father probably called Geddes, the circumstances of his conception, vague. For the rest, Guinness told the tale of his life obliquely, its focus firmly on loved ones and friends rather than on himself. He was there, as it were, in reflection.

Finally the question of his birth didn't matter to him, but in the beginning it must have. A reluctance to put himself in the spotlight - an almost neurotic discretion - was the mark of both his professional and personal style. In a 1953 monograph about him published by Rockliff, Kenneth Tynan wrote: "Were he to commit a murder, I have no doubt the number of false arrests following the circulation of his description would break all records."

While still only 20 he was a flowery Osric in Gielgud's Hamlet at the New theatre. Thereafter until the war, his career was spent at Old Vic, where he impressed with a modern-dress Hamlet in autumn 1938.

He always denied having any technique as an actor - or knowing what technique might be. Yet he was proud of his gift.

For Guinness the purpose of acting was to make-believe. The theatre was an act of faith, whose object was to tell the inner truth about situations and feelings, not to embroider falsehood with trickery and display. He was a master of disguise as he demonstrated in the Ealing comedy Kind Hearts and Coronets (1949), with an emotionally thankless multiplicity of roles. Denis Price, the villain at the centre, was the sort of charming role that Guinness later made his own, through a series of famous Ealing Studio hits.

But the Kind Hearts gallery of family victims was consciously broad brush. Guinness was an actor, not an entertainer or vaudevillian. The spiritual core of Guinness's inner conviction remained the same - whatever game of disguise he might play.

His conversion to Roman Catholicism followed an episode during the 1954 shooting of Father Brown (called The Detective in the US), in which he played GK Chesterton's cheery cleric. Walking back in the dark, still in a cassock, to the station hotel of a village near Macon after a drink in the local bar with Peter Finch, his hand was seized by a small boy, a complete stranger, who called him "Mon père" and trotted along beside him chatting in French.

Despite his phony credentials as a cleric, Guinness felt strongly that the reality of this trust was important. When his 11-year-old son Matthew was temporarily crippled from the waist down with polio, Guinness had taken to dropping in on church and praying. Shortly after Father Brown, he joined the church of Rome.

As an actor, he had acute and particular tastes, an infallible instinct for the apt moment, the ideal tone, the canny strategy. When he was Fool to Laurence Olivier's unsuccessful King Lear (1947), Guinness said that Olivier had been irritated that he had received the lion's share of the reviewers' favour. This was, said Guinness, a direct consequence of Larry's actor-managerish vanity. "Every time Larry came on stage, the lights went up in his vicinity. All I had to do was just stay very close to him." Guinness, of course, couldn't fail to be noticed if only because he was doing so little so well.

He knew his own vulnerabilities and exploited them with courage, to give some of his best performances. He had resented, for instance, Olivier's assumption in the mid-thirties that he was John Gielgud's boyfriend. Not because he could not have been, or was ashamed or offended to be cast in that role, but because he was not and they had no reason to assume it. In 1938 Guinness became a scrupulous husband and father - though his sexuality was complex.

Typically he did not balk at playing the transvestite professional criminal Mrs Artminster in Wise Child (1967) with the then glamorous-looking Simon Ward. His Lawrence in Ross rang dangerously true to self. Being mixed-up, discreet, acutely intelligent and voraciously well-read fuelled the neurotic-but-muffled engine that drove him as an artist.

Being so private a personality let him bring out the normally hidden interior aspects of Harcourt Reilly in TS Eliot's Cocktail Party. He played this role, the Unidentified Guest, at Chichester, the Wyndham's and the Haymarket in 1968 and 1969, as well as in Edinburgh and New York in 1950. His reading of Eliot's Four Quartets on radio was spell-binding. He was perfect material for Alan Bennett's Old Country (1977) and Habeas Corpus (1973). In the latter he devised and performed alone a typically self-revealing dance at the end.

Tynan's fine portrait of him misinterpreted the diffidence and humility. Guinness, Tynan wrote, "never will be a star in the sense that Olivier isHe does everything by stealthHe will illumine many a blind alley of subtlety, but blaze no trailsHis stage presence is quite without amplitude; and his face, except when, temporarily, make-up transfigures it, is a signless zero."

The suggestiveness, the wish to avoid being domineering, was a different sort of contract with the audience's imagination. Guinness also wielded glacial fierceness and terror with authority.

His greatness materialised without Olivier's showmanship, Richardson's abandoned cussedness, and Gielgud's resonant lyricism. Tynan admired but was inclined to patronise Guinness's poetry and versatility.

At 24, in 1951, the critic was engaged by Guinness as Player King in his second Hamlet. Guinness invested much amour propre in this production. Tynan called it "Hamlet with the pilot dropped" and said it was cast with "exuberant oddness". Its failure turned out to be a major factor in Guinness's move away from the classics and Shakespeare and into films, ultimately television, and new plays.

Tynan found Guinness less potent in the classical arena because he expected actors to perform like concerto soloists. I did not see Guinness's inspirational Richard II for Ralph Richardson's Old Vic company at the New theatre (now Albery) in 1947. His Macbeth at the Royal Court (1966) was certainly a quiet, clipped tragic victim without the expected sexiness and physicality, and handicapped by Simone Signoret's characterful, impossibly Gallic English as Lady M. (Gielgud's 1961 Stratford Othello was also criticised for lacking diapason.)

In fact, Guinness was an actor for a new theatrical style, subtle and undecorated. From the 1960s in the West End he mostly created roles in new plays rather than challenging memories of Gielgud, Richardson or Olivier. He might have been a marvellous and unusual Lear, but when he took the role on radio it was underwhelming.

Though his work in Alan Bennett's plays was superb, he was far less inclined, at the end of his career, to accept the sort of risks that Gielgud - secure in a theatrical dynasty - famously did with Pinter, David Storey and Julian Mitchell.

He was always a bit of a social upstart in an English theatre world full of great families, a self-made actor with no advantages, spotted by Gielgud and Guthrie, but dependent on a very spiritual stillness and charisma. When in the mid-seventies I first met Guinness, who had long been an idol, he had a slightly grand shyness off-stage. Yet, of all the great British stage actors, his was the busiest film career, for which his modest way of acting was unrivalled.

He was not only an actor. He was good at drawing and produced a charming, diffident design for his own Christmas cards each year. Like Caruso he was a natural at caricatures, especially of himself. He was also a very able author.

His adaptation of The Brothers Karamazov, directed by Peter Brook in 1946, marked his return to the stage (as Mitya) after war service in the Royal Navy. Earlier, just before the war, his stage version of Great Expectations (later the basis of David Lean's film) had been directed by George Devine.

After playing Herbert Pocket in Lean's Great Expectations, and Fagin in Oliver Twist, he went on to a series of glorious Ealing comedies - perhaps most memorably as the crook Henry Holland in Crichton's Lavender Hill Mob, and as Professor Marcus, another crook in Mackendrick's Ladykillers.

His greatest film role was probably Colonel Nicholson in Lean's Bridge on the River Kwai (1957), where his quintessentially English stiff upper lip and obsessive unreasonableness under, eventually, dreadful Japanese maltreatment won him an Oscar and numerous other prizes.

Further award-winning work included the artist Gulley Jimson in The Horse's Mouth, with his own screenplay based on Joyce Carey's novel. It was a pity that his brilliantly unpleasant Scottish impersonation of Jock Sinclair in Tunes of Glory (1960) was not followed by a lot of other good starring roles with the exception of Dorrit in Christine Edzard's epic Dickens adaptation. He settled mostly for lucrative supporting parts in various blockbusters, including Cromwell, The Comedians and The Quiller Memorandum.

Some were quite distinguished - like Lean's Doctor Zhivago, Lawrence of Arabia and A Passage to India. In The Fall of the Roman Empire, his Marcus Aurelius was one of the film's few redeeming features. Little Dorrit and his television appearances in Le Carré's Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy and its sequels, were effectively his screen monument.

Guinness was a charming, fascinating and elusive companion. He did not enjoy playing the star, though he liked the respect he got when visiting famous restaurants. He lived in a modest way ouside Petersfield from the mid-1950s, with a large garden that much occupied his wife Merula. He had a small circle of particular friends, many outside the theatre. For years he and Merula were close to Rachel Kempson and Michael Redgrave. He was knighted in 1959.

If one visited him in his dressing room in the West End in the 1970s one might find a surprisingly broad collection of people there, many of whom were never destined to discover what the others' link with the great actor might be. He preferred to keep his friends separate: a one to one person. He liked good food and drink. His favourite London hotel for years was the Connaught, with its superb cuisine. He was essentially not a club man. Anybody outside his close immediate circle was intrigued by the Guinness enigma.

But the reserve through which that attractive generosity and warmth powerfully shone was, for him, an impenetrable and necessary protection.

webTitle: Sir Alec Guinness dies, aged 86

fields.headline: Sir Alec Guinness dies, aged 86
fields.trailText: The legendary actor Sir Alec Guinness has died aged 86.
fields.body:
The legendary actor Sir Alec Guinness has died aged 86.

The star of films such as the Bridge Over the River Kwai and Lawrence of Arabia, he died on Saturday evening at the King Edward VII Hospital, in Midhurst, West Sussex, after taking ill at his home on Thursday. His death was not announced until early today.

A spokesman for the hospital said Sir Alec had died "very peacefully". He would not identify the cause of death, but Sir Alec had been in poor health for a number of years.

Sir Alec's acting career spanned 60-years and ranged from Shakespearian classics to Ealing comedies, and his acclaimed television portrayal of the spymaster Smiley.

In 1959 he won an Oscar for his role as the colonel in the classic Bridge Over the River Kwai, a role which also led to his knighthood the same year.

The younger generation will remember him for his role as Obi-Wan Kenobi in George Lucas' 1977 film Star Wars.

Despite the phenomenal success of the film it was a role that the veteran actor despised saying he threw all the fan mail away unopened.

The son of a banker, he always wanted to be an actor as a boy and often walked three miles from his home in Bayswater, central London, to the Old Vic to spend his pocket money on watching performances there.

He married the playwright Merula Salaman in 1938, and had one son, Matthew.
