webTitle: Nick knack Sun muscles in on Big Brother

fields.headline: Nick knack Sun muscles in on Big Brother
fields.trailText: The media circus around the TV show Big Brother took another bizarre twist last night when a newspaper tried to drop leaflets on the house urging its remaining occupants to kick out "Nasty Nick".
fields.body:
The media circus around the TV show Big Brother took another bizarre twist last night when a newspaper tried to drop leaflets on the house urging its remaining occupants to kick out "Nasty Nick".

Nick, 32, a London insurance broker who claims to be a vice-chairman of Fulham Football Club, has been shown on the Channel 4 programme to be plotting against the other occupants.

But thus far he has not been nominated to be voted out.

The intervention yesterday by the Sun newspaper, which hired a helicopter to fly over the Big Brother house, was an attempt to tip off the other occupants of the house to Nick's activities before they decide today on which of their number would be nominated for the chop.

The last participant remaining in the house will win £70,000.

The Sun helicopter managed to drop about 40 leaflets in the vicinity of the house and its grounds but only a few landed in the garden.

A spokesman for the show said the company was now going to tighten the security regime and was considering hiring barrage balloons to repel further airborne attacks.

Last Friday Andrew, a twentysomething sales manager, became the second person to be ejected from the house. His exit came as a shock to him and the general public who had expected Nick to be the most vulnerable. A campaign against the smooth talking Londoner has been waged in several tabloid newspapers.

Last night the Sun was not owning up to its stunt. A staff member said: "I'm completely unaware of this."

webTitle: Nova: Right idea, wrong decade?

fields.headline: Right idea, wrong decade?
fields.standfirst: Caroline Roux on an editorial clear out at Nova and IPC's attempt to re-create 'that 60s and 70s thing'
fields.trailText: Caroline Roux on an editorial clear out at Nova and IPC's attempt to re-create 'that 60s and 70s thing'
fields.body:
It can't possibly have been intentional. The August edition of Nova, which opened with a jokey and seasonal editor's letter - a postcard simply saying Deborah Bee is on holiday - arrived on the same day as the news that Bee's holiday was going to be an exceptionally long one.

As is so often the case with new magazines, Bee is leaving the job after producing only a handful of issues.

Whether she was as proactive about standing down as her employers IPC would like to make out is of course open to question. The industry rumour suggests that IPC was not happy with the millennial relaunch of the 1960s icon. There's nothing like a bad advertising audit to upset the company applecart, and Nova has seemed a little on the light side in pagination. But the magazine's publisher, Elaine Foran, insists it is "definitely on budget" - not just on target, in fact, but better than IPC had hoped in terms of both circulation and advertising.

There is also the question of whether Bee was happy to go. She is still answering her phone but unable, she politely regrets, to answer any questions at the moment.

Nova has not had an easy ride since it reappeared on May 4. The 1960s incarnation of the magazine is upheld by designers and journalists as a truly provocative, trail-blazing, mould-breaking publication, in which the images and layouts shouted as loudly as the campaigning words.

Looking back over those old issues (it stayed the course from 1965 until IPC pulled it in the mid-70s), not many of them measure up to its shining reputation. The ones that do, however, where the directness and sheer courage of an idea is not naive but genuinely confrontational, are remarkable: a cover image of a black man with a single cover line asking if you would really want him to be your neighbour still sends a shiver down the spine.

"The idea of the relaunch stank from the start," says Chris Hemblade, acting editor of Time Out and former features editor of Scene, the now-defunct fashion magazine where Bee was editor. "Every art director uses Nova as a model, an ideal. But this relaunch felt like a bunch of publishing executives wanting to bring back something they'd felt good about in the past. It was bound to be a poor imitation."

The view from IPC is, as you'd expect, quite different. "Everything Nova stands for is all the vogue again," says Julie York, the company's director of corporate communications. "That 60s and 70s thing."

Such literalism seems rather ingenuous from such a giant of publishing. The prevailing "60s and 70s thing" emerges from the fact that many current opinion- and taste-makers and media-ites grew up in the 60s and 70s. Their - our - take on the world is certainly informed by values from those decades, but it is liberally reinterpreted for the society we live in today.

To be fair to Bee, her original plan wasn't to redo Nova. Bee, then editor of Scene, approached IPC along with Scene's features editor, David Roberts, and its art director, Gerard Saint, with an idea for an intelligent high-fashion magazine aimed at 18- to 25-year-old women. They reckoned there was a gap in the market and that they could produce a niche product to fill it.

IPC had long toyed with the idea of a Nova relaunch - it nearly happened 10 years ago, but came out as Marie Claire instead. "It was something being talked about," says Elaine Foran. "And then Deborah came up with an idea that was so similar that we put the two ideas together."

Now Jeremy Langmead is waiting to fill Bee's still-warm seat, and hoping to take over early in October. He has been the editor of the Sunday Times Style magazine for the past five years and sees Nova as "a creative challenge".

Echoing the words of Bee, Roberts et al, he describes his reader as "intelligent, twenty-something, fashion conscious - Stella McCartney or Chloe Sevigny". (Let's hope he really means those who aspire to be SM and CS, or he might be terribly disappointed.) He is convinced that there is an elusive gap somewhere between Vogue and Elle.

"I feel confident," he enthuses. "About having a market, knowing it's there. Vogue has got older - it's Lady Helen Windsor and Mario Testino. And Elle's gone much younger - it's the Denise Van Outen of women's magazines. So I'm pitching between the mummies and the dummies."

Langmead's profile has recently been raised by the publicity surrounding a novel by his ex, India Knight, in which some claimed to see parallels between him and the heroine's husband.

Mischievously witty, he is known for his skill and tact in handling contributors, having cultivated AA Gill as Style's restaurant critic and Tara Palmer-Tomkinson as a columnist. The Style section has a formidable record as a launchpad (alumnae include the novelists Helen Fielding and Wendy Holden). The experience of seeing his deputy Liz Jones - now occupying Tara P-T's old slot in Style with her Bridget Jones-style column - chosen as editor of Marie Claire might well have convinced him that it was time to move on.

Langmead's suitability, according to Foran, is his experience. "He can manage a large team and recognise good writing. And he understands how a fashion magazine works."

He will undoubtedly take people with him, and Nova will inevitably shed a few more original staff. Fashion-pack gossip suggests that Venetia Scott, the fashion director, could walk, taking not just her husband, photographer Juergen Teller, but a whole raft of heavyweight names, including photographers Terry Richardson and David Sims and stylist Nancy Rhode.

It's a group of people summed up by one insider as "having enough clout to work between Vogue and iD, if they choose to". If they go, a great deal of the title's credibility goes with them. But the idea of credibility hangs heavy here. And that isn't Nova's or anyone else's fault, but the problem in general with general-interest magazines, even those focused on fashion.

For all the potential twenty-something readers out there, it's a group that has proven to be notoriously fickle and since it knows how to access information from a variety of places and media - television and the internet are huge providers - is less likely to be loyal to one magazine.

When it does come to print, magazines seem to function better the more tightly they are bound to one subject. Outstanding among current successful titles are Mixmag, the dance culture bible, and Wallpaper, the aspirational design bible. Both offer finely honed content to readers according to a specific interest rather than a demographic evaluation.

That, along with Nova's difficult heritage, has so far stood in the way of it relaxing into a comfortable role. An ex-employee of Frank, the Wagadon title launched in 1997 that took a stab at a similar market, says: "It has made an effort to take on the values of old Nova - to be a strong, meaty, social read, dealing with bigger issues. But although we do want to be made aware, pulling it off in this context is very difficult."

Under pressure to reflect the title's earlier interests, we get Celia Brayfield on why women are still underachieving in the 21st century. With no disrespect to the writer, it made me think I was back in the 70s being lectured by someone's well-meaning mother in a pine-filled kitchen in Camden.

Langmead needs to hold on to his fashion team, which is what currently makes this product into the jewel in the crown that IPC wants it to be. He wants to get rid of the magazine's slightly irritable tone, and introduce a softer, more comforting voice.

Twenty-something girls might be a prickly, strident bunch these days, but it's dangerous - and unwelcoming - to interpret that too literally. Magazines work by becoming familiar and friendly.

There's a reason that the idea of "curling up" with them has become a cliche. By his own admission, Langmead wants to "make it more bubbly, really heat it up". At least it's already warm.

Re-creation or poor imitation? Twenty-five years on and off Carolyne Ellis

The original Nova was part of its time, it's a different time now, so it's difficult to do the same thing. Nova's strength was that it was irreverent, clever and quite shocking, and visually very strong. There are a lot of magazines these days and to succeed you must be different. Alexandra Shulman, Vogue

It was a good idea to revive the title, but I don't know how relevant that style of journalism - provocative and groundbreaking then - is now. There's little that shocks today. The magazine was pretty much what we expected - edgy and niche. And if that's what they tried to create, then they've achieved it. Fiona McIntosh, Elle

I love the [first] cover. It was a nice mix of the 60s and the year 2000. I love the model, I love the fashion - it's nice having a purely fashion magazine again. Some of it does try to please too much. It's a little bit prickly, not apologising about anything. It says, 'this is what we do and if you don't like it, that's tough'. Liz Jones, Marie Claire

They've got a strong team and the cover and the logo are strong, too. But I felt that it fell between two stools: it was not for the London hipster and it was not mainstream either. I don't think it's a timely or a clever idea. I have been a big fan of the original, but for a first issue it fell short of my expectations. Johnny Davis, The Face

From super Nova to not so super Nova

* The original Nova ran from 1965 to 1975 and achieved near mythic status. It re-wrote the rules of women's magazines and fashion journalism, becoming the 60s style bible.

* Previously women's magazines meant knitting patterns and cooking recipes. Homosexuality and abortion were taboo. Breaking down cultural, moral and sexual prejudices became Nova's aim. One 1967 cover story dealing with homosexual law reform showed two men above the words: "They consent in private". A 1969 cover featured child killer Mary Bell.

* Editor Dennis Hackett attributed Nova's success to its ability to appeal to both sexes: "We were read by women and men. We had a 42% male readership - the highest of any women's magazine."

* Contributors included home editor Janet Fitch, comic strip writer Peter Preston, cookery expert Elizabeth David, writer Penny Vincenzi and astrologer Patrick Walker.

* But by the early 70s Nova was losing its editorial and innovatory edge. IPC decided to kill the title in 1975.

* On announcing last November that Nova was going to be revived 25 years on, IPC insisted it was not a nostalgia trip - the free, incisive spirit of the original would be preserved but adapted to the concerns of 21st-century women. The mission statement burbled that Nova would set out to be "fresh" and "contemporary", and provided a profile of "Nova woman". Nova woman wore Prada, Gucci, Joseph and French Connection. She liked Kate Moss, Deborah Harry, Blind Date and Ewan MacGregor. She believed in fashion magazines not magazine fashion, sexual equality not feminism, drugs not drug abuse, details not packaging.

* According to editor Deborah Bee there was a three-fold prototype: "The triangle we had as our working model was the style press, which is incredibly cool, the fashion mags, which deal with the catwalk very well, and newspapers, which have the best writing. Our woman is right in the middle of that triangle and wants something from all of those." Editors of rival magazines - talking above to the Independent - responded coolly to her debut issue, however.

* The Competition: Red (launched: 1998, circ: 180,000); Elle (launched: 1985, circ: 210,000); Marie Claire, (launched: 1988, circ: 450,000).

webTitle: Wheels: Citroën's mini MPV

fields.headline: Picasso: the blue period
fields.standfirst: Citroën's mini MPV is easy, light and the roof peels off. Never mind the quality, feel the space, says  Giles Smith
fields.trailText: Citroën's mini MPV is easy, light and the roof peels off. Never mind the quality, feel the space, says Giles Smith.
fields.body:
Car names tend to come in thematic clusters, according to fashion: ski resorts, say, or British university towns, or winds. So one wonders where Citroën are going with their new Xsara Picasso, in which, in one of art history's less predictable moves, one of the most influential painters of the 20th century comes to endorse posthumously a five-seater miniature multipurpose vehicle with air-conditioning and CD player as standard. Next up, perhaps, the Constable - bucolic but reliable. Or maybe the Munch - ugly to look at, but an absolute scream to drive.

You'll know you have an original Picasso by the signatures - one jauntily sprayed on each side of the car. How strange to see the name attached to something which is so clearly an imitation, if not actually a forgery. Citroën have gone to the well-established Renault Scenic for the Picasso's look and layout and haven't really forced the idea for ward, beyond adding a few bits of plastic and a couple of eccentric gimmicks, and then giving the whole thing a re-spray in a variety of eye-tingling colours.

The Renault Scenic was the mini MPV and a smart compromise: a people carrier for people who realised that they needed to drive children and large amounts of junk around but still wanted a vehicle on which the back end came round the corner at roughly the same time as the front end. It's a popular notion (350,000 Scenics are sold annually in Europe), so you can't blame Citroën for wanting to muscle in, along with Fiat with their Multipla and Vauxhall with their Zafira.

What they've come up with is easy to drive and suprisingly light on its wheels given the height and width. And you can peel the roof clean off, which is not an option with the Renault, barring an accident with a low bridge. Clearly top-removal has come a long way at Citroën since the days of the 2CV, which used to fea ture a square of canvas and a couple of paperclips. That said, even with a fully automatic push-button system in place, a hint of Vichy France remains in the way the Picasso's cloth roof concertinas its way to the back of the car. Why does one feel this mechanism isn't built to last? You can feel that about the car generally. I introduced a one-year-old into the rear of the Picasso, closed the door on him and waited. In less than 30 seconds he had located, pulled down and snapped clean off the aeroplane-style seatback tray in front of him.

But never mind the quality, feel the space. Space is, after all, what the market seems to be screaming for. The Picasso has a cavernous boot. You could stage an exhibition in there. And the handbrake is hard up against the driver's seat and the gear-shift is mounted in the dashboard rather than on the floor - a throw-back to the old and admirably cranky Citroëns of the past, but also a policy decision, designed to free up space between the front seats and enable you to get into the back of the car without going out of the door first.

This makes good sense in any number of imaginable child-related scenarios but I don't suppose anyone who is over four foot six could manage it comfortably. Also, it's worth remembering: if you can get to them in the back, they can get to you in the front. Particularly if they aren't over four foot six. Generally the Picasso ditches the unfussiness of the Scenic for something more frothy and - dare I use the word - "fun". Note the eye-shaped headlights, the grinning grille, the badge where the nose might be - no other car on the market resembles a Pokémon so closely.

Meanwhile, the instrument panel - an ovoid recess in the acreage of plastic between you and the bottom of the windscreen - owes very little to Cubism and quite a lot to the deck of the Starship Enterprise. The bright green display deals mostly in pictures: a big padlock with the lock sprung to let you know that the doors are unlocked; a radio mast emitting sound waves to let you know the radio is on. Meanwhile, in the absence of the conventional dial, giant green numerals flitter up and down telling you how fast you are going.

Less insultingly, the designers seem to have put a lot of energy into stowage. The car has a boggling 30 different compartments, pockets and holders. It's a filing clerk's dream. Cans, coins, cups, papers - Citroën have thought of everything and then created a dedicated lump of moulded plastic for it. There is even a ticket-clip on the windscreen to facilitate paying and displaying. The Picasso stops only just short of providing an external one for traffic wardens.

But there's more. Honda may well have perfected the pop-out picnic table, but Citroën go up another notch with the pop-out basket-on-wheels. I must have missed the moment when the cry went up across Europe for in-car shopping trolleys, but Citroën heard the call and swooped. Accordingly, stowed neatly in the Picasso's boot (and not as an extra, note, but as a standard), is what Citroën refers to bravely as "the Modubox" - your very own, detachable, fold-away shopping basket on wheels. Never again need you be caught without a trolley you can pull along by its handle.

Somehow, I don't think Renault will be trembling.

The lowdown Citroën Xsara Picasso 1.8 SX

Price: £14,625

Maximum speed: 118 mph

Acceleration: 0-62 in 10.8 seconds

Petrol Consumption: 36.7 mpg (combined)

At the wheel: Sally Gunnell

On the stereo: Now That's What I Call Music 48

En route for: Homebase

webTitle: Rumours Unlimited

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All the rumours hit straight back down the ground for six by a talented West Indian batsman
fields.trailText: Sol Campbell "looks certain" to join Manchester United at the end of the season, according to a report in the Daily Mail. He will be a free agent by then, and will pocket a signing-on fee of "at least" £5m.
fields.body:
Sol Campbell "looks certain" to join Manchester United at the end of the season, according to a report in the Daily Mail. He will be a free agent by then, and will pocket a signing-on fee of "at least" £5m.

If Campbell joins, he could be greeted on arrival by Lazio striker Marcelo Salas, who is interested in moving to Old Trafford, according to onefootball.com. "If Mr Ferguson wants to come and talk, I will be happy to consider what he has to say," the Chilean striker announced. "I've always liked English football but I cannot say more until someone takes this further. Personally, I don't exclude anything." The Italian champions could be prepared to sell after buying Hernan Crespo, but it's not all good news for United - Lazio will insist on getting Jaap Stam in exchange.

Lazio are also after Harry Kewell - they will offer Leeds £20m for a player they have described as "the best young striker in the Premier League".

Leeds and Barcelona will go head to head in a £15m battle for the signature of Rio Ferdinand. West Ham are reluctant to get rid of their young defender, but they are unlikely to turn down a large bid. Barcelona will start the bidding by offering Harry Redknapp £12m plus Dutch international defender Winston Bogarde.

Arsenal, who are waiting to hear if their bid for Bordeaux striker Sylvain Wiltord has been successful, are in negotiations with Latvian winger Andrejs Rubins. The Skonto Riga player has been on trial at Highbury and would cost £2m.

Israeli midfielder Idan Tal will sign for Everton in a £750,000 deal. The 24-year-old Maccabi Petah Tikva player will undergo a medical and discuss personal terms today before signing a five-year-deal. webTitle: Lisa St Aubin de Terán celebrates balmy evenings

fields.headline: The house of jasmine
fields.standfirst: In the first of a four-part series in which acclaimed writers relect on summer nights, Lisa St Aubin de Terán celebrates balmy evenings, lazy conversation and the sound of nightingales at her Umbrian home
fields.trailText: In the first of a four-part series in which acclaimed writers relect on summer nights,  Lisa St Aubin de Terán  celebrates balmy evenings, lazy conversation and the sound of nightingales at her Umbrian home
fields.body:
For the last 20 years, most of my August nights have been spent in Italy, of late in Umbria, halfway up a hill cloaked in oak woods. Spring is something that local people speak of with nostalgia, relegated to a day or two between snowfall and heatwave. If you blink, you miss it. Summer is now a season that runs from April to October.

The English are notorious for their dreary obsession with the weather. Yet I have found that wherever I have lived or travelled, in whatever culture, the weather is a subject of constant comment and frequent local analysis. Italians tend to commence every other conversation with a temperature check. In winter, it is cold, and in summer, of course, it is hot - "fa caldo". This is a phrase repeated so often and with such vehemence that an English tourist was heard to enquire "Why is everyone so down on Aldo in the summer?"

Meteorological inanities aside, in summer Italy is deliciously hot. Living, as my family does, in a rambling terracotta refrigerator during the winter, we appreciate the near- magical transformation of our house into a pleasantly cool summer residence as much as any tourist could.

April to October is the high season for tourism in Italy in general, and it is the high season for guests - dozens of them. Forty-four staying at any one time is our (pretty uncomfortable) record, 10 or 12 is the norm. There are regulars, first and foremost my eldest daughter and her family. And there is Otto, the one-time revolutionary, my oldest and dearest friend, who makes an annual pilgrimage to Umbria from Venezuela. Then there are over-lapping trails of family and friends, and friends of friends. Most of our guests are artists, but they don't have to be. The one thing they do have to be is good company in the evenings (we can all be as dull as we choose during the day); the other house rules are - not to be sick in the house; and not to get tired and emotional in the kitchen.

When it comes to guests, I am a lot more Latin American than English. Some of our visitors have stayed for years on end and I have thoroughly enjoyed their company. During the day, though, I relax my duties as hostess, pulling the strings again each evening from dinner onwards. I am the designated cook.

So summer evenings start, for me, with a trawl through the herb garden, gathering whatever I need for supper that night, carefully pulling taragon, parsley, chives, salads and so on, from between the rampant weeds that flourish among them. Gardening is a little more than a hobby - more, really, of an overriding obsession. Years of experience have shown me that its discussion is not to everybody's taste, so I'll let it go here with only a mention of its main contribution to every summer night in the guise of its heady fragrance. There is a long, high, hedge of honeysuckle and jasmine beside the house, there are pots of lilies and beds of mock orange, roses, lavender and rosemary. All these scents waft through the balmy twilight, although, the later it gets, the lingering smells are always those of the jasmine and the lemon flowers.

Anyone who believes that living in the countryside is a haven of peace and quiet is mistaken. There is a nightly cacophony which breaks down, more or less, as follows. From afar, frogs croak with intermittent but almost deafening insistence. This is overlaid by cicadas, which are utterly tuneless but seem to be endlessly tuning up. There is, in the middle distance, the sound of water playing in the fountain. Then, nearer, the breeze in the cypress trees.

In a huge oak tree behind the herb garden a nightingale sings to the delight of the new guests and the distaste of old ones. This is year three. This nightingale has five notes. I remember the pleasure I first felt on hearing it outside my window, blessed as any oriental princess by its clear song. Any song on a perpetual loop palls in the end, particularly if the loop is only a few seconds long. Often now, on summer nights, I ponder the wisdom and sanity of those Chinese emperors who sacked entire kingdoms in search of a nightingale. And, if there are any searchers left out there, they can have mine.

Meanwhile, the younger children (either two or four 10-year-olds headed by my daughter, Florence, and grandson, Felix) have beaten a retreat after dinner, scavenged pro visions for their camp out on a garden terrace, and retired in good order to their adventure.

Unless we others choose to go down to the lake, which is only four minutes away, but which I am usually too lazy to adjourn to, we are not unduly plagued by mosquitoes. But there are always one or two. Like the Carib Indians who lined up on the shore of Guyana to scare off Sir Walter Raleigh and his men, they seem to be constantly running around and lining up to give the impression of being legion.

Against the backdrop of so many miscellaneous noises, there is always music - Cuban, Malian, blues, opera - whatever is topping the house charts that week. And over the music, there is talk, lots of it, from huge round-table discussions to splinter groups, with heated debates on everything from painting to malicious gossip.

After about one o'clock, the group begins to thin. Since I sleep very little, I am often the last up. I like wandering around the house at night when everyone else is asleep. It is one of my favourite times for reading.

In fact, I like summer nights so much that I decided to skip winter altogether and head off, en famille, to the Caribbean for six months. A lot of our regular visitors came out to stay with us, so the house-party feeling extended to the tiny island of Nevis. Despite having had a lovely time on that island paradise - who couldn't? - I found summer lovelier when preceded by some good, bracing cold.

The mosquitoes were monstrous, and the entire island was beleaguered by wild donkeys which brayed, stampeded and fornicated astonishingly loudly from dusk till dawn. Island conversation, when the island is minuscule and lives for tourism, can get on to a loop only marginally longer than a nightingale's. Most of these churlish reflections were not uppermost in my mind during the months I lived on Nevis. They surfaced, gradually, while contemplating the hosts of fireflies around our house in Umbria. Having said that, I'd go back to the Caribbean any day, but only for a holiday strategically planned in, say, February, for a few weeks. Summer in Italy is too good to need to travel in the hopes of reproducing it.

Although I love having guests, I don't go out very much. But for the last five years I have had a lot to do with the Umbrian film festival. This takes place in the first week of July in the small Renaissance hill town of Montone.

We drop a huge screen over the facade of a palazzo in the main square and then sit out in the cafes watching movies until the wee hours. When our film festival is over, I do stir myself to sit out in squares around the neighbouring cities watching their selection of films alla Cinema Paradiso under the stars.

Mostly, though, summer nights are spent at home, with motley concerts and shows put on by the household. The last one was an adult puppet show which was a cross between Little Red Riding Hood and Reservoir Dogs. It was put on by Gerrald, an elephant trainer, and was very good, but I cannot take any credit for it because my contribution was the refreshments during the interval.

Had this been a piece about August days it would have had to include paroxysms of shopping, missed flights, visits to the accident and emergency unit and mountains of laundry. But August nights are another matter.

webTitle: Obituary: Michael Meyer

fields.headline: Obituary: Michael Meyer
fields.standfirst: Renowned translator whose work on Ibsen and Strindberg profoundly affected English-speaking theatre
fields.trailText: Michael Meyer, who has died aged 79, was the greatest translator of Ibsen and Strindberg into English there has ever been; greater even than William Archer, who introduced Ibsen to these islands but brought him down into the narrow range of his own Victorianism.
fields.body:
Michael Meyer, who has died aged 79, was the greatest translator of Ibsen and Strindberg into English there has ever been; greater even than William Archer, who introduced Ibsen to these islands but brought him down into the narrow range of his own Victorianism.

Today, although there have been some interesting versions of the plays, no one can match Meyer for the combination of understanding of the texts allied to the means of expressing them in a language faithful to Ibsen, even rising to the heights of his great first dramas. Three major productions of Meyer's translations are currently in preparation: Creditors and Pariah, as a double bill at the Southwark Playhouse, Shared Experience's A Doll's House, also in London, and Ghosts, at the Royal Exchange, Manchester - 34 years after the translations were made.

British theatre in the 1950s was far more parochial than now. There was no National Theatre, and the Royal Shakespeare Company was confined to Stratford and the Shakespearean repertoire. In 1959, as a schoolboy crazed with theatre, I went to the Lyric, Hammersmith, to see my first Ibsen. Michael Elliott directed Brand for Casper Wrede's 59 Theatre Company, with Patrick McGoohan in the lead.

The production, design and acting rightly received great praise, but the fact of the matter is that Brand had only previously been known through William Archer's six-hour long rhyming couplet version. It was unstageable. Meyer's superb blank verse version rescued the play from oblivion. Indeed, it placed Ibsen back where he belongs, at the centre of the repertoire. By so doing, it influenced the thinking of writers and directors in a profound way, which has not been fully appreciated.

Meyer's witty, moving and acute autobiography is called, typically, Not Prince Hamlet (1985). Michael thought of himself as a bystander, an extra, privileged to know famous men better than he, but always to be ranked lower than them.

This is wrong on two main counts. First, this was the man who wrote The End Of The Corridor, a novel based on his unhappy days at Wellington College, pub-lished in 1951; that year he also wrote his first play, The Ortolan, produced by Wrede in 1953, with Maggie Smith in the lead, and by myself in 1965, with Helen Mirren. It was the same man who later wrote Lunatic And Lover, a play about Strindberg's love life, Summer In Gossensass, about Ibsen's late love, and Meeting In Rome, which starred Kenneth Haigh, an account of a fictional meeting between the two giants; and, in 1992, adapted Gissing's The Odd Women, which I directed for the Royal Exchange.

Secondly - and more importantly - Meyer wrote the definitive biographies of Ibsen (three volumes, 1967-71) and Strindberg (1985). The first won the Whitbread Biography Prize in 1971, and the other led to his becoming the first Englishman to be awarded the Gold Medal by the Swedish Academy. They are model biographies, and stand in their own right as works of literature.

All this is legacy enough. But for those who knew him, Meyer the man was as great an achievement as Meyer the artist. Born in London, into the timber-importing family which ran the firm of Montague Meyer, he read English at Christ Church, Oxford. While there, he edited Eight Oxford Poets (1941) with Sidney Keyes; following Keyes's death, Meyer edited Keyes's Collected Poems (1945, revised 1989). Meyer's studies were interrupted by war service, at Bomber Command from 1942-45, and, after taking his degree, he lectured at Uppsala University from 1947-50, where he learnt Swedish and Norwegian. Between 1978 and 1991, he was visiting professor of drama at various US universities.

His gargantuan appetite for life was as passionate as his love of the theatre. He was a keen sportsman, excelling in hockey and real tennis, and no bad hand with bat and ball. He was a fanatical watcher of sport, with an awesome recall of match detail: he once drew the entire English football team around him after the England-Scotland match in Euro 1996, not because he was trying to, but because they were captivated by him. His greatest passion of all, perhaps, was for food. He was a close friend of Sir Raymond Postgate, founder of The Good Food Guide, served on the committee and nearly took over the editorship.

Meyer will be missed for his warmth and generosity, both private and public. He devised three anthologies: Rogues And Vagabonds, about theatre, His And Hers, about sex and love, and Fun And Games, about sports, which he would cast with famous actors and take all over the country to raise money for charity. If he believed in someone, he would encourage them, make introductions and, not least (as I remember from my youth) sometimes feed them.

Indeed, the Royal Exchange Theatre, previously the 69 Theatre Company, owes him a huge debt. Meyer it was who introduced me to Michael Elliott and Casper Wrede, whom I had admired as a schoolboy watching that memorable 59 Theatre Company. I had written to Michael asking to use his translation of Brand, which, God help me, I wanted to play at school. He came to all my university productions, and persuaded these two distinguished men to take notice of me. The result is the Royal Exchange, which he regarded as his home. We will always see him as one of the moving lights of the company.

Almost every theatre company in this country, and many in the US, have staged important productions of Meyer's translations. He never seemed to believe in the immensity of his contribution, and probably never realised how much he was loved by so many people. With his daughter, Nora, he had a relationship all fathers and children would envy, and he also leaves his brother, Peter. I expect that up in heaven now, Ibsen and Strindberg will be saying "thank you", the chefs will be quaking, and it will certainly be a more fun place to be.

Michael Leverson Meyer, translator and biographer, born June 11 1921; died August 3 2000

webTitle: This medium needs to transmit loud and clear

fields.headline: This medium needs to transmit loud and clear
fields.trailText: The first rools.com interview was for Dot TV, Sky's business technology channel. It was relatively straightforward, covering the Rools business, plans and the market. Because it was recorded for later transmission, the pressure did not feel great.
fields.body:
The first rools.com interview was for Dot TV, Sky's business technology channel. It was relatively straightforward, covering the Rools business, plans and the market. Because it was recorded for later transmission, the pressure did not feel great.

Our second interview was more testing: a live spot on BBC TV's Breakfast News. The Beeb's interest had been caused by the investment that we had secured and the fact that Rools is providing a service for teenagers. It wanted to find out more about what we do and get the views of the Consumer Credit Association on the appropriateness of the service.

We have been advised by our PR agency to be extremely clear in what we communicate in such situations. People do have genuine concerns about online businesses in general and there is particular sensitivity about commercial services for teenagers and children. The most common concern is that services of this kind encourage irresponsible spending among young people.

We have spent a huge amount of time developing a service that delivers real benefits to teenagers in a responsible manner. We emphasise things such as that teenagers cannot spend more than they have in their accounts, that all our retail partners are reputable and appropriate for young people, and that our banking partners protect teenagers' funds and pay interest on the accounts.

We stress these points when we are talking to the media. Unfortunately, it does not always ensure that the right message gets across. Inaccuracies in the trade press about our service have been frustratingly common. Take a couple of examples: we have been wrongly reported to have secured investment of £76m (only £69m out!) and that we are a teenage shopping portal rather than a payments service.

Obtaining positive coverage prior to launch is an important part of our strategy. webTitle: A mixed Test for both sides

fields.headline: A mixed Test for both sides
fields.trailText: The weather came out on top in the end, but even if there had been a full day's play a draw was the likeliest result once West Indies batted on for an hour on the fifth morning. Actually both sides' chances of winning would have been better if West Indies had been bowled out late on the fourth evening - then a mouthwatering final day would have been in prospect.
fields.body:
The weather came out on top in the end, but even if there had been a full day's play a draw was the likeliest result once West Indies batted on for an hour on the fifth morning. Actually both sides' chances of winning would have been better if West Indies had been bowled out late on the fourth evening - then a mouthwatering final day would have been in prospect.

Both sides have good and bad points to mull over as the Test-match roadshow rumbles across the Pennines. England have their plusses: the batting of Alec Stewart in his 100th Test, and Marcus Trescothick in his first - those one-day runs weren't a flash in the pan, then. And the first-innings bowling and catching was good (shame about the second innings).

On the minus side was Robert Croft, who started the fourth day looking as if he would bowl the Windies out on his own - one ball to Adams spat up at him and could have gone anywhere - and finished it with 1 for 112 and the hangdog expression of someone who'd played his last Test. He'll certainly be hoping it's his last in Manchester, anyway; his overall figures there are 3 for 333.

England will doubtless call up another seamer for the line-up at Leeds: Alan "14 wickets" Mullally is the probable choice, although Martin "I took 16" Bicknell and Alex Tudor will have their supporters, as will that gaggle of medium-fast Yorkshiremen.

West Indies' big gain was Brian Lara, back to form and so hungry for runs that he missed his lunch to bat in the nets. Their minus is the continued ordinariness of all their under-35 bowlers. You could sense those West Indian punishers-turned-pundits Ian Bishop and Colin Croft yearning to be back out there to teach Rose and King a thing or two.

A draw is a rare result in Tests these days, although soggy English summers are always going to sink a couple of matches. It means the series will be in the balance all the way to The Oval in September, which is good news for the ticket-sellers - and even better news for the fans.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

webTitle: Peter Preston: The Lewinsky affair was the shaming of modern journalism

fields.headline: The sauce and stains that wrecked Clinton's reputation
fields.standfirst: The Lewinsky affair was the shaming of modern journalism
fields.trailText: The Lewinsky affair was the shaming of modern journalism.
fields.body:
Sources close to the editor of this paper, it may be revealed, are working hard at constructing a code which will give his readers some notion of who is being anonymously quoted - and why. Sources very close to the ex-editor of this paper couldn't be happier about that. Recondite stuff? Not at all. Here is a horror story.

You surely remember some of it: the randy president of the United States, the plump young intern, sex in the Oval Office, the mystery of the semen-stained dress. You probably won't, though, have been following what happened much later - including the trial of one of Judge Kenneth Starr's permutating spokesmen, Charles Bakaly, for lying to a judge. (Was he or wasn't he the source of a New York Times story? Verdict awaited).

The two stories are linked, of course: both feature America's one-man unofficial press complaints commission, Steven Brill, editor of the modestly titled magazine he calls Brill's Content. Brill began snapping away at the Monica Lewinsky saga two years ago in a memorably long and contentious article called Pressgate. And this watchdog is still gnawing the same, battered bone.

Brill's thesis is simple and damning. There seemed to be many sources through the White House travails of 1998 and 1999 as newspaper reporters and TV political commentators and magazine investigators and internet gossipers and talk show hosts chased each others' tales through the thickets of scandal. It was such a huge thing; it was so infinitely exciting that the world media looked on agog. Yet, when you comb through the first six months of these pulsations, there were really only three people making the news.

One was Linda Tripp, the "friend" of Monica who wanted to write a book and be famous. Another was Lucianne Goldberg, the literary agent and renowned Clinton loather, who wanted to sell that book for cash. And the third, more collective source, was the office of the "independent prosecutor", Ken Starr, which had spent millions in fruitless pursuit of the president and needed a break, any break, like desert rats need an ice-cold lager. Put that trio together and you've more or less run out of other sources - save for a little toing and froing with the lawyers for Paula Jones, who had their own fish to fry.

Consider, then, a few of the more memorable Monica moments. How (around mid-October 1997) did it all start? When the Jones legal team began getting anonymous telephone calls from a woman who told them that Tripp and Lewinsky would be worth subpoenas. Who made those calls? Tripp herself. Did Lucianne encourage Linda? "Not exactly, but, hell, I guess you could say so." The subpoenas were issued. Thereafter, one of the pair called the Starr team to alert them to Lewinsky's existence - and once that had happened, the story (in news reporting terms) became "real". Newsweek began to be interested. The show was on the road.

What about all the love letters and tapes that Lewinsky allegedly had sent by courier to Clinton's office after the affair was over, times and deliveries documented and leaked? Lucianne's brother's family owns the courier firm. Tripp and Goldberg (un-amazingly enough) told Monica which company to use.

That stained blue dress, may be (nudge, nudge) uncleaned and still in existence: "Monica's Love Dress", according to the New York Daily News. Matt Drudge, internet gossip, breaks the tale on the net. There's a "potential DNA trail" and ABC television is soon following it. Is this Tripp stirring the Drudge sludge? No: Goldberg is the source again - though, she tells Brill, she's not sure that Monica told Linda she'd "saved" it, just that it was stained. "I might have added the part about it being saved." It does not stop the story echoing round the globe. (We only learn much later that the dress had been dry-cleaned anyway.)

And then... the White House employee (perhaps a butler, perhaps a secret service agent) who supposedly "walked in" on the guilty couple. Enter a Washington lawyer, Joseph DiGenova, and his lawyer wife, Victoria. Joe hears Vicki on the phone talking to an old White House chum (unspecified) who says that he/or she's talked to another co-worker who saw Bill and Monica "in a compromising position". The co-worker has asked the chum to ask Victoria whether she might do the legal honours if he/she goes to Kenneth Starr (though, unbeknown to Joe, nobody pursues anything).

DiGenova mentions this to a reporter from the Dallas Morning News, which gets out the big headline type. A one-source story, Brill remarks, from a fifth-hand source - because "DiGenova (1) heard his wife (2) talking to a friend (3) of someone (4) who had talked to someone (5) who said they'd seen Lewinsky with Clinton." By the time the Associated Press had picked it up from Dallas and CNN was running with it, fifth-hand was seventh-hand.

I could go on (and Brill does, with a beady eye for detail): but the essential case is already made. The president and the intern were horrendously foolish - and Bill Clinton's reputation, unlike Monica's dress, is stained for ever. There was a story in there somewhere. But, crucial caveat, most of the stories around the story were the confections of three eager people (Linda, Lucianne and Ken) with axes to grind.

Back to modern times, Charles Bakaly and the charges of lying. As the impeachment proceedings reached fever pitch in January 1999, the New York Times reported "several associates" of Judge Starr as saying that the independent counsel's office had concluded that Mr Clinton could be indicted while a sitting president. Was Bakaly one - or all - of those associates? He denied it; then, in evidence, admitted handing over an indictment memo to the Times.

Well, we'll see. . . but we don't, I think, need to wait for a conclusion. The Lewinsky affair, in its lathering falsities, was the shaming of modern journalism. So few sources, so much blather. And because news is constant now - from a word on the net or the agency wires to speculation as fact to a balloon of talk show discussion - the machine feeds the frenzy. What everybody's saying becomes obviously true - because everybody's saying it. Even if the first and only person to say it was Lucianne of the stained/saved dress.

The press, says Alastair Campbell bitterly, just make up stories. No they don't: but they do find it increasingly hard to know what's real and what's phoney in the constant reprocessing from sheet to sheet and medium to medium - what's source for the goose and sauce for a gander. May Heaven bless Mr Rusbridger and his prospective code. May the reader be better informed. The miasma of Monica, though, had too little to do with the reader. That was journalists baffling each other with their mystic, deluding jargon.

fields.trailText: In an article headed, High fashion ... or high street?, pages 10 and 11, G2, July 28, we said that the society milliner Philip Treacy "lost his battle" against the Whiteley Hat Company. In fact, the court case related solely to Treacy's withdrawal of an application for an interim injunction. An order for costs was made and these have been referred to a costs judge for assessment. We have been informed, and accept, that Treacy's copyright claim against Whiteley is proceeding.

In an article headed, High fashion ... or high street?, pages 10 and 11, G2, July 28, we said that the society milliner Philip Treacy "lost his battle" against the Whiteley Hat Company. In fact, the court case related solely to Treacy's withdrawal of an application for an interim injunction. An order for costs was made and these have been referred to a costs judge for assessment. We have been informed, and accept, that Treacy's copyright claim against Whiteley is proceeding.

In Finance notebook, page 21, August 2, we quoted Interbrew's chief executive Hugo Powell saying the biggest brewer in Germany had a market share of 82%. That should have been the biggest brewer in Greece.

Homophone corner, from Weatherwatch, page 16, August 4, a reference to the local weather of Hampstead, where the hill "creates its own private and, one might say, rather well-healed cumulus".

webTitle: Harry Legge

fields.headline: Harry Legge
fields.standfirst: Conductor with a passion for widening musicians' horizons
fields.trailText: British professional orchestras are full of players who owe an incalculable musical debt to Harry Legge, who has died aged 86. His founding and conducting of the Edinburgh Rehearsal Orchestra (later renamed the Rehearsal Orchestra) provided a training ground that has never been surpassed.
fields.body:
British professional orchestras are full of players who owe an incalculable musical debt to Harry Legge, who has died aged 86. His founding and conducting of the Edinburgh Rehearsal Orchestra (later renamed the Rehearsal Orchestra) provided a training ground that has never been surpassed.

Born in Liverpool, Legge had musical parents; his father was the city's director of education and, from a young age, Harry performed as a violinist with his amateur pianist mother. He was educated at Winchester College and Queen's College, Oxford, where he read zoology; with the Oxford Playhouse Company he made his conducting debut in The Beggar's Opera.

After studying at the Royal College of Music, he taught at Oundle school. His second world war service included conducting light music for the home defence forces, before the Royal Army Medical Corps posted him to Lagos to run a hospital. A brief return to Oundle proved incompatible with increasing orchestral playing, and in 1949 he joined Sir Thomas Beecham's Royal Philharmonic Orchestra as a viola-player.

Legge remained in the orchestra until 1975, serving as vice-chairman from 1963-73, and was one of the principal contributors to the survival of the orchestra after Beecham's death. He was also a member of the English Sinfonia from 1964-97, and, in his capacity as chairman and later vice-president, was also involved in saving that orchestra from extinction.

In addition to his professional playing, Legge conducted amateur orchestras throughout north London, starting from the Brent Symphony Orchestra, with which he gained valuable practical experience. From 1969-89 he conducted the National Youth Wind Orchestra.

The award to Legge in 1982 of the OBE for services to music was thus thoroughly appropriate, but there was nothing formal or self-important about him. His deep love and understanding of music, his quick brain, his broad cultural background and his relentless energy surged along on a tidal wave of good humour and wit, which made even the most serious occa sion turn into a party. As he said once in a BBC interview: "I enjoy my work because it is to do with the real love of music and not any other puffed-up reason," and this enjoyment was always close to the surface.

Legge's finest invention, the Rehearsal Orchestra, has run each year since 1957 during the Edinburgh Festival. Each section of the orchestra is led and coached by a professional player, and students, amateurs and young professionals explore a wide repertoire of music, far broader than they could hope to meet in their college or local orchestras. The orchestra also holds weekend meetings in various parts of the country, where the time is usually devoted to a major large-scale work that players would rarely have the opportunity to experience.

Legge's time spent playing under internationally famous conductors, most particu larly Beecham and Rudolf Kempe, meant that much of their expertise was channelled directly, with certain Harryish asides and diversions, to the players under his baton. His approach to the players, of whatever standard, was always professional; he expected the best that they could produce, and would not accept less.

Harry's commitment to the music, and the underlying seriousness of his demands, was always accompanied by a twinkle in the eye, even if some of his comments were sometimes a little sharp- edged.

As a bassoonist, and librarian in the early days, I was given a fair amount of gleeful abuse "to frighten the others a bit". He always knew how to get to the heart of a work and, without fussing about unimportant detail, worked on the essential points that would create a good performance in the short time available.

The administrator Gillian Halse Noel worked closely with Legge right from the start, and shared his anxiety on the orchestra's first morning in Edinburgh. Would they turn up? Could they play? Faced with a full orchestra of unknown quantities, Harry, in his (now legendary) red shirt, brought down the baton, dreading a total silence. The first bars of Mendelssohn's Hebrides Overture sounded, and so started an adventure of which Halse Noel recorded the first 40 years in Keeping Out Of The Rain (1997).

The book's title came from Beecham's reason for agreeing to become the patron of a venture which might fill concertgoers' daytimes; but in its foreword, Sir Simon Rattle, a timpanist with the orchestra for a time, salutes its eventual, more substantial purpose: "It gives musicians an invaluable opportunity to work and learn music at the speed they will have to reproduce in their professional lives."

Harry was pleased and excited at the way the very first course went, and felt that the orchestra had tremendous potential. He said to Gillian, "Wouldn't it be the most wonderful thing to leave footprints in the sand?" Right up to the last weeks of his life, he was planning concerts, and had even hoped to get to Edinburgh this summer and conduct just a little; his excitement and his love of the orchestra never waned.

He leaves his wife, Sue, and his sons, Christopher and Anthony, from his first marriage.

Henry 'Harry' James Grenville Legge, musician, born April 24 1914; died July 19 2000

As a bassoonist, and librarian in the early days, I was given a fair amount of gleeful abuse "to frighten the others a bit". He always knew how to get to the heart of a work and, without fussing about unimportant detail, worked on the essential points that would create a good performance in the short time available. The administrator Gillian Halse Noel worked closely with Legge right from the start, and shared his anxiety on the orchestra's first morning in Edinburgh. Would they turn up? Could they play? Faced with a full orchestra of unknown quantities, Harry, in his (now legendary) red shirt, brought down the baton, dreading a total silence. The first bars of Mendelssohn's Hebrides Overture sounded, and so started an adventure of which Halse Noel recorded the first 40 years in Keeping Out Of The Rain (1997). The book's title came from Beecham's reason for agreeing to become the patron of a venture which might fill concertgoers' daytimes; but in its foreword, Sir Simon Rattle, a timpanist with the orchestra for a time, salutes its eventual, more substantial purpose: "It gives musicians an invaluable opportunity to work and learn music at the speed they will have to reproduce in their professional lives." Harry was pleased and excited at the way the very first course went, and felt that the orchestra had tremendous potential. He said to Gillian, "Wouldn't it be the most wonderful thing to leave footprints in the sand?" Right up to the last weeks of his life, he was planning concerts, and had even hoped to get to Edinburgh this summer and conduct just a little; his excitement and his love of the orchestra never waned. He leaves his wife, Sue, and his sons, Christopher and Anthony, from his first marriage. Henry 'Harry' James Grenville Legge, musician, born April 24 1914; died July 19 2000

webTitle: Hans Werner Egli

fields.headline: Hans Werner Egli
fields.standfirst: Witness to Hitler's civilian bombing of Britain
fields.trailText: A writer likes to know that his work is read: the Swiss journalist Hans Werner Egli, who has died aged 101, received the ultimate reader reaction when a furious Adolf Hitler denounced him and tried to have him sacked.
fields.body:
A writer likes to know that his work is read: the Swiss journalist Hans Werner Egli, who has died aged 101, received the ultimate reader reaction when a furious Adolf Hitler denounced him and tried to have him sacked.

In November 1940, Egli, then chief London correspondent of the Neue Zürcher Zeitung (NZZ), went to Coventry to witness the devastation wrought on the city’s housing and cathedral by German bombing. He wrote: “The German attacks, as tended to be the case in London, did not, for the most part, hit war targets, but had the principal objective of terrorising the civil population.”

When the führer read this, he flew into a rage, as it brought home to him that German press reports of effective, accurate Luftwaffe bombing amounted to no more than whistling in the dark. It was only in 1945 that Egli had the gratification of learning that Hitler had instructed the German ambassador to Switzerland to demand his removal, though unsuccessfully.

The son of an insurance clerk in Affoltern am Albis, in the canton of Zürich, Egli attended the Realgymnasium in Zürich, studied law and economics for a year at Zürich University, and went to London in 1919 for a two-year course in international law and economics at King’s College and the London School of Economics. This marked the start of his long involvement with Britain; in 1921, he married Helen Roe, and they had a son and daughter before divorcing.

In 1924, Egli graduated from Zürich University with a doctorate in law, but his legal career ran no further than spells as a substitute clerk at a civil court in Berne. A period as assistant editor of the Swiss Telegraphic Agency led to his return to London in 1926 to write for a number of Swiss newspapers, and in particular as economic correspondent for the NZZ.

In this capacity, he repeatedly criticised Winston Churchill, as chancellor of the exchequer between 1924 and 1929, for seeking to maintain the gold parity of the pound with the 1913 exchange rate “as if the first world war had passed the British economy by without leaving any trace”. But in the 1930s, Egli became one of the first journalists to attach weight to Churchill’s warnings about Hitler’s aggressive intentions. In 1936, he started writing exclusively for the NZZ, continuing to do so until his retirement in 1974, and married the actress Selma Vaz Dias, with whom he had a son and daughter; Selma died in 1977.

The Coventry episode was characteristic of the objectivity of Egli’s war reporting, which kept Switzerland consistently well-informed, just as it often annoyed Germany. During the war, foreign journalists worked alongside their British colleagues in the Ministry of Information press room at London University. The foreigners’ reports were censored on the spot, and if they spoke a single word to their editors outside the written script, the telephone line was cut off. Resulting disputes called for a journalists’ spokesman, and, in this role, the Foreign Press Association (FPA) came into its own. Egli was much involved in these exchanges, becoming the FPA’s president for 1945-46.

With the end of the war, the FPA needed a new home, so Egli prodded friends at the Foreign Office into action, with a letter to the Times. This brought him a reproach for his “unnecessary reminder”, but also the offer of the rent-free use of 11 Carlton House Terrace, which enabled the FPA to develop into one of the world’s leading foreign press centres.

Egli worked ceaselessly for the Swiss community in the UK, becoming president of the New Helvetic Society (1947-57 and 1962-69), and president of the Federation of Swiss Societies in the UK (1949-58). Into his 90s, he spoke on all matters of Swiss concern and British-Swiss friendship - and still drove a car.

He is survived by his partner of 20 years, Laura Kaufman, his four children, 11 grandchildren and five great-grandchildren.

Hans Werner Egli, journalist, born March 17 1899; died June 28 2000

webTitle: Tories enlist economic experts

fields.headline: Tories enlist economic experts
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The Conservatives yesterday stepped up their attack on Gordon Brown's £40bn public spending plans by releasing a dossier of warnings from economic experts that voters face the prospect of higher inflation and dearer borrowing.
fields.body:
The Conservatives yesterday stepped up their attack on Gordon Brown's £40bn public spending plans by releasing a dossier of warnings from economic experts that voters face the prospect of higher inflation and dearer borrowing.

In an attempt to neutralise the political impact of the three-year boost to expenditure, the Opposition said comments from the City, the Institute for Fiscal Studies and the Na tional Institute of Economic and Social Research supported William Hague's argument that the government's "spending splurge" would harm the economy.

Michael Ancram, the Conservative party chairman, said: "According to respected experts, businesses, homeowners and families now face the renewed threat of higher interest rates and inflation, on top of the higher tax burden already imposed by Labour.

"Ordinary people will rightly wonder at the chancellor's claims of prudence and generosity."

Last month's comprehensive spending review was seen by all sides at Westminster as a crucial event in the run-up to the next election.

Yesterday's document contained quotes from Andrew Dilnot, director of the IFS, Digby Jones, director general of the CBI, Martin Weale, director of the NIESR, and David Walton, chief UK economist with Goldman Sachs.

webTitle: How Americans responded to Megan's law

fields.headline: How Americans responded to Megan's law
fields.standfirst: Measure against paedophiles continues to divide
fields.trailText: No one ever accused Jesse Timmendequas, a paedophile on death row, of being an over-achiever, but his crimes are responsible for one of the most emotional debates in the United States.
fields.body:
No one ever accused Jesse Timmendequas, a paedophile on death row, of being an over-achiever, but his crimes are responsible for one of the most emotional debates in the United States.

The former labourer, 39, might be low on name recognition, but that of his victim is known even to those who have no knowledge of her abruptly curtailed life.

Megan Kanka was seven years old when Timmendequas, a New Jersey neighbour living with two other paedophiles, abducted, raped and strangled her in 1994.

The girl's parents believed that she might still be alive had they known he was living nearby and set about gathering 430,000 signatures to press for a change in the law.

New Jersey responded quickly, and in 1996 Congress and President Bill Clinton obliged with the measure known as Megan's law: each state had to release "relevant" information about child molesters and violent sexual offenders to the public.

It was left to each of the 50 states to decide how access to the information was provided. Civil libertarians argue that the law breaches the privacy of ex-offenders and makes them a target for retribution.

"People who have been convicted of crimes, who have served their sentences, should not be the subject of continuing punishment," said Barry Steinhardt, associate director of the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU).

Some states make the information about the nation's 324,000 registered sex offenders available at local police stations, while in others people have to write requesting details or call a toll-free telephone number. Twenty-one states, most of them in the south and the mid-west, post details on the internet. But at least 10% of the information, which is supplied by the offenders, is thought to be incorrect.

When the law was finally en forced two years ago in New Jersey after a series of legal challenges, the names and photographs of men whose details were meant to have been confined to the neighbourhood - an area which was not defined - turned up in the local media. Then a school counsellor who had never been accused of sex crimes was identified as an offender in handbills distributed close to his home.

Many people were upset when it became clear that they would not find out about every sex offender but only those who were living nearest to them and were considered the most dangerous.

Later, five bullets were fired through the sitting room window of a home above that of a man who had been to prison for raping teenagers.

Elsewhere, a man hanged himself from a tree in Santa Rosa, California, after police warned his neighbours that he was a convicted child molester; another shot himself after officers in Seal Cove, Maine, distributed handbills saying he had confessed to having sex with a boy six years previously; an offender's car was fire-bombed in Los Angeles after he appeared on an internet list; and two men beat a convicted sex offender with a baseball bat in North Fort Myers, Florida, and threatened to kill him if he went near children in the neighbourhood.

New Mexico was the last state to adopt Megan's law. "This is mean-spirited voyeurism, and that's its only effect," said Denise Clegg, acting executive director of the state's ACLU. "If there was a good case we would definitely challenge it."

Even in New Jersey the operation of Megan's law is by no means settled, and it has been suspended twice under legal challenge in the past seven months. Now that it is back in use, prosecutors say they cannot act against those who misuse information about sex offenders because of a court judgment limiting the scope of warnings to those who receive it.

Another, more strident measure against sex offenders that has received less attention is Stephanie's law, named after a 19-year-old killed in 1994 and adopted in various forms by at least 13 states. This law, born in Kansas, allows for the detention in mental institutions of those considered likely to offend again after their release from jail. In Illinois, for instance, more than 100 have been incarcerated in institutions in the past two years and none has been released.

Amitai Etzioni, a professor at George Washington University and founder of the Society for the Advancement of Socio-Economics, said that neither law worked well. Megan's law deprived sex offenders of privacy without improving the safety of children unless adults were with them at all times. Stephanie's law did improve safety but removed the rights of released prisoners.

"Confine child molesters in special, guarded, child-free communities," he said. "As a means of separating molesters from children, this would be more effective than Megan's law but less intrusive and costly than Stephanie's law.

"While some critics have compared this proposal to leper colonies, the communal custody approach is better than any of the alternatives."

webTitle: Sir Alec Guinness dies

fields.headline: Sir Alec Guinness dies
fields.trailText: Sir Alec Guinness, the actor, died on Saturday night at the age of 86, it was announced late last night.
fields.body:
Sir Alec Guinness, the actor, died on Saturday night at the age of 86, it was announced late last night.

The star of numerous Ealing comedies and Star Wars passed away at the King Edward VII Hospital in Midhurst, West Sussex, a hospital spokesman said.

He had been taken ill at his home in the village of Steep Marsh, near Petersfield, Hampshire, on Thursday, and was taken to hospital by ambulance.

Jenny Masding, a palliative care consultant, said he died at 9.50pm on Saturday. She said Sir Alec "died very peacefully", but would not confirm the suspected cause of Sir Alec's death.

Sir Alec had been in ill health for a number of years. He had also battled against chronic glaucoma and cataracts for some time and underwent extensive surgery to restore his vision.

His sixty-year career included such highlights as Kind Hearts and Coronets - in which he famously played eight different roles - and Bridge Over the River Kwai, for which he won an Oscar in 1959. He was knighted the same year.

To anyone under 30, however, he was probably most famous for playing the part of Obi-Wan Kenobi in 1977's Star Wars. It was, a role he professed to despise, saying he threw away all Star Wars fan-mail unopened.

Sir Alec married playwright Merula Salaman in 1938 and the couple lived well away from the spotlight. They had one son, Matthew.

webTitle: Time to stop taking the bit-player role

fields.headline: Time to stop taking the bit-player role
fields.trailText: Here's the theory. Britain can never hope to challenge the United States as top dog in the world economy, but it has the potential to play Athens to America's Rome. The blossoming of our cultural industries will civilise the hard-nosed form of enterprise coming across the Atlantic.
fields.body:
Here's the theory. Britain can never hope to challenge the United States as top dog in the world economy, but it has the potential to play Athens to America's Rome. The blossoming of our cultural industries will civilise the hard-nosed form of enterprise coming across the Atlantic.

Tate Modern is the symbol of a renaissance that will essentially write off the 20th century as a hundred wasted years. A new economic phoenix will emerge from the ashes of all those obsolete car factories and shut-down steel plants, taking Brit art, Brit pop, Brit software, Brit TV and Brit fashion to every corner of the globe.

The reasoning goes like this. Britain is not very good at manufacturing. Lots of people make money out of making ads, designing software, running record companies and so on. Therefore, the future is with the filmmaker who can turn out the next Full Monty and the entrepreneur who can discover the next Oasis, rather than people who are making tangible products.

This is a false syllogism. Britain's recent performance in manufacturing has indeed been poor (not least because of dreadful macro-economic errors) but the idea that the creative industries are so dynamic and unstoppable that they can plug the hole in the balance of payments is fanciful in the extreme.

Lowest ebb

Two-thirds of British films are never seen because they are so uncommercial; British television is awash with repeats, cheap fly-on-the-wall docu-soaps and American imports; British pop music is at its lowest ebb since the days of Cliff and the Shadows in the early 60s. When the best that last night's TV can manage is the umpteenth re-run of Fawlty Towers and David Bowie is still the headline act at Glastonbury, it is hard to take some of the claims made for the cultural industries seriously.

The figures do not lie. We run a massive balance of payments deficit in film, a smaller deficit in TV and our share of the world music market is falling.

There could be the simplest of explanations. The end of ideology, the idea that class no longer matters, the scrabbling for the centre ground, the homogeneity implicit in the triumph of Americana have led us into a cultural cul-de-sac, where mediocrity rules and there are no causes left worth fighting for.

Conflict is good for creativity, blandness deadens it. Seen from this perspective, the appeal of programmes such as Big Brother - in which contestants are cooped up in a house and battle against each in the hope that they will be the last to be turfed out by a TV audience - is the modern version of the Colosseum and illustrative of the same sort of moral decay that led to Rome's demise.

But, for the sake of argument, let's assume that this is not the case, or even if it is that the forces of globalisation will result in the rejuvenation of western culture rather than a creeping homogeneity. Are there any factors that will limit the rise of the cultural industries?

Two immediately spring to mind. One is the British cult of amateurism, normally dressed up as spontaneity or creativity. Our ideal hero is the chap who is persuaded to step in at the last minute for a cricket match on the village green, borrows a pair of flannels and a bat held together with sticky tape, then goes in and scores a brilliant century. But real life is not like that.

It is no accident that the United States has been the dominant force in world cinema for the past century, because whereas Hollywood has always been consumer rather than producer driven, Europe's filmmakers have never had much truck with market reseach.

As Finola Kerrigan and Nigel Culkin of the Univesity of Hertfordshire concluded in a study of cinema: "Historically, the structural problems which are seen to dog the European industry emanate from the organisation of the industry itself combined with a reluctance on the part of the Europeans to adopt industrial and marketing tactics readily embraced by Hollywood.

"The European industries are very heavily production led and continue to ignore the importance of distribution, which results in their failure to secure a greater share of the global film market."

So, if we want our cultural industries to thrive, lesson one is to treat them as an industry, with proper regard given to those elements - investment, research and development - that make firms successful in competitive markets.

Make do and mend - a philosophy tested to destruction in parts of manufacturing - will not do if we are to alter a situation in which British films capture 1% of the American market and US films take 70% of the British market.

The average budget for American productions in Britain is £18m, against £3m for British films. Alan Parker, who is chairing the film council, set up by the Department of Culture Media and Sport, wants Britain to concentrate on making fewer vanity films and more blockbusters.

Some might not like this approach, arguing that Hollywood is about the lowest common denominator, dumbing down and formula movie-making. Given that America has given us Scorsese, Coppola and Altman, while we have given them the Carry On series and Hammer Horror, this is not an especially strong case. Parker's approach is the right one, and applies to TV as well as film, where the demand for programmes triggered by the satellite and cable revolution has outstripped the ability of programme makers to supply quality products. Greg Dyke's plans for two new BBC TV channels are fine in principle, but will only succeed if the money is there to make quality programmes.

Lesson number two is that there should be less emphasis on high culture and more on mass culture. This is brought home in an excellent pamphlet by James Heartfield in which he argues that leisure has been captured by the rich. The amount of leisure time per person has not increased much since the start of the 60s, but more and more of it is being captured by the better off.

"We need to distinguish between mass cultural consumption and the more leisurely and reflective cultivation of pleasure at the other end of the scale. The first is characterised by greater technological productivity, accessing the same two-hour slot between the evening meal and going to bed. Media directed towards that time-slot is frenetic, demanding a short attention span, offering the utmost in sensational impact.

"The second is characterised by craft production values and an open-ended time-scale. These cultural products are marked by ambiguity, irony and obscenity as well as being heavily coded to limit entry."

There is no doubt the elite does very well for itself out of the cultural industries and calls most of the shots. Vast dollops of public cash subsidise opera and ballet, for example. "By minimising their unpaid labour, Britain's wealthy professionals have succeeded in expanding their appreciation of minority culture, pointedly reasserting their monopoly over society's leisure time," Heartfield says. "Britain's leisure society is strongly weighted towards its leisure class."

Does this matter? Well, not if we see culture as the icing on the cake, the bit of the economy that celebrates the human spirit and adds texture to life. But it does if we think that we can make a living out of cultural industries, because the market for mass culture in Britain is far bigger than that for minority culture.

Unfortunately, culture is one of the bulwarks of British snobbery; high culture is seen as quality culture, pop culture as low-grade culture. A glance at some of the "high culture" on display at Tate Modern is a quick-working antidote for this way of thinking.

In the end, the choice is between being a niche player or going for a mass market. The glamorous end of the fashion industry is designing haute couture for Paris and Milan; the real money is made in the high street. Britain's economic history is full of missed opportunities. It would be a shame to see the cultural industries go the same way.

Great Expectations; James Heartfield; £7.50 from Design Agenda, <A HREF="http://www.design-agenda.org.uk"
