webTitle: Arson inquiry over house fire which killed three

fields.headline: Arson inquiry over house fire which killed three
fields.trailText: Arson specialists will today continue to comb the shell of a terrace house where a mother and her two teenage daughters died in a fire which police are treating as suspicious.
fields.body:
Arson specialists will today continue to comb the shell of a terrace house where a mother and her two teenage daughters died in a fire which police are treating as suspicious.

The baby daughter of one of the two young women suffered facial burns but was saved by being thrown from an upstairs window as neighbours heard screams from the house at Telford, Shropshire.

The boyfriend of one of the teenagers and their father escaped with minor injuries from the blaze, which was so severe that an estimated £250,000 damage was caused to neighbouring homes.

Firemen evacuated part of the street, Halifax Drive, in Leegomery, Telford, before the flames were brought under control at 4am on Saturday.

An uncle of the teenagers, Edward Lowe of Telford, named the victims yesterday as his sister-in-law, Linda Lowe, and her daughters Sarah, 17, and Lucy, 16. Mr Lowe said that his brother George, who suffered smoke inhalation, was in a state of shock.

"He has lost his entire family - two daughters and the wife he doted on," he said.

The baby girl was taken to the Princess hospital, Telford, where her condition yesterday was described as comfortable.

webTitle: EC 'interfering' in education

fields.headline: EC 'interfering' in education
fields.trailText: The Conservatives last night accused the European commission of planning to interfere in the school curriculums of member states.
fields.body:
The Conservatives last night accused the European commission of planning to interfere in the school curriculums of member states.

The accusation arose from the discovery of a multi-million pound tender by the commission seeking expert bodies to examine Europe's educational and cultural needs.

The shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, invoked article 149 of the EU treaties to claim that the commission was acting illegally.

The 109-page tender in the EU's official journal is looking for expert advice across a range of cultural and educational policies, with budgets of up to £300,000 for the work.

One element sets out plans to develop a form of EU curriculum by evaluating "a European dimension in education, including analysis of the cultural or socio-economic/political elements appropriate for inclusion" in timetables at primary and secondary schools and in higher education.

It seeks advice on a European youth policy designed to work with regional governments, rather than national ones - a hyper-sensitive strategy to Eurosceptics, who believe that any EU education policy would also play down the role of the nation state.

Accusing ministers of failing to stand up to "interference", Mr Maude said: "It is clear that the attempt to develop modules for education is the first step to create a single EU curriculum. Education should be a local and national issue."

He cited the passage in article 149 that said the EU should "encourage cooperation" and practical support for better education "while fully respecting the responsibility of the member states for the content of teaching, the organisation of education systems, and their cultural and linguistic diversity".

webTitle: Analysis: The importance of the pensioner vote

fields.headline: Grey power
fields.standfirst: Political parties ignore the wishes of pensioners at their peril. The government would do well to consider this before the next election
fields.trailText: Political parties ignore the wishes of pensioners at their peril. The government would do well to consider this before the next election.
fields.body:
We have already entered the "long" election campaign. By the time the official or "short" campaign gets going, it will be too late for the parties to change the outcome. By then the majority of electors will have made up their minds about how they are going to vote. According to the British election study (BES) which collected data shortly after the 1997 general election, some 63% of voters made up their minds before the short campaign and only 27% made up their minds during the official campaign itself.

One of the features of the long campaign is the opportunity it provides for groups to lobby the government with the forthcoming contest in mind. Groups can threaten that their supporters will switch to rivals or abstain if the government does not change its policies. In recent months spokespeople for ethnic minorities, students, rural voters, women and supporters of the Labour heartlands have all used this tactic. Actually, it appears to have worked in the latter case, since the government has responded to disaffection in the Labour heartlands with plans for more cash for the regions.

In fact, claims by many interest groups that their supporters can swing elections have little validity. Two factors determine clout. An interest group has to be big enough to matter in a significant number of seats. Secondly it has to be sufficiently cohesive - its members will vote on the basis of their group interests. The first requirement rules out students and ethnic minorities. They are just not numerous enough to influence the outcome in all but a handful of seats. The second requirement rules out women. Despite the fact that they are one of the largest groups with, arguably, common interests in electoral politics, the evidence is that women are not cohesive enough to vote on a clearly defined set of issues in order to shift the political agenda. Both factors rule out the Countryside Alliance. The rural vote, as opposed to the urban and suburban votes, is not that large in Britain and in any case the alliance does not speak for rural voters in general.

"Grey" or retired voters are an exceptional interest group. They make up just over a fifth of the electorate, but represent about a quarter of voters because they are more likely to turn out than younger members of the population. Thus they meet the requirement of being a large group which is represented in all types of constituencies. In addition, there is evidence to suggest that they are willing to vote on the basis of perceived common interests.

Many grey voters are poor and therefore care more than voters in general about welfare issues, including of course pensions. In addition, grey voters are more likely than the rest of the voting population to hold the government of the day responsible for their economic situation. In the 1997 BES survey, respondents were asked to indicate their preferences for taxation and spending along an 11-point scale, where a score of one meant that they were enthusiastic supporters of increased spending and higher taxation, and a score of 11 meant the opposite. A surprising 32% of grey voters were in the most enthusiastic taxing and spending category, compared with only 20% of voters in general.

In addition, some 34% of young and middle-aged voters in the election study thought that their standard of living had increased since the previous election, but only 19% of grey voters believed this to be true. When asked if the Tory government was responsible for this, some 53% of grey voters thought that this was the case compared with only 42% of the rest. Thus grey voters felt worse off than voters in general and were more likely to hold the government responsible for this state of affairs. This evidence goes a long way to explaining why 38% of them supported Labour and only 29% the Tories in the 1997 general election.

In a Gallup survey conducted in April this year only 24% of grey voters supported Labour against 38% for the Tories, in response to a question about their voting intentions. This suggests many of them have become disillusioned with New Labour since the election. Perhaps this is not surprising since New Labour's emphasis on the new and the dynamic tends to suggest that old people are a bit of an embarrassment. More to the point, the neglect of grey voters in relation to the pensions issue is having a political effect. The 75p pensions increase clearly did a lot of damage to Labour's support.

I have tried to estimate the electoral consequences of neglecting the grey constituency. This can be done by rerunning the 1997 election using a computer simulation which keeps everything the same as it was in that election, with the exception of the grey vote. By substituting the grey vote estimated from the April 2000 Gallup poll for the vote recorded in 1997, it is possible to get an idea of its electoral importance.

If grey voters had voted in 1997 the way they would now, Labour would have won 349 seats instead of 418. Putting this another way, some 69 Labour MPs are in jeopardy. The Liberal Democrats are also hit quite hard in this simulation, losing 21 of their 46 seats. The Tories gain 90 seats overall.

The irony in all of this is that the Tories are unlikely to do anything significant to help grey voters on the pensions issue if they were elected, because they are strongly committed to tax cuts. This suggests that if Labour did now court this constituency, both in terms of policies and also in its rhetoric, it might well win many of them back.

 Paul Whiteley is professor of politics at Sheffield University.
P.Whiteley@sheffield.ac.uk

webTitle: The sec's files

fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.body:
 SKIP THE RUSH HOUR

Have you ever considered becoming a teleworker, and doing your nine to five at home instead of in the office? If so, it seems you are not alone. Analysis of the government's Spring 2000 Labour Force Survey by the Institute for Employment Studies shows a huge increase in the number of people working for their employer or client from home, up 19% on last year. One British worker in 17 now uses technology to give themselves a more flexible work pattern. Seven out of 10 teleworkers are men, and most are in senior positions. Research indicates, though, that it is women who are the faster growing group favouring home over office.

 LEARNING CURVE

Need a bite-sized skills boost? Try the latest additions to the popular "30-minute" series from publisher Kogan Page. Just launched are three books that promise in half an hour to help you understand the financial pages, improve your networking skills and discover how to get promoted. These handy pocket guides are quick to digest and great for those looking for an introduction to a new skill, or wanting to update a rusty one. The edition on promotion, for example, will show you how to advance your career, increase your personal power and build a good relationship with managers and colleagues. All titles are available (priced £3 each) from bookshops, or direct from the publisher on 01903 828800.

 THINK BEFORE YOU SEND

It's a minefield. How do you use email effectively and professionally at work and avoid appearing too informal? According to online temp recruitment agency, tempz.com, the key is to think before you send. Be friendly but not overly familiar, and keep messages brief. Avoid abbreviations that mean nothing to the recipient, always put a heading in the subject box to help people prioritise what they receive and do remember to add the attachment you promised. Don't hide from a tricky situation by sending an email instead of talking to people. Finally, take care when sending and forwarding - it's easy to send to the wrong person, sometimes with disastrous consequences . . .

 PRIZE SUPPLIES

Fancy a five-night holiday for two in a luxury hotel in the heart of Hollywood, plus £1,000 spending money? For a chance to win, all you have to do is buy any office product from the five Esselte brands - Leitz, Pendaflex, Curtis, Dymo or Esselte - from now until December 1 2000, and send the barcode to the address given on the products. For suppliers, contact Esselte on 020 8282 1000.

Compiled by Penny Cottee, editor of Executive PA magazine.

webTitle: Desktop icons: No 31: The pencil

fields.headline: Desktop icons
fields.standfirst:
No 31: The pencil

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: No 31: The pencil
fields.body:
HB or not HB? That is the question for the office worker. Some, of course, eschew the pencil altogether, leaving it to the rest of us to decipher the codes - HB, 3B, 2H, 3H, BB ... is there even a BB ? - as the trip to the stationery cupboard suddenly requires some serious thinking. With so many categories and sub- categories to choose from - and that's not considering eye pencils or coloured pencils - the eventual selection should be carefully considered, for a person's pencil habit will reveal far more than a CV ever could. Unless, of course, that CV is written in pencil, a sure sign that the author should never be allowed into an office environment.

The modern pencil user falls into one of three basic categories: the propellors, the chewers and those who use the pencil instead of an inky alternative.

Fans of the propelling pencil cannot be without it, and have a tendency to clip their pencils into their breast pockets with an air of brisk efficiency. When needed, they are unveiled in a flash, firmly gripped, poised and then irritatingly clicked three times.

The chewers, on the other hand, will leave a damp legacy on every pencil that rolls innocently into their path. Unconsciously they put the unsharpened end between their front teeth and gnaw away until, eventually, graphite, toxic paint and splinters wreak their revenge.

But the worst culprits must be those who use a pencil for everything, oozing neatness, tidiness and geekishness. They sit in meetings, pencil in hand, watching with an air of smug superiority as a colleague hastily scribbles over a mistake, before pedantically erasing his or her own.

Thanks to their years of dedication to the graphite stick, they can tell you that the average HB office pencil can write about 45,000 words, draw a line 35 miles long, be used in zero gravity, upside down and even under water. It may not have occurred to them that, underwater, the paper would be ruined.

webTitle: Bid for drinks arm of Seagram

fields.headline: Bid for drinks arm of Seagram
fields.standfirst: Founding Bronfman family to make offer
fields.trailText: Some members of the founding Bronfman family are understood to be putting final touches to a multi-billion dollar bid for the drinks arm of Seagram, the media business to be merged with Vivendi of France.
fields.body:
Some members of the founding Bronfman family are understood to be putting final touches to a multi-billion dollar bid for the drinks arm of Seagram, the media business to be merged with Vivendi of France.

Charles Bronfman, co-chairman of Seagram, is preparing a bid for the drinks division, which includes brands such as Chivas Regal scotch and Captain Morgan rum, in an effort to keep the 76-year-old business in the family.

Several members of the Bronfman family, which still owns 24% of the entire group, are understood to have been unhappy about selling their stake after its $34bn (£23bn) takeover by Vivendi.

As part of the deal, announced in June, the French media and entertainment group said that it would sell the drinks business to focus on Seagram's media assets, which includes the Universal film studios and one of the world's largest record labels.

Weekend reports suggested that Charles Bronfman had appointed Bear Stearns, the US investment bank, to help prepare a bid worth about $7bn.

However, an offer document being drawn up by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter is expected to be sent to Claridge Investments, the family's investing vehicle, once it is completed in two weeks' time. Other companies expected to receive the confidential details include European consumer groups Diageo, Allied Domecq and Pernod Ricard prior to putting in bids of their own.

Bankers have also made it clear that, if the family is to win the drinks business, it must be prepared to pay more than these global businesses. Charles Bronfman is understood to have approached several backers to help raise the necessary funds for a bid. The family's entire stake in the business was valued at about $8.5bn by the Vivendi offer at the end of June.

Several members of the family share this stake, however, with Charles and Edgar Bronfman, the father of the current chief executive and chairman of the board, understood to be the largest shareholders.

The family stake was felt to be the biggest barrier to the company being taken over before Edgar Bronfman Jr, chief executive and nephew of Charles, arranged the Vivendi deal. He described the decision to sell a business founded by his grandfather Samuel in 1924 as "not without emotion".

Although his decision to sell won the support of most of the family shareholders, others were understood to have privately expressed reservations about selling the entire business. The company started life as a distiller and has only in recent years expanded into music and entertainment. A return to the drinks business would therefore be a return to the company's roots.

Wall Street brokers are hoping that interest from the world's top drinks companies will help force up the price.

webTitle: The office gossip

fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.standfirst:
on ... a good boss

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: on ... a good boss
fields.body:
"You can't work for someone for 10 years if you don't think they're a good boss," says Rebecca Edwards, PA to Lord Andrew Hay, who heads up the country house department at Knight Frank, a large London property firm.

"Having said that, however, it's not just luck if you have a good relationship with your boss. Obviously it helps if you start off liking each other, but it's the same as any relationship - you have to work at it to get it right."

Edwards has been working for Hay since she was 21, and she believes their long-running partnership works so well because they communicate constantly.

"Andrew is frantically busy and he's out of the office about 50% of the time," she says. "But we speak constantly - always in the morning and the evening, and several times throughout the day. Sometimes I can take 80 to 100 calls in a day and the only way to ensure that Andrew is up to date on everything is to keep talking to him. It means that there's much less room for error."

As head of the department, Hay conducts viewings only on properties worth more than £4m, but Edwards also makes the arrangements for clients who want to see other, less expensive properties.

"If Andrew is doing the viewing, then I make all his travel arrangements and speak to the client; if not, then I will organise one of our regional people to take the client around. I try to deal with as many enquiries about properties as possible; if we send out details of a house with Andrew as the contact name we may get hundreds of calls. If I gave all the messages to him, he wouldn't be pleased, and most of the questions I can deal with myself."

In addition to working as Hay's PA, Edwards is also the office manager, responsible for the five other secretaries in the department. "At times combining the two roles means I am extremely busy," she says. "For example, at the moment I'm organising a large party, in addition to all my other duties. At times I feel a bit like I'm drowning, but the good thing is that I can tell Andrew that. He might ring up and ask why I haven't done a report when the phone hasn't stopped all day. But if I explain, he's always very understanding and he'll suggest things I could delegate to one of the other secretaries. I think it's essential to be honest - your boss can only help you out if he or she understands the situation."

According to Edwards, the other key to a successful relationship is being able to have a laugh - but only at the right moment. "A lot of the time the department is like a dealing floor and things are incredibly busy. That's the time I keep my head down and get on with the job in hand. But other times, at the beginning and end of the day, we have a real laugh and I think that's so important. Of course it's important to treat your boss with respect, but you should be able to have a little fun as well."

webTitle: Speculation grows over Telewest takeover

fields.headline: Speculation grows over Telewest takeover
fields.trailText: Telewest faces further stock market turbulence today amid takeover speculation prompted by last week's frosty reception of its interim profits figures.
fields.body:
Telewest faces further stock market turbulence today amid takeover speculation prompted by last week's frosty reception of its interim profits figures.

The rumours about the future ownership of the cable television and telephony group were so intense over the weekend that one potential bidder, Callahan Associates, was last night moved to deny an interest in the group.

That means investors looking for some respite for Telewest's shares may need to rely on NTL, the group's closest rival, as being a more credible bidder.

The slippery slope for Telewest, formed by the merger of Telewest and Flextech, began two weeks ago when the group announced difficulties with its planned roll out of digital television services. The shares have fallen 10% since the original announcement which has followed a strong performance from BSkyB in winning more digital television customers. Shares in Telewest closed at 160p on Friday.

Yesterday Dick Callahan, head of Callahan Associates which already owns a range of cable interests across Europe, said a report that he had made a £6bn offer for the group was "absolutely not true".

NTL is regarded by the City as the preferred partner for Telewest and they have some shareholders in common. Microsoft is one, with a 23% stake in Telewest and 5% of NTL. But industry sources say that while Telewest's shares have been heading south - they hit a 20 month low on Thursday - NTL is also having a difficult time with investors.

Both companies are saddled with large debts which might also make a merger difficult to finance even though Telewest is regarded as being prepared to engage in merger talks. Talk that Telewest is vulnerable to a takeover may be wide of the mark, however, as 50% of its shares are in the hands of two investors, US software firm Microsoft and Liberty Media.

Telewest had been hoping to attract 500,000 customers for its digital television services by the end of the year but its technical problems have forced it to push that back to the first quarter of 2001. Last week, it reported a 35% rise in revenues to £514m for the six months to July but worsening pre-tax losses of £296m.

Through a merger with NTL, Telewest is regarded as having more clout to squeeze the position of BSkyB which announced recently that it had taken 1m subscribers last year.

NTL is regarded by the City as the preferred partner for Telewest and they have some shareholders in common. Microsoft is one, with a 23% stake in Telewest and 5% of NTL. But industry sources say that while Telewest's shares have been heading south - they hit a 20 month low on Thursday - NTL is also having a difficult time with investors. Both companies are saddled with large debts which might also make a merger difficult to finance even though Telewest is regarded as being prepared to engage in merger talks. Talk that Telewest is vulnerable to a takeover may be wide of the mark, however, as 50% of its shares are in the hands of two investors, US software firm Microsoft and Liberty Media. Telewest had been hoping to attract 500,000 customers for its digital television services by the end of the year but its technical problems have forced it to push that back to the first quarter of 2001. Last week, it reported a 35% rise in revenues to £514m for the six months to July but worsening pre-tax losses of £296m. Through a merger with NTL, Telewest is regarded as having more clout to squeeze the position of BSkyB which announced recently that it had taken 1m subscribers last year.

webTitle: Skills shortage 'not cause of unemployment'

fields.headline: Skills shortage 'not cause of unemployment'
fields.standfirst: Worst jobs blackspots still created by lack of vacancies, says report
fields.trailText: Unemployment in many of Britain's hard-core centres of joblessness is the result of a continued lack of available work rather than a dearth of skills amongst those on the dole, according to a report out today.
fields.body:
Unemployment in many of Britain's hard-core centres of joblessness is the result of a continued lack of available work rather than a dearth of skills amongst those on the dole, according to a report out today.

Rejecting government claims that unemployment is now largely a "skills" problem, a study by Cambridge Econometrics said that almost 500,000 people, mainly in the north of England, were unable to work because of limited job opportunities.

The report by the forecasting think tank underlined the north-south divide in Britain's jobs market despite the fall in the number of people out of work and claiming benefit to a 20-year-low of 1.1m.

"Unemployment rates are generally higher than the UK average in the north of England, and a higher proportion of areas fall into the jobs shortfall category, notably the majority of jobs centres in Yorkshire and the Humber, Liverpool, Manchester, Newcastle, and Northumberland."

Ministers, including the chancellor, Gordon Brown, have argued that the jobs outlook for Britain is now much more uniform than it was in the 80's and early 90's, with regional disparities narrowing and a growing number of unfilled vacancies.

Cambridge Econometrics said there was evidence that the real level of unemployment was being under-reported in areas where job prospects were weak. It said a shortage of skills was the key factor for fewer than one-in-three unemployed workers claiming benefit.

"More than 300,000 unemployed live in areas where skills mismatch appears to be the dominant issue," it said, adding that most of these lived in Scotland, Wales and scattered parts of the north including Durham and the Wirral. Scottish areas have seen the decline of traditional manufacturing sectors, such as shipbuilding, mechanical engineering and textiles and it appears that the unemployed are not taking up jobs in the thriving electronics sector and, in some areas, growing services employment.

"However, more than 450,000 unemployed are in areas where a jobs shortfall appears to be the dominant issue, with the majority of them in the north of England."

With the report also forecasting that growth in the south will continue to outstrip that in the north, the findings are likely to fuel demands for the government to take a more aggressive approach to regional policy, with action to increase the demand for labour in areas that have yet to feel the benefits of more than eight years of economic growth.

One of the factors that contributed to the lengthening of the dole queues in the early 80's was the arrival in the workforce of the baby boomer generation.

webTitle: Cinven to pay £434m for parts supplier

fields.headline: Cinven to pay £434m for parts supplier
fields.trailText: Private equity provider Cinven yesterday agreed to acquire private aerospace parts group McKechnie for £434m in cash.
fields.body:
Private equity provider Cinven yesterday agreed to acquire private aerospace parts group McKechnie for £434m in cash.

The announcement came three months after McKechnie, a manufacturer of plastic and metal products for the telecom and aerospace industries, said it was in talks about a possible offer for the company.

McKechnie's chairman, Vanni Treves, said the decision to buy took into account that the company was trading below expectations and re-structuring might be necessary.

The company saw its share price fall from more than 520p last September to 230p in March as it struggled to drive up sales.

Mr Treves said pre-tax profit in the year ended July 31 were not more than £50m; below market expectations and down on last year's £59m.

"Further, no other firm offers have been made for the group. These factors make a significant re-rating of McKechnie unlikely in the foreseeable future and we therefore intend unanimously to recommend McKechnie shareholders to vote in favour of the proposals," he said in a written statement.

The offer values each McKechnie share at 400p. McKechnie shares closed at 371p on Friday.

The price represents a 26% premium over McKechnie's closing price of 317p on May 9, just before the announcement of offer talks.

Cinven has formed a company called BlueAzure to manage the purchase.

webTitle: Monday briefing

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

Fears are growing in top financial circles of a further slump in hi-tech shares, which may prompt a global stock market crash. Investors in the US appear to have lost patience with growth funds that rely on dot.com stocks and could sell heavily over the next month.

Singer & Freidlander, the merchant bank, has decided to pull out of large-scale City dealmaking, the newspaper said. It is understood to have sold it corporate finance division to its management for a nominal sum.

Sunday Times

Royal Dutch/Shell has contacted BG Group about the possibility of buying the gas firm's exploration and production business, which analysts value at £8bn. Shell made the informal contact months ago, after BG announced it would de-merge this autumn into BG International (the E&P business) and Transco, the British pipelines arm.

Vodafone is expected to announce a trade sale of its Italian fixed-line phone and internet business, Infostrada , which is valued at more than £6bn. Vodafone previously said it would float 49.9% of the business later this year.

Sunday Telegraph

Dick Shoemate, chairman, president and chief executive of Bestfoods , the US food company, is due to receive a $9.5m (£6.6m) payoff from Unilever , which is buying the company. It is one of the biggest severance packages ever paid by a British company.

Up to 12,000 newsagents are threatened with closure and newspaper and magazine companies could lose annual sales of up to £150m if Tesco goes ahead with plans to set up a joint distribution deal with WH Smith , according to a report. The report, for the Newspapers Publishers Association , is to be sent to MPs and other opinion formers in an effort to block the deal.

Sunday Business

Photo-Me International non-executive chairman Dan David is to resign as the company draws up a new board "from scratch" the newspaper said. The move follows a sharp decline in the company's share price and an accounting error that has delayed full-year results, originally due out tomorrow.

The French state-owned railway group, SNCF is this week expected to confirm that it wants to build a new inter-city route across the Pennines. Costing £2bn, the joint bid with transport company First Group is one of many going forward for approval to the strategic rail authority, which devised the franchise. Arriva and a Virgin Rail-Stagecoach partnership have also submitted proposals for the route.

Emap has approached a national newspaper group regarding the formation of a £1.5bn joint bid for IPC Media . The approach was said to have been rejected, but Emap is reported to be keen to find a partner to avoid competition problems because any deal involving both companies will be examined closely by competition authorities.

IoS

The Department of Trade and Industry is understood to have been advised by its lawyers to pursue a criminal prosecution of the City Slickers, the two former Mirror journalists sacked earlier this year for alleged insider trading.

Nomura , the Japanese bank backing the £105m purchase of the Millennium Dome, wants to create a network of domes across the continent. Guy Hands, who heads the bank's principal finance group in the UK, also believes there is room for one or two more domes in Britain.

Mail on Sunday

John Prescott has agreed to back the first expansion of an out-of-town shopping mall for almost10 years. Metro Centre , outside Gateshead, will be able to increase in size by 10%, adding a new department store and 27 shops.

Insurance group CGNU is to cut its global risk division, placing more than 600 jobs at risk. The division looks after business for some of the insurer's largest clients, but is to be closed following last week's profits fall.

Friday

Thursday

Friday

US Retail sales (Jul). FR Current account (May).

webTitle: Today's radio

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Morning Performance/Engineering Eden
fields.body:
Sean Rafferty offers the first of five 90-minute selections from the wide range on offer last month at one of Europe's newest music festivals. Morning Performance (11.30am, Radio 3) is devoted to the West Cork Chamber Music Festival, now in its fifth year and with a fast-growing reputation. Its repertoire runs from the Baroque to the contemporary, interspersing concerts with masterclasses. This session leans heavily on Mozart (pictured) and features Hallelujah Games, Amy Rubin's recent work for piano and percussion.

In a new three-part series, Jolyon Jenkins investigates whether we can reinstate landscapes devastated by human activity. Engineering Eden (9.0pm, Radio 4) takes him to America to meet Steve Packard, who has galvanised 5,000 volunteers into rehabilitating 27,000 acres of mid-Western prairie, ideally with buffalo herds grazing there again. Further south, the Army Corps of Engineers hopes to restore the Florida Everglades to something near their primordial glory.

webTitle: Weekend TV:  Gareth McLean

fields.headline: Very bad things
fields.standfirst: Weekend TV:  Gareth McLean
fields.trailText: Road To Riches/Movie Virgins/The X Files/Wildlife On One: Pussies Galore
fields.body:
David Starkey is like a mischievous mechanic. There was the creasy-faced, steady pair of hands Peter Jay steering along the Road To Riches (BBC2, Sunday) towards his theory that the industrial revolution turned us all into consumers, when along came Starkey on a bus, ready to throw spanners into poor Peter's works like confetti.

On the bus in Bath - destination, one can only presume: Contrary City - and continuing this surprisingly accessible yet thoughtful series, Starkey advanced the theory that it was consumers who drove the industrial revolution, not vice versa. In his distinctive diction - sounding like he's trying to work a toffee off his back teeth - he persuasively argued: "Market first, smoke-stack industry second". Bath was the Bluewater of the 1700s, and it was voracious consumer demand that built grim factories and dark Satanic mills, the call centres of their day.

According to Starkey, vice and badness drove the economy - war, greed, dishonesty, promiscuity - and not the we-must-have-no-fun Protestant work ethic at all. For a moment, Jay looked a bit lost as his passenger questioned his navigational and driving skills. It was a joy to see. As was Bath, actually. Looks a lovely place. Bet the pair got themselves high tea and forgot their differences.

The blokes featured in Movie Virgins (C4, Sunday) should probably get out more. Leon Herbert and Alex Jovy, two wannabe feature film directors, were so intent on making their respective movies, they seemed to have lost all sense of reality, not to mention their sanity. Leon had no money but was determined to make Emotional Backgammon, a film he billed as a glorious human interest story of love and loss - actually a cliché-packed, misogynist pile of nonsense.

Surprisingly, it was difficult to warm to Leon, swanning round in Lily Savage cast-off chinoiserie dressing gowns in his north London flat, which made Gianni Versace's Miami mansion look like a minimalist temple. With serious delusions of grandeur, he said things like "Women always leave you when they love you" and "I couldn't bear to shoot it on video". Alex, meanwhile, was equally irksome. His film, "a very commercial thriller set in London's clubland" sounded equally appalling, though Alex had the edge on Leon because he said things like "Kate Moss really likes the script" and "Mick Jagger would really like to play Damian". (Whether he met the famous Kate and Mick or another Kate and Mick, from Sunderland say, we never found out). One of the All Saints was interested too, he half-pleaded on the phone. If there's a reason for this movie never to be made, there it was.

Amazingly though, the pair progressed, with Alex getting a meeting with Fox Searchlight and Leon heading to Polygram in one of Jonathan Ross's old suits. By the end of the episode, Leon was all set to start filming (maybe next week he'll be dressed from a jumble sale at Latoya Jackson's) and Alex was in Cannes. He was supposed to be going waterskiing with Ewan McGregor. A veritable shoo-in to get Jude Law to star in his movie, then. If television adds 10 pounds, Movie Virgins proved it also magnifies character defects. It must be nice to have so much self-confidence. Or be so deluded. Fingers crossed they fail miserably.

A pleasant success was The X Files (BBC1, Saturday). With David Duchovny taking both writing and directing credit as well as starring, it could have been some horrible self-indulgent Mulder-centric mush, but Duchovny's efforts were generous to everyone else concerned. Obviously, it was all about Mulder (roll on the series when he gets abducted and Scully actually gets some stories of her own and a chance to develop properly as a character), but with most of the episode set in Roswell in 1947 and concerned with an alien (or is he?) pretending to be a baseball player, Duchovny's Mulder only appeared intermittently. In a couple of tender and funny scenes with Gillian Anderson's Scully, he gave her the best lines and managed to wring another bit of sexual tension out of their closeness, just when you thought that was an over-furrowed field.

There's something about Sunday nights that lends them to cosiness. What you need is something comforting, warm and fuzzy. In the absence of Pam Ferris from Where The Heart Is, Wildlife On One: Pussies Galore (BBC1, Sunday) was marvellous. So many cats scampering around was good enough, but then some kittens turned up! Bless.

webTitle: The stars before they were famous: Michael Douglas

fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: The stars before they were famous
fields.body:
Michael Keaton in Night Shift (Ron Howard, 1982)

Who? Michael Douglas - but that was already taken, so he changed his surname. His breakthrough role came here, and he ploughed a similar light comedy furrow with Mr Mom (1983) and Johnny Dangerously (1984). But it wasn't long before directors noticed the malevolence lurking beneath the funny guy veneer, casting him as a coke fiend in 1988's Clean And Sober, and a tenant from hell in Pacific Heights (1990). His most fruitful working relationship has been with goth genius Tim Burton, who cast him in Beetlejuice (1988) and, most famously, Batman (1989). Hiring Keaton, best known for his comedy roles, to play the tortured superhero angered a lot of nerdy comics fans, but that was before Val Kilmer got to have a go (now, that really angered them). Keaton dated Courteney Cox for many years, but her level of celebrity subsequently rocketed past his, and she wound up marrying David Arquette instead. Them's the breaks...

The role: Bill Blazejowski ("but folks call me Billy Blaze"), a motormouth who works the - here comes the title - nightshift at a morgue. He's the one who urges his uptight colleague Chuck Lumley (Henry Winkler) to turn the morgue into a brothel during the wee small hours.

Best line: Picking up a photo from Chuck's desk, he asks "Who's this? Your wife?" "Fiancee," Chuck replies. Bill looks closely at the picture: "Nice frame."

Cringe factor: Apart from the worryingly tight jeans, pretty low. It's the usual Keaton shtick - hyperactive, wise-cracking and kind of annoying.

Other wannabes: An 11-year-old Shannen Doherty.

Critical judgement: Leonard Maltin calls it a "delightful, good-natured comedy".

Also not starring in: A 1979 TV series called Working Stiffs.

Night Shift, Sky Cinema, Friday 11 August, 8pm

Hiring Keaton, best known for his comedy roles, to play the tortured superhero angered a lot of nerdy comics fans, but that was before Val Kilmer got to have a go (now, that really angered them). Keaton dated Courteney Cox for many years, but her level of celebrity subsequently rocketed past his, and she wound up marrying David Arquette instead. Them's the breaks... The role: Bill Blazejowski ("but folks call me Billy Blaze"), a motormouth who works the - here comes the title - nightshift at a morgue. He's the one who urges his uptight colleague Chuck Lumley (Henry Winkler) to turn the morgue into a brothel during the wee small hours. Best line: Picking up a photo from Chuck's desk, he asks "Who's this? Your wife?" "Fiancee," Chuck replies. Bill looks closely at the picture: "Nice frame." Cringe factor: Apart from the worryingly tight jeans, pretty low. It's the usual Keaton shtick - hyperactive, wise-cracking and kind of annoying. Other wannabes: An 11-year-old Shannen Doherty. Critical judgement: Leonard Maltin calls it a "delightful, good-natured comedy". Also not starring in: A 1979 TV series called Working Stiffs. Night Shift, Sky Cinema, Friday 11 August, 8pm

webTitle: Today's TV

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Adventures Of Robin Hood/Rush Hour/Blue Velvet/The Velvet Underground: Curious
fields.body:
The Adventures Of Robin Hood

(William Keighley, Michael Curtiz, 1938)

7pm, TCM

By far the best Robin Hood in the wood. It's played with enormous brio, Errol Flynn at his devil-may-care best as the hero, Olivia de Havilland his haughty but melting Maid Marian. And Basil Rathbone and Claude Rains make a fine dastardly duo as Guy of Gisbourne and Prince John. The non-stop, high-spirited action builds to a classic final duel ("You've come to Nottingham once too often..."), all of it superbly photographed in the new, lustrous Technicolor.

Rush Hour

(Brett Ratner, 1998)

8pm, Sky MovieMax

The indestructible Jackie Chan (pictured) bounces back for more martial arts mayhem. He's a Hong Kong supercop, in LA to find the kidnapped daughter of an old pal; Chris Tucker's the local detective assigned to keep him out of trouble. Amid the usual frenetic, beautifully choreographed action scenes, Ken Leung makes a worthy, high-kicking adversary, but the best of it is in the chalk-and-cheese pairing of Chan and Tucker.

Blue Velvet

(David Lynch, 1986)

10pm, FilmFour

Disturbing, voyeuristic peep at smalltown America, with a Buñuelian sense of the surreal. Kyle MacLachlan is the young chap whose discovery of a severed ear is an entrée into a macabre underworld; the relationship between nightclub singer Isabella Rossellini and a deeply disturbed Dennis Hopper is gut-churning, his Frank Booth being one of the great screen studies in evil.

The Velvet Underground: Curious

11pm, VH1

Some 25 years after the fact, a 1993 European tour provided a chance for the four original members of The Velvets to talk about being the world's biggest cult band. In the light of their subsequent bickering, it's telling that they're interviewed individually, but it's still fascinating. Reed feels that time has vindicated their initial lack of sales; Mo Tucker is happy to give the fans a chance to actually see them. Scenes from Warhol's Factory era and live footage from 1993 round things out.

webTitle: Rich Brazilians look down on crime and traffic.

fields.headline: Rich Brazilians look down on crime and traffic.
fields.standfirst: Kidnappers, carjackers and congestion make Sao Paulo the world's helicopter capital.
fields.trailText: Every morning the man leaves his gated community by helicopter. He is not alone: the sky is full of helicopters taking the rich to work above an endless sprawl of high-rise blocks and streets jammed with traffic.
fields.body:
Every morning the man leaves his gated community by helicopter. He is not alone: the sky is full of helicopters taking the rich to work above an endless sprawl of high-rise blocks and streets jammed with traffic.

This vision of helicopters being used like cars above the chaos of unplanned urban growth is already a reality in Sao Paulo, Brazil's bloated metropolis of 17m people.

According to the Sao Paulo Pilots' Association, more helicopter flights are made here than in any other city. Only the fleets in New York and Tokyo are bigger - the difference is that in Sao Paulo the craft are mainly privately owned.

Well-off Paulistanos use their helicopters not only for commuting but also for travelling to their weekend beach homes, and even for shopping. The boom has been so great in recent years that some apartment blocks lack the parking space to cope with the demand.

"Having a helicopter is not only accepted here but it is considered a necessary tool for existing," said Fabrice Cagnat, commercial director for Helibras, the Brazilian subsidiary of Eurocopter.

Sao Paulo's penchant for helicopters has grown partly as a result of its exaggerated social divides, in a country with one of the world's most unfair distributions of wealth. Kidnappings and carjackings are daily occurrences, and a growing number of Paulistanos are willing to pay up to put themselves out of danger by flying the skies.

Commander Marcos Braga, vice-president of the the Pilots' Association, said: "Helicopters bring security. Not just top executives but medium-level businessmen are realising it is worth it."

In the past 100 years Sao Paulo has become Latin America's most important industrial and financial centre, and the engine that drives the Brazilian economy. But its infrastructure has not kept up with the steep rise in population caused by the millions of migrants who have arrived from poorer parts of the country seeking work.

With only three underground lines, no proper network of major roads, and a significant part of the population rich enough to afford cars, massive traffic delays are inevitable.

"At some times during the day it can take three hours to cross from the north of the city to the south. In a helicopter you can do it in five to seven minutes," Fabrice Cagnat said.

Since 1994 the number of helicopters in Sao Paulo has quadrupled to about 450, compared to 700 in Tokyo and 2,000 in New York.

"From my point of view the boom has hardly started," Commander Braga said.

"There would be a lot more helicopters if it wasn't for the currency crash in 1999. Growth has already climbed to 30% this year. And people are buying bigger helicopters too."

On Avenida Paulista, Sao Paulo's main business street, there are about 80 helicopter landings a day.

For the Sao Paulo Formula One race at Interlagos earlier this year, helicopters made 2,000 landings.

"Already we are seeing traffic jams in the sky," a pilot said.

The new helicopter society is changing the landscape of Sao Paulo. As you fly into the city's airport you can see dozens of helipads on the high-rise buildings. Even shopping centres have started to cater for aerial arrivals.

webTitle: Leader: Britain has not got the hang of online retail

fields.headline: e-up and e-down
fields.standfirst:
Click here for the receivers
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: England may be a nation of shopkeepers but it isn't, and may never be, a nation of e-tailers. People have been surprised by the collapse of such high-profile online shops as Boo.com and Clickmango, which crashed last week despite having Joanna Lumley as its figurehead. They should not have been. Half of all new businesses fail within their first four years and the death rate for dot.com companies ought to be even higher.
fields.body:
England may be a nation of shopkeepers but it isn't, and may never be, a nation of e-tailers. People have been surprised by the collapse of such high-profile online shops as Boo.com and Clickmango, which crashed last week despite having Joanna Lumley as its figurehead. They should not have been. Half of all new businesses fail within their first four years and the death rate for dot.com companies ought to be even higher. Yet if they had been ordinary small companies they would have withered away unnoticed. Because they are using a new medium to sell their goods they attract attention. Clickmango.com, for instance, was notching up sales of only £2,000 a week. This is corner shop stuff. Lastminute.com managed to push transaction sales up to £1m in the three months to June, on which it made trading losses of over £11m. It is a good job it still has £117m in the bank from its flotation to see it through.

Lastminute is at least doing something original. The problem with other online retailers is that they are merely selling old economy goods in a more expensive way without the brand loyalties their (traditional) competitors enjoy. Building up a brand from scratch can be expensive - and that's before the huge cost of installing a new distribution system. It has been the same sorry story in the US. The American shakeout has left three companies - Amazon.com, eBay the online auction house and Priceline.com - with 90% of the market value of online retailing.

In recent months, e-tailers have had to contend with the downward pressures on prices that the internet generates because of the consumer's ability to move to a cheaper source. In the US, failure in business is regarded as a rite of passage whereas in Britain it still carries a stigma. It is time we learned to be more mature. Judging by the escalating rate of failures, it looks as though we are going to get lots more opportunities.

webTitle: Leader: Stephen Byers should be pragmatic and proud

fields.headline: Intervention works
fields.standfirst:
Byers should be pragmatic and proud
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Trade secretary Stephen Byers has not exactly set the Thames on fire with his summer series of speeches about government's relationship with industry. That is partly because he is still a political juvenile, forever consulting the script (Tony's book of Third Way apophthegms) before opening his mouth. It is also that Mr Byers cannot, as a loyal minister, ask hard questions about the boundary between his department and others.
fields.body:
Trade secretary Stephen Byers has not exactly set the Thames on fire with his summer series of speeches about government's relationship with industry. That is partly because he is still a political juvenile, forever consulting the script (Tony's book of Third Way apophthegms) before opening his mouth. It is also that Mr Byers cannot, as a loyal minister, ask hard questions about the boundary between his department and others. On one side there are agriculture and environment (which control regional development agencies), on the other defence, a major purchaser from British industry, and David Blunkett's responsibilities for skills and employment.

There is a further, profound reason why he does not cut a commanding figure. Mr Byers wants to lay down principles. They veer in a free-market direction. State intervention is a bad thing. But this is from an MP with a seat in the north-east. So he also notes the "exceptional circumstances" when emergency aid or sandwiches round a table in Victoria Street might be justified to stop a firm going bust. He is trying to be too schematic. In our post-socialist age, trade secretaries should revel in the sheer pragmatism of their position. Employees afflicted by impending closure of their factory or office must have recourse to political action. They must expect - demand - the government attempts to save their jobs. The alternative is some horrible fatalism, which in turn becomes a recipe for alienation or destabilising anger at the injustice of the economic system. Governments must, in Baden-Powell's words, be prepared. Stephen Byers, so typical of New Labour in this, wants to believe in the essential benignity of big business. Corporate boards are full of kind and gentle people, caring for customers, co-workers and the common good. As if. Governments will find it hard to counter the power of multinationals. Big companies will threaten to pull out of one jurisdiction and relocate to a more favourable one - to stop such leapfrogging is one of the very purposes of the European Union. Unless ministers are willing to carry a big stick and occasionally issue threats, they are effectively conceding the field to corporate capitalism, warts and all.

Mr Byers's confusion about his role is understandable. We lack, these days, clean explanations of what the state can do to make private business more effective at creating jobs and income. Preaching about productivity to gatherings of great and good business people may not achieve a great deal. The DTI is shortly to issue its latest plan for the regulation of competition. Ministers will be invited to keep out, leaving decisions to neutral experts at the office of fair trading and competition commission, as if appraising mergers were merely technical. It is not. The shape of a market, like the rewards of directors, is a legitimate object of political concern. What is wrong with attempting, in any given market sector, to create a "national champion" with all that entails for corporate size? Or railing at boardroom greed?

In his speechmaking so far Mr Byers has steered clear of training and personnel, keys to adding value in all organisations. Perhaps it is because he knows many companies take a dim view of improving staff skills. Finance capital does not have much time for human capital. So it is usually the state that educates and that, as Labour recognises, is a lifelong project. If Whitehall were rationally organised, the DTI, education and employment would occupy the same administrative space. But would Mr Byers command it?

webTitle: Jews and Arabs join in deploring rabbi's tirade

fields.headline: Jews and Arabs join in deploring rabbi's tirade
fields.trailText: The bad boy of the Israeli rabbinate created a rare unity between Arab and Jew yesterday, scandalising his own people by saying that the millions killed in the Nazi Holocaust were sinners, and outraging Palestinians by declaring them accursed "snakes" despised by God.
fields.body:
The bad boy of the Israeli rabbinate created a rare unity between Arab and Jew yesterday, scandalising his own people by saying that the millions killed in the Nazi Holocaust were sinners, and outraging Palestinians by declaring them accursed "snakes" despised by God.

The outpourings from Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef, who devoted his Saturday sermon to the Holocaust and the Arab-Israeli peace process, caused a firestorm as prominent Israeli rabbis and politicians as well as Palestinians took to the airwaves to deplore his views.

"The victims of the Holocaust, all 6 million Jews, all those poor people who were lost at the hands of those evildoers the Nazis were reincarnations of earlier souls who sinned time and again and did all sorts of things that shouldn't have been done, and were reincarnated so that things could be set right," the rabbi told a crowded synagogue in Jerusalem, and thousands of followers who tuned in on pirate radio stations.

He berated the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, for trying to make peace with the Palestinians. "Why are you bringing them close to us? You bring snakes next to us. How can you make peace with a snake?" Rabbi Ovadiah told his applauding followers.

"The Ishmaelites [Arabs] are all accursed evil people. They are all haters of Israel. God regrets having created these Ishmaelites," he went on.

Rabbi Ovadiah's fulminations cannot easily be dismissed. A former chief rabbi of Israel, and a religious scholar of some repute, he is also the spiritual leader of the Shas party, the kingmaker of Israeli coalition politics.

Shas, which combines ultra-Orthodox theology and ethnic pride of Middle Eastern Jews, is the third largest party in the Israeli knesset, or parliament, and Mr Barak is desperate to woo its 17 parliamentarians back to his coalition. That explains the prime minister's tepid response yesterday.

Ignoring the slur against the Palestinians, Mr Barak said the rabbi's comments did not befit a religious leader of his stature. "They are liable to harm the memory of those who perished in the Holocaust and the feelings of their family members," his office said in a statement.

Mr Barak's silence on the attack on Arabs was inexcusable, said the Palestinian information minister, Yasser Abed Rabbo. "Every Israeli stands accused of being a racist until he condemns this racist and idiot."

An Israeli Arab member of the Knesset, Ahmed Tibi, said he would ask Israel's attorney general to charge the rabbi. That seems unlikely; the attorney general has already refused to charge Rabbi Ovadiah with incitement after he called the secular education minister an enemy of the Jews who should be liquidated.

webTitle: Racing driver David Coulthard tells  Richard Williams about the world of formula one.

fields.headline: 'Last week I did some laundry... I thoroughly enjoyed ironing a pair of trousers'
fields.standfirst: Racing driver David Coulthard tells  Richard Williams  about the glamorous world of formula one
fields.trailText: Racing driver David Coulthard tells  Richard Williams  about the glamorous world of formula one
fields.body:
It was the night before the German grand prix, and David Coulthard was doing the ironing. This is not something you would expect to read in connection with the great heroes of motor racing history. Who could imagine the Marques Alfonso de Portago y Cabeza - Ferrari driver of the 50s, Olympic fencer, bobsleigh champion and legendary lover - doing the domestic chores?

But the times are different, and so is David Coulthard, the courteous, unassuming and thoroughly sensible 29-year-old Scottish grand prix driver who hit the front pages three months ago when he pulled his fiancée from the wreckage of a private jet in which the pilot and co-pilot had perished. Coulthard is different from the heroes of the mythical past, different even from his contemporaries. And different, some say, from the David Coulthard that he used to be.

A year ago Coulthard would have stuffed his dirty washing in a hotel laundry bag and called down to get it picked up. If a friend asked him which hotel he was in, he would probably have needed to consult his key tag. This year, all that has changed. Instead of leapfrogging from hotel to hotel, now Coulthard parks a large blue and white motorhome - the colours of his racing helmet, patterned on the flag of St Andrew - in a corner of the pad dock. In the virtual world of Bernie Ecclestone's formula one, this looks very much like one man's way of restoring a bit of normality to his life.

"That's absolutely correct," he says, sitting in the office of his father's haulage company in Twynholm, a village half an hour's drive from Dumfries. And, with telling clarity, he recalls the decisive moment. "One day, about two years ago, I was at a test session in France, at the Magny Cours circuit, and I felt absolutely lifeless. I remember finishing early and checking in at the hotel and asking at the reception, 'What is there to do in this area?' And the guy didn't have an answer for me because there was nothing to do. Magny Cours is in the middle of nowhere. I went to my room. I had a book to read but I had no motivation to do that, and there was no one that I particularly wanted to talk to on the phone. I thought, what am I doing? It just felt like I was giving away part of my life to ... nothing. That's when I decided to get the motorhome."

Racing drivers don't often talk like this. More usually, they want you to know what a great time they had with a bunch of supermodels at that party in Milan last week, or how fast their new speedboat will go. Coulthard is indeed engaged to be married to a model, the very thin and very blonde Heidi Wichlinksi, and his current salary is around £5m a year but he seems to have held on to the sort of self-questioning modesty that befits his solid upbringing in a village where the name of Seaman Thos W Coulthard RN is on the memorial to the victims of the 1914-18 war.

"I suppose this is slightly bizarre," he says, "but last weekend at Hockenheim I was in the motorhome alone because Heidi was working, and I did some laundry. I did some ironing - I haven't ironed in a long time. I guess it doesn't sound very glamorous, but I thoroughly enjoyed ironing a pair of trousers and watching the telly and getting myself ready for the next day. I like organising my own little environment. I can invite into it those I want to be there and keep out those I don't."

Along with the desire to reclaim a bit of his life this year came a deter mination to rid himself of the reputation for lacking a mean streak on the track, largely the result of his honourable behaviour in Australia in 1998, when he stuck by the terms of a pre-race agreement and moved aside to let his team-mate, Mika Hakkinen, win the race. "I went through a period when I was perceived as being a soft touch, somebody who moves over, who is not hungry enough to win," he says.

Some suggest the ordeal of the air crash added a final touch of steely resolution to his character. He is reluctant to discuss the event and its consequences, unwilling to do anything that might cause further distress to the families of the two men who died, but in any case such a melodramatic claim crumbles under scrutiny. Since the accident he has indeed won two races, but he had won at Silverstone immediately before it.

Tall, slender and unusually square-jawed, Coulthard can look - sitting in his car during a practice session, wearing his flameproof balaclava - like a Burne-Jones knight on the eve of battle. He has been racing since his father put him in a go-kart at the age of eight, he made his formula one debut in 1994, as Damon Hill's team-mate, and he currently stands second in the championship, which intensifies the requirement for him to fit endless sponsorship commitments around his schedule. And now, in Twynholm, his father has opened a small David Coulthard museum. But the image side of the grand prix world is not his thing. "I go through periods when I think that, other than on the track, this isn't really very much fun," he says. "It's having to try to deal with the constant questioning when things aren't going very well, people poking you to try and get a response and perhaps taking you close to the edge emotionally."

He lives in Monaco, like several of his rivals. "It's a very closed, controlled environment," he says, with evident approval. "When you're there you don't get any reminders that you're a grand prix driver. But every other Thursday, when I walk through into the paddock at a grand prix, and there are 1,000 cameras there, the reality comes back - this is the part of this world that I don't like, but I have to endure it because it gets me to the bit I do enjoy."

As a man to whom being grown-up means being in control of his emotions, he dislikes leaping around on the victory rostrum but does it because that's what the photographers want. "I think, why the hell do I have to be a showman? But then I realise that the reason you get the opportunity to do this is because of the public's dream that it must be fantastic to do this job, and they want to see that it's fantastic. They want to live it through you. I haven't quite sussed that part out yet, and I don't know if I ever will."

One part he may be getting sussed out is the significance of personal conflict, a vital factor in formula one's vast box-office appeal. As a boy, Coulthard watched on television as Mansell, Prost, Senna and Piquet fought often ill-tempered battles. Now he and Michael Schumacher are indulging in an acrimonious run ning squabble of their own. Two years ago, after a couple of mid-race collisions, Schumacher accused Coulthard of trying to kill him. This season the German and the Scot have tangled again. "It makes life a wee bit interesting," he says, without giving the impression that he enjoys it.

So what does he really think of Schumacher? "Two different things. As a man I think he's a decent guy, a family man, quite straightforward. Given the hero worship and his vast wealth, it would be very easy for him not to be quite as normal as he is, privately. Publicly, as a racing driver, I'm not entirely comfortable with his inability to realise that he does make mistakes and it's not always someone else who's entirely to blame.

"I had a conversation with him last year, and I said: 'In your home, are you always right and your wife is always wrong?' He went: 'No, no, that's different.'

"I said: 'It's not different. It's values. It's understanding what right and wrong are. I believe I have those values and you clearly don't. Now we can leave this room today and never speak to each other again, and I'll have a happy life and you'll have a happy life, but it would be a shame because we live in the same world, as competitors, and part of the enjoyment I get from competing is to look my fellow competitors in the eye. The human side is very important.'

"He had to agree on that and we shook hands and walked away. Until the next time we fell out."

Their latest spat erupted when Coulthard complained about Schumacher's habit of weaving across the track. For a couple of races they didn't talk to each other but before the grand prix in Germany 10 days ago, Schumacher made an unexpected move. "It was a bit like what happens after two kids have fallen out in the playground. Eventually the one who thinks that maybe he was a little bit wrong makes the gesture of coming back and saying, 'Do you want a sweetie?' As we were coming out of one of the corners in the forest, Michael tapped me on the shoulder and said: 'Do you think there should be a kerb on the outside of this corner?' There was absolutely no need for a kerb at that part of the circuit. But I took it as his gesture at trying to start the conversation again. And I accepted it."

He will retire to start a "normal life", he says, when he loses the buzz he experiences before a race, when he gets "as nervous as I did when I was 11". But losing his nerve is unlikely to play a part. "I think some guys will probably never get fear in their whole lives, and other guys will get it. I think in Damon's case, he came up against fear. At Hockenheim last year I remember him saying to me, 'I can't do this any more.' I was pretty shocked. I was thinking, God, we've still got a few races to go - if you're saying that, why not stop now? Why take the risk? There are considerable risks in doing these speeds, and if you don't see that as a challenge and a thrill, then it's got to be too frightening. I never want to put myself in a position where I'm frightened. I just don't do things that frighten me."

webTitle: Letters: The Parthenon frieze debate

fields.headline: The case against losing your Marbles
fields.trailText: Jonathan Jones says that the Parthenon frieze is "a beautiful vision of a radically democratic society" (Tainted love, G2, August 3).
fields.body:
Jonathan Jones says that the Parthenon frieze is "a beautiful vision of a radically democratic society" (Tainted love, G2, August 3). But democracy in ancient Greece often produced turmoil and breakdown. That's why Plato and others rejected it. Nor did democracy make armies any less cruel and merciless. Despite the optical refinement of the architecture and the realism of the sculpture, despite the myth-building by later eras, art then did not embody in visual form the perceptions, awarenesses and social knowledge to transcend this ugly state of affairs.

It is doubtful that false assumptions will be exposed by your question "What happens to great art when it is taken from its original setting?", while it is addressed with a mindset that treats form and affective response as separate from the unconscious ideology and socio-economic factors conditioning such art and our reactions to it.
Mandy Tango
London

Jones implies that the sculptures could be reunited with the Parthenon. In fact, as the Greek government has admitted, this would not be possible because of the severe pollution which has damaged the sculptures left there by Lord Elgin. There is nowhere in Athens for the Marbles to go. There is a proposal to build a museum to house them (not on the Acropolis, the site of the Parthenon) but it has encountered objections: it would have to be constructed on stilts over an important archeological site, in an active earthquake zone. Even assuming the Greek authorities can agree on a design for this museum - which they have been unable to do - what would be lost if the Marbles were to leave the British Museum would be irreplaceable: the possibility of historical and cultural compassion, and the sense of the Marbles' artistic pre-eminence, in the setting of a vast international collection. Every visitor to London can enjoy for free (not the case in the proposed Athenian centre) examining these carvings at ground level - a privilege last enjoyed by the dinner guests of Pericles during the building of the Parthenon.
Michael Daley
Art Watch UK

webTitle: Letters: Miscellaneous

fields.headline: Joan is back on the map
fields.trailText: Commenting on the Globe Theatre, Helena Newton (Letters, August 5) remarks: "Joan Littlewood must be turning in her grave".
fields.body:
Commenting on the Globe Theatre, Helena Newton (Letters, August 5) remarks: "Joan Littlewood must be turning in her grave". Since she rang me today, I can say in all truthfulness that Joan Littlewood is alive and well and living in Paris. As to the matter of Sam Wanamaker, Joan does not hold it against him for being American. He was an old friend who, in 1952, helped Theatre Workshop get the show Uranium 235 into the Embassy Theatre, Swiss Cottage.
Peter Rankin
London
peteran@globalnet.co.uk

Why does the Guardian continue to publish such outlandish maps of Scotland? Your latest (Hi-tech jobs at stake, August 4) shows Edinburgh on the Clyde and a place called Kilbride (East Kilbride? West Kilbride?) in Lothian. During the recent Open you amazed visiting golfers by moving St Andrews to Dunfermline, although your greatest coup was surely in swapping Skye with Mull last year.
AJ Mullay
Edinburgh (in bottom right-hand corner of most maps)
ajmullay@yahoo.co.uk

I would happily harvest the fruits of my Araucaria araucana (Letters, August 5) if someone would explain how to collect them without getting maimed... but surely that was always the puzzle for the monkey?
David Swaysland
Stourbridge, West Midlands
david.swaysland@which.net

Surely the applause between movements at the Proms, rather than being explained by the presence of Classic FM listeners (Letters August 5), is a result of the trend towards authentic performances and could be attributed to the influence of Radio 3? Audiences are simply following the habits of the 1800s. Peter Kershaw
Winchburgh, West Lothian
Peterkershaw@hotmail.com

webTitle: Letters: Premier Oil's presence in Burma condones suffering

fields.headline: Oil slicker letter
fields.trailText: Charles Jamieson (Letters, August 5) claims Premier Oil does not condone human rights abuses.
fields.body:
Charles Jamieson (Letters, August 5) claims Premier Oil does not condone human rights abuses. But to cooperate with a murderous regime is an act of condonation, especially when Burma's elected leader has begged foreign companies not to do so. He also claims that his company's influence is restricted to a 40- by 10-mile strip of lower Burma. But all deals with the junta provide the military with enough cash to finance atrocities all over a country the size of England and France put together. It may be true that a million Burmese will benefit from Premier's involvement; it is certainly true that millions more will suffer because of it.
Gerry Abbott
Manchester

webTitle: Letters: Doubt about Sarah's Law

fields.headline: Doubt about Sarah's Law
fields.trailText: I am puzzled about the reasoning behind the idea that the existence of a public register would have prevented the tragic murder of Sarah Payne (Paper relents over drive to shame, August 5).
fields.body:
I am puzzled about the reasoning behind the idea that the existence of a public register would have prevented the tragic murder of Sarah Payne (Paper relents over drive to shame, August 5). It is not being suggested that she was the victim of a "groomer" - someone living in her locality who befriended her - but of someone who snatched her at random.

Knowing that someone in the neighbourhood has past convictions for child offences doesn't change anything for parents at large. Surely we all monitor who befriends our children and exercise caution over unrelated adults who want to spend time alone with them? And as for "snatchers" or "pouncers" - how does knowing their home address change things? Any criminal can travel.

For a register to help you would need to know not only the potential criminal's address, but to be alerted every time they left the house.
Annie Robson
Stevenage
r.annie@virgin.net

Isn't the fundamental error of the campaign waged by the News of the World against sex offenders and in favour of "Sarah's Law" that we do not know if Sarah's murderer was a convicted offender, or even that it was a man?
David Mason
North Shields

Can we now look forward to a NoW campaign against the motor car, which kills and injures hundreds of children each year?
D Meredith
Manchester

You had Rebekah Wade's name and photo all right, but forgot to put her address. Me and some of my mates would like to have a street party outside her house. Take my meaning?
Bernard Crick
Edinburgh

As Mark Lawson notes (After Sarah, August 5), "establishment bodies ... have sheltered known sex offenders". Meanwhile the government is using weasel phrases like "controlled access", Jack Straw defends the brutal regimes in boarding schools as "eccentric British customs" and the victims remain, as usual, largely unheard. It's enough to make one want to start a riot.
Tim Browne
London
timundanita@hotmail.com

Mark Lawson is right to raise the Richard Jewell case. When is NoW going to pay up for damages to Mr Horgan and others it has wrongly accused? And why is it not being prosecuted for conduct likely to cause a breach of the peace?
Michael Ellman
London
Micellman@aol.com

webTitle: Letters: Definitions of Blairism

fields.headline: Polished definitions of Blairism
fields.trailText: I know that the English language is constantly changing, but did such an eminent person as Nigel Wilcockson, editor of the New Penguin English Dictionary (Blairism, noun: very difficult to define, August 5), really mean to say, as quoted, that "we went through no less than five different definitions before we finally reached agreement"?
fields.body:
I know that the English language is constantly changing, but did such an eminent person as Nigel Wilcockson, editor of the New Penguin English Dictionary (Blairism, noun: very difficult to define, August 5), really mean to say, as quoted, that "we went through no less than five different definitions before we finally reached agreement"?

Were all those years persuading young journalists to write "fewer than" wasted?
Mike Broadbent
Luton
mike_broadbent@yahoo.com

How about: "the abandonment and erosion of decency, compassion, justice and equality, collectively known as socialism, and reinforcing society's worse prejudices of greed, selfishness and bigotry, collectively known as Thatcherism."
Tim Waton
Leeds
twwatson@talk21.com

How did they manage to agree a definition of Blairism while retaining the "S" word within it ?
Bert Large
Beckenham, Kent
Bert@sabu.demon.co.uk

The text of your report is shaped by the assumption that Blairism is a phenomenon of the 1990s. However, in 1858, Oliver Wendell Holmes, in The Autocrat of the Breakfast-Table, defined blairing as "polishing into correctness and smoothness" (after the philosopher Hugh Blair, 1718-1800).

Whether by prescience or predetermination, it would seem that Wendell Holmes has much to teach the editor of the New Penguin English Dictionary: "Blairism, noun: the practice of polishing into correctness and smoothness."
Prof Kenneth R Seddon
Donaghadee, County Down
kseddon@genie.co.uk
