webTitle: Letters: Responses to the Queen Mother's birthday

fields.headline: Standing up for the salute
fields.trailText: I enjoyed Steve Bell's 41 bum salute cartoon immensely August (August 4)! It's time to replace the royals with a modern and democratic institution.
fields.body:
I enjoyed Steve Bell's 41 bum salute cartoon immensely August (August 4)! It's time to replace the royals with a modern and democratic institution. Unlike Maureen Coatman (Letters, August 5) I believe the main issue is not their attractiveness to foreign tourists. Other countries who got rid of their royal families find that tourists still visit.

For those interested in the history of monarchism, museums and historical monuments provide visitors with ample opportunity to learn about this; places like the Tower of London are popular despite the non-appearance of living royals.

If joining the euro means the end of the Windsors then the sooner we join the better. Harking back to outdated institutions with their in-built privileges only emphasises the disparity between those born into wealth and those who are not.
Gordon Smart
Glasgow
gordon.smart@talk21.com

Maureen Coatman asks how many tourists "would come to look at a man in a dark suit?" I can't see what obvious advantages a woman in a pastel frock has, but she seems to have overlooked the fact that when Charles eventually succeeds to the throne he will be precisely that; a man in a dark suit. Is she suggesting that Charles should go in for cross-dressing to liven up the pageantry?
Stephen Ashley
Ickenham, Middlesex
STEVETJ@aol.com

Steve Bell's cartoon, surely, was not only offensive to the Queen Mother (as it was meant to be) but to republicans. The natural implication was that republicans are brainless and mannerless louts, incapable of rational debate and obsessed with excretion. I doubt if this is universally true.
RL Sturch
Kidlington, Oxon
RSturch@compuserve.com

John Race (Letters, August 5) is right: even Steve Bell's strange obsession with bums does not excuse his gross insult to the Queen Mother on her 100th birthday. As an ex-PoW of the Japanese I feel particularly incensed because some of my fellow ex-prisoners gave this "bum salute" to their emperor in London, to demonstrate their anger at our appalling treatment during captivity and contemptuous lack of reparations afterwards.

To suggest that the Queen Mother deserves a similar gesture is ludicrous if not obscene. When in her 90s she showed that she at least had not forgotten us by spending hours chatting to many of us at a Guildhall reception.
Tony Searle
Abingdon, Oxon
TonySearle@abingdon106.freeserve.co.uk

I lived in east London, throughout the blitz. I did so because I was born there and had no alternative. When a land mine demolished the house in February 1941, we just dusted ourselves down and looked for a better hole. Had we the resources to move to a safer area, I am sure we would have done so. The Queen Mum did not see me through the blitz. She was a total irrelevance.
Ivy Alexander
Winchester

Let's be honest with ourselves: the Queen Mother and the rest of her dysfunctional family are not an "inspiration" to the majority of the British people. The huge expense incurred by maintaining this anachronism is not, I'm afraid, justified by the odd display of "wombles, winkle-pickers and reluctant camels". Get a grip, people!
Morgan P Thomas
Wembley, Middx
mpthomas@tinyworld.co.uk

Exhilarated, like all loyal citizens, by the sight of our Queen and her consort and the entire royal family, assembled on their family balcony, a truly terrifying thought entered my head: what if, under the assembled weight of Queen, consort, royal mother and numerous one-parent families, the balcony were to collapse? Of course, the Queen Mother would survive - that is her forté - but who would then sit on the throne? We should be told!
Val Smith
Coventry
ValVardre@aol.com

webTitle: Barak, Arafat pave way for Camp David II

fields.headline: Barak, Arafat pave way for Camp David II
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: With 37 days remaining before Yasser Arafat has vowed to declare an independent Arab state, Israelis and Palestinians are preparing the ground for a second encounter at Camp David, leading Palestinian figures said yesterday.
fields.body:
With 37 days remaining before Yasser Arafat has vowed to declare an independent Arab state, Israelis and Palestinians are preparing the ground for a second encounter at Camp David, leading Palestinian figures said yesterday.

"There are many contacts with the Israelis," Hassan Asfour, a senior negotiator, told the Guardian. "We have contacts: this is good news. How it will be is difficult to speak of at the moment, but you can say that we are on the first step of preparations for a summit."

Israeli newspapers reported yesterday that the Clinton administration was working behind the scenes to convene a second summit, possibly in late September.

Although the talks broke off last month without agreement, the Israelis and Palestinians - and the Americans, who are trying to broker a peace settlement between the two - all refuse to cast the initial summit as a failure, arguing that they had reached "understandings" in several areas.

The Tel Aviv newspaper Ha'aretz said secret talks got under way last week between Israeli cabinet ministers and senior Palestinian officials to explore potential areas for compromise on the most contentious issues dividing them: the status of the square kilometre of hallowed ground within the old walled city of Jerusalem, and the future of 3.6m registered Palestinian refugees.

Another senior Palestinian negotiator said that efforts would be redoubled in the run-up to September 13. That is the deadline Mr Arafat has set for a declaration of a Palestinian state, but in recent days he and senior aides have hinted strongly that the move could be delayed until after the US presidential elections in November.

"We have asked the Israeli side to engage immediately on extensive negotiations between the two sides on a daily basis." Saeb Erakat, a senior Palestinian negotiator, said yesterday. "We want to accomplish as much as possible in the next six weeks."

While the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, told his cabinet yesterday that it was premature to talk about a second summit, the reports in the Israeli press coincided with a flurry of diplomatic efforts - by both sides - intended to shore up their bargaining positions in advance of a summit.

After a disappointing meeting in Alexandria last Friday with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, Mr Barak is sending two close cabinet allies on a tour of European capitals this week. He has also appealed to Britain's Lord Levy to act as his emissary.

In Gaza Mr Arafat set off yesterday on another stage in his diplomatic campaign. After visits to South Africa and Turkey last week, he left for Libya and the United Arab Emirates to seek support for Palestinian claims to East Jerusalem, and the holy Muslim and Christian places of the Old City, occupied illegally by Israel since 1967.

Washington is also gearing up for a diplomatic campaign. The US envoy, Dennis Ross, is due in the region on August 20, a visit Israeli officials hope is a signal of further high-level American intervention. But a spokesman at the US embassy in Tel Aviv would not confirm reports that a summit could be announced soon.

Still, both sides see encouraging signs in recent days that negotiators could conjure up a deal that would allow Israel to give its blessing to the birth of a Palestinian state, and so minimise the chances of violent confrontation.

"It makes sense to me that a significant effort is being made to see whether we can build on the successes in Camp David, and to complete the job," said Joseph Alpher, an independent analyst who advised Mr Barak at the summit.

"Everything points to the determination of Mr Barak to move ahead and to achieve a successful peace deal."

The Israeli prime minister has no other option if he is to ensure his political survival. With early elections all but inevitable, he is desperate to reach an agreement with Mr Arafat that he can dangle before voters.

webTitle: French economy has emerged as the most dynamic of the large European Union economies

fields.headline: France gets to heart of problem
fields.standfirst: Debate: Andrew Tylecote
fields.trailText: There is something odd going on across the Channel. The French economy, allegedly weighed down by over-regulation and high taxes, has emerged as the most dynamic of the large European Union economies. It now has fast growth, low inflation, trade in surplus and falling unemployment. The French must be doing something right.
fields.body:
There is something odd going on across the Channel. The French economy, allegedly weighed down by over-regulation and high taxes, has emerged as the most dynamic of the large European Union economies. It now has fast growth, low inflation, trade in surplus and falling unemployment. The French must be doing something right.

They are. Once or twice a decade the modernising cross-party elite that runs France - state, big business, and everything else that counts - identifies a big problem and worries at it collectively until they have a solution.

In the 1970s they decided that German business was going upmarket in a way they could not match because their firms, particularly the smaller ones, were underspending on training and innovation. The state duly intervened: every firm had to pay a training levy, which it got back. Britain briefly had such a system - before Thatcher. An agency called Anvar provided funds to subsidise the research and development of smaller firms. It worked: the skills gap has shrunk.

In the 1980s the big problem was regional policy. The old system of instructing big French firms to locate new plants where jobs were needed looked dated in a globalising world. Why was the economy largely confined to Paris? As with London and the south-east, that was where most of the decisions were taken, and where higher education and the science base was concentrated. That had to be changed.

The process began in the early 1980s. Government and the civil service were decentralised. While Britain missed much of the regional subsidies available from Brussels because the Treasury balked at the condition that it must match them ecu for ecu, the French treasury has paid up. It has paid up in higher education and research.

But even that was not enough. It was proposed that the Ecole Nationale d'Administration be moved to Strasbourg. France gasped. The government also moved the elite engineering school, the Ecole Centrale, to Lyon. Imagine the London School of Economics being moved to Leeds.

The result is that other advantages provincial France already has - labour, space, the uncongested road and rail infrastructure - can really show their value. Its own small and medium firms are blossoming, and it is attracting multinational investment.

The Bank of England feels obliged to keep sterling interest rates high to prevent overheating in the south-east. In France, inflation remains below the British level in spite of low Euro interest rates and growth that has accelerated past Britain's. Of course, Britain has its own cross-party consensus that taxes must be kept low and business left to respond to market forces.

But it is already mostly government money that funds the university system, and it is allocated without any visible connection with regional policy. The public research funding mechanism, for example, funds universities according to their research output. Research output is higher when there is supplementary private funding: in London and the south-east.

It would not cost the British taxpayer an extra penny if the government were to recognise the regional skew of this funding and act against it. But perhaps it is only French governments that are capable of joined-up thinking.

Andrew Tylecote is Professor of the economics and management of technological change at the University of Sheffield

webTitle: Leader: English living in France

fields.headline: Purchasing in Périgord
fields.standfirst: An Englishman's home is his château
fields.trailText: Abbey National reports that half a million United Kingdom nationals now own domestic property in France. The boom associated with Peter Mayle's literary sojourn in Provence has continued.
fields.body:
Abbey National reports that half a million United Kingdom nationals now own domestic property in France. The boom associated with Peter Mayle's literary sojourn in Provence has continued. Perhaps Posy Simmonds's brilliant recapitulation of Flaubert played a part in re- advertising the delights of rural Normandy. Of course the tunnel has made the Nord-Pas du Calais more accessible, but France attracts because it is cheap. Metal bashers in the Midlands rue the strong pound but look what it does for the price of Gascon gîtes.

The locals are happy enough. José Bové and the sheep farmers of the Causse don't like the international terms of trade as they affect Roquefort but are unconcerned by the mobility of capital across the Channel. Where, after all, would the bricoleurs of the Dordogne be without their hapless British clients? As a social phenomenon, the migration seems altogether benign. There is no hint in the Auvergne of those tensions that have arisen in, say, Jutland over the purchase (by Germans) of Danish farmsteads nor the anxiety felt by Poles and Czechs about the acquisition of homeland by non-nationals. France and Italy are expansive. Just as the geometra of the average Tuscan commune simply rubs his hands when non-natives arrive to buy out the dilapidated contadini, the French too take foreigners' bankers' drafts without complaint.

There is, however, a puzzle here. Those UK owners of French property ought to be euro-enthusiasts. The single currency would make it a lot easier to pay the boucher and the boulanger. Britain in Europe has either missed a trick with this constituency or, strange to relate, French property owners love the countryside, food and wine but have no wish to get any closer to the French. Once it was thought that travel translated into liberal political attitudes; freer access to the continent would expand Euro-consciousness. Yet the evidence is ambiguous. Owning a house in la France profonde does not bring engagement with the neighbours; it may not change basic attitudes on either side. Property used to be considered a handmaiden of conservatism, a stake in the land. These Brits in theory form a French interest group with a lot in common with the Gallic version of the Countryside Alliance. They might even aspire to wield influence in Paris. Except to do that they would have to speak the language.

webTitle: War on extremists turns into muddle

fields.headline: War on extremists turns into muddle
fields.trailText: The German government was in disarray yesterday over what its leader had heralded as a drive against the extreme right.
fields.body:
The German government was in disarray yesterday over what its leader had heralded as a drive against the extreme right.

In a magazine interview the interior minister, Otto Schily, gave a firm thumbs-down to proposals for a ban on the most radical legal far-right group. Earlier the idea had been given a sympathetic reception by Mr Schily's cabinet colleague, the environment minister Jürgen Trittin.

Almost two weeks after Chancellor Gerhard Schröder launched a campaign against the ultra-right, it is still far from clear what the authorities actually intend to do.

The weekend brought evidence of renewed police zeal in dealing with neo-Nazi skinheads; and Mr Schily told the news magazine Der Spiegel that he was considering deploying border police in areas of racial tension.

But if the government hoped to inspire a general public stand against the extremists, the signs were not promising.

Last week Mr Schröder's spokesman called on Germans to become personally involved in combating neo-Nazi thuggery. On Friday night in the eastern city of Eisenach more than 300 people did gather in support of two Africans who had been spat at, kicked and chased by a gang.

But a march against racial violence in Düsseldorf, a city of almost 600,000 people, at tracted no more than 1,300 the following day. It was called after a home-made shrapnel bomb went off outside a station injuring 10 immigrants, six of them Jewish. One was a pregnant woman who lost her unborn baby. No one has claimed responsibility.

A rally in the same city in favour of tougher measures against certain breeds of dog two weeks earlier brought out 10 times as many people.

On Saturday the police arrested 100 neo-Nazis in the eastern state of Thuringia as they tried to get to a banned rally called by the National Democratic Party (NPD).

So far the main effect of the controversy has been to provide the ultra-right with a rare bout of sustained media coverage. The NPD has seized the moment to propose a march through the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin in January to mark the liberation of Auschwitz.

It is the NPD that Bavaria's interior minister, Günther Beckstein, said last week should be outlawed. The idea was taken up by Mr Trittin, a leading Green minister in the governing coalition of Social Democrats and Greens.

But it was rejected at the weekend not only by Mr Schily but also by the interior ministers of Thuringia and Saxony-Anhalt, two of the regions most prone to neo-Nazi violence.

They predicted a ban would run foul of the constitutional court and, even if approved, would merely drive the movement underground.

webTitle: Spain torn over role as a key EU gatekeeper.

fields.headline: Spain torn over role as a key EU gatekeeper.
fields.standfirst: In the dangerous waters west of Gibraltar, a lone patrol boat searches for the Africans who risk all for a share of European prosperity.
fields.trailText: Exhausted, thirsty and dejected, Christian Nikei, his wife Maris and their friend were intercepted by a civil guard cutter within metres of their destination: Europe's southern shore.
fields.byline: Adela Gooch in Algeciras southern Spain
fields.body:
Exhausted, thirsty and dejected, Christian Nikei, his wife Maris and their friend were intercepted by a civil guard cutter within metres of their destination: Europe's southern shore.

Hauled on board the Spanish patrol boat from a flimsy rubber dinghy, they slumped in the cold early morning light, their journey over.

They were the latest addition to the ranks of illegal immigrants caught this year - 7,000, according to the authorities in Andalucia - while risking their lives crossing the treacherous Strait of Gibraltar from Africa in search of a better future.

They said they were political refugees from Sierra Leone, who had come by way of Mauritania, and had organised the journey for themselves.

Christian looked fit and healthy in contrast to his two companions. His wife and the friend needed urgent medical attention. Their skin was burned by a mixture of petrol and salt water. It was quicker to take them in the patrol boat to hospital in the southern Spanish port of Algeciras.

"We won't be separated?" Christian asked as he gazed at his wife shivering inside the cabin and his emaciated friend lying on the deck beside him, nearly unconscious.

Their story seemed plausible but none of it was likely to be true, the sergeant in charge of the patrol, Antonio, said.

Christian had been well briefed to say the things likely to make it possible for him to stay in Spain, he said. He had almost certainly used one of the mafias that charge up to 500,000 pesetas (£1,850) a head to bring people over.

Every night two patrol boats based in Algeciras, next to Gibraltar, set out to try to stop the human tide. One heads 30 miles east to Estepona, where the Costa del Sol begins. The other turns west, through the strait.

Back and forth they trail, watching the radar screen, listening to the radio, but well aware that they cannot catch all the vessels hoping to sneak by. According to one police estimate, Spain stops fewer than a quarter of the illegal immigrants heading for its shores.

"We're not inhuman, but it's our job and we have to do it," said Pascual, one of the four paramilitary guards patrolling the strait on the night Christian was picked up.

As a signatory to the Schengen treaty - the agreement by which a majority of EU members have sought to eliminate border controls between themselves - Spain has the thankless task of policing one of the main southern routes for illegal entrants: across the Strait of Gibraltar, where the gap between rich and poor is just 20 miles of hazardous water.

The Spanish authorities say that at least 250 people have died trying to cross since 1998. An estimate in the Moroccan daily Libération said over 3,000. No one really knows.

Increasingly desperate, the Spanish government has toughened its controls. Under the old law illegal immigrants were entitled to stay in Spain after two years in the country with a job. Now the threshold has been raised to five years, and it will be harder to bring in relatives and easier to throw immigrants out.

The law includes measures against human traffickers and fines of up to 10m pesetas (£37,000) for employing illegals.

Until the 1970's Spain was itself an exporter of labour. Now part of the affluent north, it is struggling to keep immigrants out while pressing the EU to invest more on the southern shores of the Mediterranean to stop them coming.

Immigrants from Morocco and other parts of north and sub-Saharan Africa have been joined more recently by eastern Europeans and Pakistanis crossing the Pyrenees.

Spain is torn between its need for labour and its fear of integrating newcomers in a society that has stayed remarkably homogeneous since the end of the 15th century when Jews and Arabs were expelled. Foreigners form only 2% of the population, about 1m people; just under half of these are northern Europeans living in the affluent coastal ghettos.

One of a series of amnesties for illegal immigrants has just ended. The number of applicants for legal status was more then twice that expected: 180,000 will achieve legal status as a result; several thousand will be turned away.

In December a new law provided for about 70,000 immigrants to settle each year. But the centre-right government, fearing a racist backlash, has retreated from full implementation. In the past year there have been clashes in Andalusia and Catalonia, where many immigrants do the jobs Spaniards no longer wish to take on.

Civil guards patrol the notorious N340 coast road north of Algeciras to try to stop trucks and vans packed full of immigrants. "It's only a matter of time," one said, " before something happens here like the Dover disaster" when 58 Chinese would-be immigrants were found dead in June of heat and suffocation in a lorry.

webTitle: Iran's leader stamps on freedom

fields.headline: Iran's leader stamps on freedom
fields.standfirst: Ayatollah tells MPs to spike their reformist press bill.
fields.trailText: The supreme leader of Iran, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, ordered the reformist parliament yesterday to abandon its promise to expand freedom of speech and revive the banned progressive press.
fields.body:
The supreme leader of Iran, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, ordered the reformist parliament yesterday to abandon its promise to expand freedom of speech and revive the banned progressive press.

It was seen as a step toward re-asserting clerical rule over participatory democracy.

Ayatollah Khamenei's action runs counter to the hopes of millions whose votes in February's general election sent to parliament a majority of reformists who had run on platforms including a free press.

Using his powers to intervene in the legislative process, the ayatollah issued a letter to the 290 MPs concerning a new bill meant to amend the restrictive press law. When the letter was read aloud in the chamber, scuffles broke out on the floor.

"If the enemies infiltrate the press, this will be a big danger to the country's security and the people's religious beliefs," he wrote.

"I do not deem it right to keep silent . . . The bill is not legitimate and not in the interest of the system and the revolution."

Iranians have been waiting to see when and how the conservative establishment would try to use its overwhelming power to challenge republican rule.

Under the constitution, the supreme leader, who is appointed by a body of conservative clerics, has the final say in all matters of state. But it came as a surprise that Ayatollah Khamenei intervened in such a blatant and public way.

Some MPs voiced outrage and threatened to resign. Others said they planned to write to Ayatollah Khamenei in protest, and reformist sources said they were afraid that one of their colleagues could face criminal charges for protesting against the leader's action too vociferously.

The Iranian press has given the reform movement a powerful voice; the ayatollah used a speech in April to label some newspapers, "bases of the enemy".

For this reason, conservatives in the judiciary shut down these publications, beginning in April, and jailed at least half a dozen editors and commentators. Some were imprisoned for up to five years; others were released on bail but banned from involvement in writing or publishing.

Yesterday the reformist MPs were poised to make such restrictive measures more difficult by passing a new press law which would require legal action to be taken against newspaper publishers, rather than against individual writers, thus lifting the threat of jail sentences from journalists.

The law would have changed the composition of a press supervisory board, which licenses publications, to include more reformers.

Reformist MPs knew that the extent of their power remained uncertain. Even if they had rallied a majority to vote for the bill, it could still have been vetoed by the Guardian Council, a body of conservative clerics and jurists charged with deciding if legislation conforms to Islamic law.

It often uses this power to veto legislation it disagrees with for political reasons.

Mohammad Reza Khatami, deputy speaker of parliament and the head of the Islamic Iran Participation Front, the reformers' biggest faction, which functions like a political party, acknowledged the movement's limitations last week.

Mr Khatami, the brother of President Mohammad Khatami, said the new MPs should lower their expectations for change.

The parliamentary speaker, Mehdi Karroubi, a senior cleric approved by Ayatollah Khomenei to lead parliament against the wishes of the reformers, reminded MPs of the limitations of republican rule.

"Our constitution has the elements of the absolute rule of the supreme clerical leader and you all know this and approve of this," he said. "We are all duty-bound to abide by it."

To counter the gains that reformers have made through the ballot box in municipal and parliamentary elections, conservatives have asserted their power in the judiciary and law enforcement - the institutions they dominate.

Many reformers now say publicly that it will take many years to achieve political pluralism. Mohsen Kadivar, a prominent cleric who was released from prison after being given an 18-month sentence, said it was unrealistic to expect freedom of speech in Iran to happen quickly.

Mr Kadivar was jailed for a series of articles he wrote accusing the clerical establishment of behaving like the shah's regime.

"We are living in a third world country. There is a 2,500-year history of despotism," he said. "It is natural that there should be resistance in the face of freedom. The judiciary respects neither the law, nor religious standards, nor public opinion.

"But the fact that they arrest their opponents, rather than kill them like they did before, is progress."

webTitle: After 40 years and millions of posters, Che's photographer sues for copyright

fields.headline: After 40 years and millions of posters, Che's photographer sues for copyright
fields.trailText: Che Guevara's appearance at the front of a makeshift platform at a memorial service in Havana lasted just a few moments. But in that short time the newspaper photographer Alberto Diaz Gutierrez managed to capture the essence of the Latin American revolutionary with such perfection that his messianic image became a 20th-century icon and the pin-up of rebellious students around the world.
fields.body:
Che Guevara's appearance at the front of a makeshift platform at a memorial service in Havana lasted just a few moments. But in that short time the newspaper photographer Alberto Diaz Gutierrez managed to capture the essence of the Latin American revolutionary with such perfection that his messianic image became a 20th-century icon and the pin-up of rebellious students around the world.

Gutierrez, better known as Alberto Korda, is delighted that his photograph has inspired socialist revolutionaries for more than three decades. But the appropriation of the image for an advertising campaign by the promoters of Smirnoff vodka has spurred him into taking action to reassert his intellectual rights. For not only was Guevara an opponent of the sort of imperial capitalism practised by an international drinks firm, Korda says, he was also near teetotal.

In what is expected to be a landmark copyright case, Korda is suing the advertising agency that developed the campaign for "spicy" vodka, the London-based Lowe Lintas (formerly Lowe Howard-Spink), and the picture agency that supplied the image, Rex Features. If the case is not settled before the suit is heard, it will come before the high court in London next month.

Korda, now 71 and still living in Cuba, may travel to give evidence. "I was offended by the use of the image," he said. "To use the image of Che Guevara to sell vodka is a slur on his name and memory. He never drank himself, he was not a drunk and drink should not be associated with his immortal memory."

In his claim to the high court, he accuses the advertising firm of trivialising the historical significance of the photograph by overprinting it with a hammer and sickle motif, in which the sickle was a chilli pepper.

Korda will have to prove that the picture was, in fact, taken by him. The London-based Cuba Solidarity Campaign, which is supporting him, believes his case is strong: Korda still has the camera with which he took the picture, and the negative.

Lowe Lintas and Rex Features have declined to comment, but it is thought they will seek to argue that no one owns the copyright to the picture because it has been used so extensively and, in effect, is in the public domain.

The picture was taken on March 5 1960 at a memorial service for more than 100 crew members of a Belgian arms cargo ship, killed in an attack for which Cuba blamed counter-revolutionary forces aided by the US. Korda was assigned to cover the ceremony, whose guests included Simone de Beauvoir and Jean-Paul Sartre.

"Che was standing on the row behind Fidel [Castro] on the platform," said Korda. "You couldn't see him. Then suddenly he stepped forward to the edge of the platform. I was standing below.

"I saw him step forward with this absolute look of steely defiance as Fidel spoke. It was only a brief moment that I had. I managed to shoot two frames and then he was gone."

Korda's newspaper was more interested in his pictures of Castro, but the photographer liked the image of Guevara and hung it on the wall in his Havana studio.

Seven years later, and now yellowed by tobacco smoke, the picture was still on the wall when an Italian publisher, Giangiacomo Feltrinelli, called, brandishing a letter of introduction from a senior official in the Cuban administration asking Korda for a copy. Korda handed the visitor two prints, declining to make a charge.

Guevara was killed a few months later and was immediately hailed a martyr to the revolution. There are conflicting stories of how the photograph came to gain such currency, but it became a rallying image in the student revolts in Paris of 1968, and Feltrinelli was quick to capitalise on its value. Of the millions of posters featuring the image that appeared around the world, some, Korda has said, even bore the notice "copyright Feltrinelli". Yet Korda does not bear a grudge against the enterprising publisher. "I still forgive him because by doing what it did he made it famous."

Undoubtedly it was the picture's iconic status that appealed to the advertising agency and, in good faith, it sourced the image from Rex, a reputable picture agency, for a billboard and magazine campaign last year. But Korda was furious.

"Che was an example as a man and we are his example to the world right now,"he said. "It is to honour his memory that I wish to have my right to the image recognised. Like I said, it is a slur on his character that he should be used to sell vodka."

Alberto Korda was interviewed for the Cuba Solidarity Campaign by Dr Stephen Wilkinson. Requests to reproduce the image can be directed to the campaign, on 020-7263 6452

fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the Argentine-Irish-Cuban hero, and why he's back in the news nearly 33 years after his death
fields.trailText: All you need to know about the Argentine-Irish-Cuban hero, and why he's back in the news nearly 33 years after his death.
fields.body:
1. Che Guevara's face is the face of revolution. Posters of it have gazed down on a million rooms, many of them occupied by students.

2. The famous picture was taken by Alberto Korda, who has never received a penny in royalties.

3. Fidel Castro believes that copyright is "imperialist bullshit". So did Korda, which is why he gave away his precious image to Italian publisher Giangiacomo Feltrinelli, who made a bomb out of it.

4. Korda has now changed his mind and is trying to reclaim his copyright. He's brassed off that ad company Lowe Lintas is using his picture in its campaign for Smirnoff's spicy vodka.

5. Che Guevara was Argentine of Irish extraction. He came from a well-to-do family, but became an ardent Marxist.

6. When he joined Castro's guerrillas in the 1950s, Korda was starting out as a fashion photographer in Havana.

7. Guevara was murdered by US-trained Bolivian troops in 1967. Had he lived, he would have been 71 today, the same age as Korda.

8. His bones were reburied in Cuba, his adopted homeland, three years ago.

9. The man they still call El Comandante remains a pop icon.

10. Images of Che in revolutionary mode abound on the net. You can also hear him, and discuss him. And, of course, buy the tee-shirt.

webTitle: For the chop:  Spanish play shocks Edinburgh fringe

fields.headline: For the chop:  Spanish play shocks Edinburgh fringe
fields.trailText: For years its critics have called it bland, bloated and sometimes even boring, but the Edinburgh Fringe Festival kicked off yesterday with scandals already blazing and the promise of even more shocks to come.
fields.body:
For years its critics have called it bland, bloated and sometimes even boring, but the Edinburgh Fringe Festival kicked off yesterday with scandals already blazing and the promise of even more shocks to come.

Chief among the atrocities on taste being committed this year and which have already worked the city's more conservative councillors into a lather, is the Spanish show Yllana's 666 in which four performers wield 3ft phalluses. Another Australian show called Puppetry of the Penis has already sparked calls for a ban from the Church of Scotland.

There has also been anger about a new Steven Berkoff play about Christ, the Messiah, which depicts him as "one of the lads, who liked a few drinks and was close to being a rock'n'roller with groupies", according to the author.

The start of the world's biggest arts festival was marked with a parade that included 16 marching bands and was watched by about 150,000 people.

The city's population is expected to double in the coming three weeks as performers and visitors flock to the Fringe, the official International Festival, and a host of other events.

The Fringe will see 1,350 companies and individuals giving nearly 17,000 performances in 177 venues throughout the city.

webTitle: Arts: Rebecca Lenkiewicz interviewed

fields.headline: What's a nice girl like you doing with a play like this?
fields.standfirst:
Fiachra Gibbons meets the table dancer turned writer
Special report: the Edinburgh Festival 2000
fields.trailText: Fiachra Gibbons meets the table dancer turned writer.
fields.body:
Rebecca Lenkiewicz is the kind of girl your mother would love you to bring home. She has big, blue, innocent eyes and the smile of a naïf. She was also once a table dancer and now she has written a play to tell the world about it.

Before you jump to any conclusions - and people are apt to do just that, as Lenkiewicz has discovered to her cost - table dancing is not quite lap dancing. "There is a distinction," she says, biting her lip. "You dance up on a stage in your bra and knickers and try to get the men to beckon you to their table, where you strut your stuff for £5 a dance. Then they buy champagne and you are supposed to sit down and talk to them about their day. I found that bit very hard. It felt wrong. The girls who were really good got presents and large tips from their regulars. Customers do ask you to sleep with them, but I didn't. But yeah, a few of the girls mixed it with prostitution."

Soho - A Tale of Table Dancers follows four dancers and their socially inept manager at the fictional Club Venus through a particularly eventful night. "I didn't want to write an evil, sleazy man figure because the manager I knew wasn't quite like that. He was proud of his girls and ran the place like a military operation."

She began writing it as a comedy but the more she wrote "the darker it became. I'm very self-conscious and dancing for somebody is very odd because it is both intimate and impersonal at the same time. There is something fundamentally wrong with society sexually if needs have to be fulfilled in these ways. The whole porn industry works on a very weird basis. I never quite know what the men get out of it. I remember this particular guy who had two beautiful brunettes sitting next to him to pour his champagne and he just looked so miserable and bored. I thought he was going to cry."

Lenkiewicz, 31, answered a small ad four years ago when she came to London with the vague aim of becoming an actress. Working in a cafe was never going to give her enough money for drama school. "I was having this not very great affair. I was feeling a bit raw. If life had been sunny, I probably wouldn't have done it."

She steeled herself to walk down the steps into a Soho basement ("You really felt you were going into the underworld"), and found that the audition gave an unlikely boost to her self-esteem. "I was amazed I got through it. There were about 20 of us and we had to walk into this room in front of this funny little guy who said, 'OK, get yer clothes off and let's see you move.' He put this sexy music on and we all bumbled around. There was this Yugoslavian girl and she was very beautiful and moved like a cat. I thought, 'Oh, my God, what am I doing?' After about five minutes the music stopped and he said, 'We'll have you, you and you.' I know it's strange, but I felt excited. I never questioned whether I should go back."

This, though, is not the story of a vulnerable girl who was used, abused and spat out by the sex industry, and her play does not carry that kind of baggage. For Lenkiewicz, who also performs in the play, the experience of stripping for "deflated, worried and rather unhappy men" every night for two months was rewarding. "OK, it wasn't like doing a year with VSO, and it is not something I am exactly proud of - as a little girl you don't dream of being a table dancer - but it has enriched me and my understanding of people. I did meet one or two unhappy women, but very few felt like victims. You didn't feel you were pouring your soul down the drain. They were good women. The banter was amazing, and you have to be confident to do it."

Nor was there much bitchiness among the girls. "Sure, you had to be a shark at times - £5 a dance is not very much when you can be hanging round all night. I never made much because I only danced, and I never gave up working in the cafe. But for some, the money was addictive."

As the weeks wore on, Lenkiewicz, who was brought up in bohemian poverty by her mother in Plymouth, felt a solidarity with women who have been quietly doing "these strange but necessary jobs" at the edge of society. "I felt a bond with them, a realisation that women have been doing this kind of work in secret for ever - going back to their families or husbands and boyfriends at night, bringing in money and yet being made to feel ashamed for it."

Her lowest moments came not in the club but in a theatre when she let it drop to a group of fellow actors that she was working as a dancer at night. "They looked at me as if I was a piece of meat, and laughed." Even so, she doesn't feel she is exposing herself by writing the play. "My only worry is about how good it will be."

 Soho - A Tale of Table Dancers is part of the RSC Fringe at the Pleasance (0131-556 6557) tomorrow, then in rep till August 14.

webTitle: Crunching the Beeb's numbers

fields.headline: Crunching the Beeb's numbers
fields.standfirst: August 7 2000: A special report by David Elstein gets to grips with with the BBC's annual report and accounts.
fields.trailText: August 7 2000: A special report by David Elstein gets to grips with with the BBC's annual report and accounts.
fields.body:
The Commons culture, media and sport committee returned to one of its favourite topics last week: the BBC's annual report and accounts.

Not surprisingly, the committee homed in on News 24, which it had previously derided as a waste of public money. This time, the target was the BBC's "misguided and misleading" method of comparing the audience share and reach of News 24 with that of Sky News. The BBC aggregates viewing of News 24's output on BBC 1 and BBC 2 along with audience of the channel itself, not surprisingly coming up with better figures than Sky News can manage, restricted as it is to cable, satellite and digital distribution. The committee recommended that future annual reports abandon this practice and instead give like-for-like figures.

The committee concluded that "trying to hold the BBC to account through scrutiny of the annual report and accounts is akin to trying to grasp an eel".

This is a little unfair, as the 1999-2000 document is certainly a step forward from previous efforts. The cringe-worthy fake quotes from governors have gone. There is a much clearer lay-out of how the BBC's statement of promises is to be tested, and how the governors assess the BBC's public services. There is the occasional frank admission - standards on BBC TV are described as "simply too variable", with both channels "still too reliant on lighter factual material". New members of the executive committee are no longer offered a private car as well as a chauffeur-driven car. The broadcast and production split has been abandoned.

Much else is, true enough, glossed over. The attempt to impose "bi-medialism" on TV and radio news - a simultaneous Birtian attack on common sense, professional standards, commercial wisdom and the English language - has also been buried, but not acknowledged. The pledge to increase the BBC's percentage of spend on content from 76% to 85% over five years has already been amended to a three-year target, according to Greg Dyke's evidence to the Commons committee, and will be driven by staff reductions - yet the annual report reveals that staff numbers increased by nearly 400 last year.

The Commons committee finally pinned down what is not in the annual report - BBC Worldwide's annual targets for delivering cash flow back to the corporation over the next six years. It would be interesting to know if these are the same targets used to assess incentive payments for Worldwide's chief executive, Rupert Gavin. Having increased cash flow by just £1m last year, he is expected to deliver increases of £10m, £14m, £16m and £18m in the next four. Meanwhile, 70% of Worldwide's operating profits from publishing and programme sales were last year wiped out by losses (£19.6m) on channels overseas.

The BBC continues to insist that it meets all its fair trading obligations. Those of us who have seen BBC Worldwide favouring its own joint ventures in programme sales, failing to secure market prices, and allowing BBC Broadcast to dictate its trading policies will continue to treat these assurances with scepticism. Let's see when the fair trading compliance committee publishes, in its promised quarterly bulletin, an account of how Channel 5 was denied repeats of Bronowski's Ascent of Man.

And, by the way, where is the follow-up to last year's research showing that just 34% of the public regarded the BBC as accountable?

At least the BBC's accounts are a model of transparency compared with our other public broadcaster, Channel 4 (whose chairman believes they are so simple a child could understand them).

In a single year, Channel 4 managed to increase its staff by 20% and its overhead costs by 30%. No indication is given as to what constitutes £42.8m of "indirect programme costs". The cost of sales and marketing for the main channel has doubled in a year, to £40.7m - why? And what is the £25.8m cost of sales and marketing for "other activities"?

Opaque accounts can be obtained, separately, for Channel 4's subsidiary companies, like the production and distribution company, FilmFour Ltd. But the FilmFour subscription channel does not fall under this category. Its modest income is declared, but not its costs. These are buried in the overall accounts - a sleight of hand that is probably in breach of the 1996 Broadcasting Act, which requires Channel 4's ITC-licensed services to file separate accounts.

The fact that Channel 4's income is derived from its free access to valuable spectrum, rather than the licence fee, should not obscure its accountability to the public. Yet the Commons committee, while glaring balefully at the BBC, gives Channel 4 barely a second glance.

Meanwhile, a suggestion to both broadcasters: before you issue next year's accounts, invite a small team of independent scrutineers to read the draft and formulate a set of questions - and include the answers in the final version.

David Elstein is chief executive of Channel 5
